PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. Limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct. 86 to 1 July 87 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct. 86 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 12 citizens), Michael Baume (from 108 citizens), Peter Baume (from 19 citizens), Brownhill (from 151 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 11 citizens), Chaney (from six citizens), Childs (from 35 citizens), Collard (from seven citizens), Gareth Evans (from 31 citizens), Gietzelt (from 81 citizens), Hamer (from 22 citizens), MacGibbon (from 76 citizens), Reid (from nine citizens), Robertson (from 289 citizens), Short (from 26 citizens) and Vallentine (from eight citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: War Criminals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
If, there is to be legal process against alleged war criminals resident in Australia, the foundations of justice should be clear and equitable.
1. Let the term, ``war crime'', be first clearly defined.
2. Let specific prosecutions be swiftly launched against those individuals alleged to have committed them, thus releasing the rest of their co-nationals from unwarranted slur and suspicion.
3. Let an Australian tribunal hear the charges. Nobody should be deported to face the ``tender mercies'' of any foreign government.
4. Let the presumption of innocence until proved guilt be clearly established.
5. Let all evidence obtained from the Soviet or any other communist government be set aside and totally disregarded.

6. Let all the costs of any person charged and found not guilty be paid by the Commonwealth Government so that innocent people are not financially ruined in the course of establishing their innocence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Related Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
The costs of raising children are rising and the value of government provided economic assistance to families is declining.
Families raising children are providing a vital function to society and are deserving of government provided economic assistance.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
1. Restore family allowance payments to their 1976 real money value.
2. Provide for the regular and automatic indexation of family allowance payments.
3. Increase the value of the Dependant Spouse Rebate to $1851 per annum and convert it to a cash payment given directly to the non-income family spouse.
4. Amend the Family Income Supplement scheme so that its value is increased, its eligibility provisions widened and its withdrawal provisions eased.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Black (from 1,995 citizens) and Robertson (from 262 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Hawke Labor Government's high tax policies and the introduction of any new taxes including a wealth tax on the net wealth of individual Australians and Australian business is totally condemned and opposed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Not introduce an investment destroying wealth tax into the Senate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Multicultural Public Library Services: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows that there is an urgent need for Commonwealth financial assistance for the provision of multicultural public library services.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should take steps to ensure adequate assistance from the Commonwealth Government to public libraries throughout Australia for the provision of materials and services in languages other than English, as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts in its Report on a National Language policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers, about the proposal to Irradiate Food in Australia. Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Block the introduction of Food Irradiation into Australia.
(2) Ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
(3) Ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X ray etc.)
(4) Ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. There is no legal barrier to the importation of X-rated videos into the A.C.T. or to their sale in the A.C.T.
2. The Government has ignored the repeated protests of the Senate and the people of Canberra on this situation.
3. As a result X-rated videos are being sold from Canberra to other States, although they are banned in all States.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government to ban the importation and sale of X-rated video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Reid (from 221 citizens) and Ryan (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate. The petition of the undersigned do respectfully showeth that pornographic material relating to children is deleterious to the health and welfare of children and society as a whole.
We respectfully urge the Government to ban all child pornography from entering or from being produced, in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke-free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutions, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke-free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

We the undersigned citizens, call on the Commonwealth Government to introduce a ban on smoking on flights of 90 minutes or less. This ban should be introduced irrespective of the stand-off attitudes adopted by the airlines at present.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Australia Card.

(2) That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combatting the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

(3) That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
(4) That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Warships in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled and to the Australian Government. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
foreign warships visiting Australian ports give acceptability to the increasing militarisation of the Indian and Pacific Oceans;
W.A. endures a visit of a foreign warship on average every 1.5 weeks;
a situation of de facto `home-porting' facilities exists in W.A.;
there is increasing citizen concern that nuclear armed/nuclear powered warships put Australian ports and people at risk in many ways.
Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Australian Government refuse entry to Australian ports to all foreign warships.

PETITION.TITLE: Earth's Ecology: Nuclear Threat
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Uranium mining and processing is dangerous to the health and well-being and ecology of the Earth and its citizens,
By-products of uranium are toxics for periods of up to 500,000 years, and are an intrinsic part of the production of nuclear weapons,
Existing safeguards are inadequate, and are not properly monitored.
The policy of the Australian Government permits the entry into Australian territory of vessels and aircraft without the assurance that they are not nuclear powered or armed.
Such vessels pose a threat to both the security and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
The presence of foreign military and communication bases on Australian soil seriously endangers the health and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
Your petitioners humbly pray that your honourable Senators will take cognisance of the above and take immediate action to remove the above dangers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled, should be aware that a significant number of Australians:

Strongly protest that the Department of Social Security pays married-rate benefits to persons who are under the age of consent and living in a de-facto relationship involving the crimes of defilement and unlawful carnal knowledge, and strongly protest the 1985 decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which effectively encourages young people to leave home, establish a de-facto relationship, and then be paid $202.30 a week for their activities.
Accordingly, your petitioners call upon their elected representatives to rectify this abhorrent practice.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Battery Egg Production
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the confinement of laying hens in battery cages is cruel and unnecessary and totally ignores the welfare of the birds.

The aviary system of egg production approved by R.S.P.C.A. allows the birds to exercise, socialise, lay eggs in nests and move quite freely. Offers protection from the elements and predators, permits excellent disease and parasite control and enables easy supervision.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:
Request the Government to introduce a Bill to phase out the battery method of egg production within five years and where appropriate offer tax deductible incentives to producers to do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-
(a) the nature, function, ambit and adequacy of income tax rulings issued by the Commissioner of Taxation; and
(b) the process by which these rulings are formulated and disseminated.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 December 1982 the Australian Taxation Office introduced a taxation ruling system. This system was established as a means of publishing and disseminating decisions on interpretation of the laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation. The system was instituted to enable the Commissioner to fulfil the obligations imposed by the Freedom of Information Act 1982, to make available for public scrutiny copies of documents which are used by his officers in making decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The system of taxation rulings is, of course, not new. As early as the 1930s the Taxation Office used to publish what were known as income tax orders. In fact, one of these rulings is still operative. It is known as Income Tax Order 1217 and it sets out the rates of depreciation determined by the Commissioner of Taxation. Similarly, the publication of taxation rulings is not new. In 1965 the Commissioner of Taxation issued a series of public information bulletins setting out the manner in which the then new taxation discretions would be exercised. However, this practice did not last long. The last of those public information bulletins was issued in 1966. The present system of income tax rulings may fairly be said to be a product of the Freedom of Information Act. The authority to issue these income tax rulings is generally thought to stem from the power of general administration of the taxation legislation. The rulings are essentially designed for use by the Commissioner's staff. Taxation rulings have replaced memoranda and other forms of advice from the central office of the Australian Taxation Office, relating to new or considered interpretations of taxation laws. They are issued in respect of decisions which satisfy three conditions, decisions which provide an interpretation, guideline, precedent, practice or procedure to be followed in making a decision that effects the rights or liabilities of taxpayers; establish a new or revised interpretation of the administration of the tax laws; and affect all taxpayers or a section of the tax-paying community, that is, not simply an individual instance.

Since 15 February 1984 the Commissioner of Taxation has met regularly with what is known as the tax liaison group, representing the principal professional bodies with which the Australian Taxation Office has frequent dealings. The purpose of these meetings is to allow the various parties to air their views on current issues within the taxation area. In late 1986, the Commissioner indicated that he would, in future, be circulating draft copies of the more significant tax rulings to the professional bodies involved with the tax liaison group and to some other appropriate organisations prior to their release to the public. The rulings have consequently become an agenda item at meetings of the tax liaison group.

The Committee is aware that the present system of rulings is not universally acclaimed. For example, the Commissioner's income tax rulings are not binding, as they cannot replace the law or take on the status of law. There are suggestions, however, that the rulings should be binding. For this among other reasons the Committee wishes to examine the nature, status and operation of the rulings.

The Committee is also aware of criticisms of the consultative process leading up to the issuing of rulings. These criticisms have come from groups which claim that their interests are not adequately represented. The Committee wishes to examine and evaluate the procedure by which rulings come into operation in order to assess the validity of these criticisms. The Committee is mindful of the need to confine its deliberations to the specific matters set out in the proposed reference. Accordingly-this will be of interest to Senator Haines, amongst others-the Committee will conduct its enquiries with a view to reporting to the Senate in the Budget sitting. I promise to send Senator Haines a copy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 May we began debate on this package of Aboriginal land rights and related Bills. At the time I was addressing the bulk of my comments to the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill 1987 because these two Bills result from the reference to the Commonwealth Parliament of legislation relating to Aboriginal land rights and cultural heritage from the Victorian Government. This was necessary because the Victorian Government, having engaged in extensive consultations with the Vic- torian Aboriginal community on the issues of land rights for two particular Aboriginal communities in Victoria and on issues surrounding the protection and development of the cultural heritage of the Victorian Aboriginal communities, had prepared legislation in the form of three Bills for presentation and passage through the Victorian Parliament. Unfortunately that process came to a halt as a result of the attitude taken to this legislation by the Opposition parties in the Victorian Parliament. It is interesting to look at that and to understand that the reason why we now have these Bills before us today is that the Liberal and National parties in the Victorian Parliament were not prepared to pass legislation giving land rights to the Aboriginal communities at Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest and providing for the protection of the Aboriginal cultural heritage in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills, as they were prepared in Victoria, were a package of three-the two land rights areas being taken separately and the third dealing with the cultural heritage issue. I have expressed concern that in following the reference to this Parliament the land rights legislation has been put together in a package of one Bill. I am concerned because the two communities involved are quite separate and there are differences in their nature. The Australian Democrats would have preferred the Commonwealth Parliament to deal with them separately in the same way as the Victorian Government had intended. However, we have satisfied ourselves that the passage of this legislation will not have any impact on the Framlingham community in the event that it does not take up the option provided for in this legislation for incorporation under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. Indeed, that has been a matter of great concern to that community because its preference was for the legislation to be passed in Victoria and, certainly, we would have supported that preference.

It was interesting to note that there was an announcement this morning in the Melbourne Sun by Mr Lauchlan McIntosh, the Executive Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, that should this legislation be passed the mining industry will go to a court of challenge. Mr McIntosh is quoted in this morning's Sun as saying that the land should have been handed over by State legislation to avoid confusion in this issue. I am in total agreement with that position, and I believe it is interesting that groups as diverse as the Aboriginal community in Framlingham, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Mining Industry Council all agree on that point. However, it being the case that the Victorian Government was unable to get support for this legislation from the Opposition parties, which attempted to carry out a campaign in the public arena through the Leader of the State Opposition, Mr Jeff Kennett, going around Victoria, in particular western Victoria, expressing opposition to, and making extravagant claims about the detrimental effects of, passing across ownership of inalienable rights to the land-a small parcel of land to which these Aboriginal communities certainly have a right-demonstrating the unwillingness of the Opposition parties to support this legislation, there was a reference to this Parliament. At that time the Australian Democrats expressed support for this reference.

Since the reference to this Parliament we have been concerned to ensure that the legislation which comes before us satisfies the wishes of the Aboriginal communities as had been expressed through some years of extensive consultation in Victoria. We have been pleased to note that in relation to both the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill 1987 there has been considerable continuing consultation with the Victorian communities and that once the Bills were drafted for this Parliament, the Government was further prepared to make more amendments to satisfy some of the concerns of the communities and their advisers.

To point up the particular concerns which had been expressed in relation to the Aboriginal land rights legislation and the putting together of the two communities, we point out that although the two communities share much in their aboriginality they each have traditions which are distinct and, importantly, there is a difference in their structures. The Aboriginal land rights legislation before us today legislates to enable the two communities to secure their land but requires the communities to become incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976 before they can receive their land. For the people of Lake Condah this presents no problem as they have been incorporated under the Commonwealth Act since 21 December 1984. For the Framlingham people, however, the situation is different because they are not as yet incorporated and they have presented to us their concerns about being incorporated under the Commonwealth Act. I understand that on a number of occasions the Framlingham community has pointed out to the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) its wish not to be incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act because it believes that under that Act the community control cannot operate to the degree to which it would want it.

As well as that, the Framlingham community also expressed to me its concern about possible forthcoming amendments to the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. In my inquiries into this the Minister informed me that the Government intends introducing an amending Bill this year. The concerns of the Framlingham community with regard to these amendments include the possibility of the Minister or his delegate having power to cease funding of an organisation if the Minister or his delegate believes that a director or staff person is not an appropriate person. It is also concerned that amendments may include other restrictions relating to the funding or granting of land. In the Minister's response to my inquiries on these matters he has informed me that the amending legislation will not give the Minister power to cease funding an organisation on the basis that the director is not an appropriate person. However, it will include a provision similar to the rules of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs relating to grants for assistance to or for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders which prevents people who have recently been convicted of offences involving bankruptcy or fraud from holding office in Aboriginal corporations.

The Minister further advises that under the proposed amendments Aboriginal organisations will be entitled to receive funds or land as long as they are incorporated under appropriate Commonwealth, State or Territory legislation. We believe that the amendments cover the concerns expressed to us by the Framlingham community and we recognise that under the legislation before us today, that community has the choice of whether or not to become incorporated under the Federal Councils and Associations Act. Should the community decide not to become incorporated they will need to consider returning to the Victorian Government in their efforts to gain title to their land. That decision remains theirs to make.

The Australian Democrats have consulted with members of the Lake Condah and Framlingham communities and we believe that a number of questions and concerns which arose out of the redrafting involved in the transferring of Victorian legislation to the Commonwealth have been resolved. While we support the views of the Kerrup-Jmara and the Kirrae Whurrong communities that there should have been two separate pieces of legislation, we reiterate our commitment to Aboriginal land rights as set down in Australian Democrat policy and therefore support, in general terms, the passage of this legislation.

I address some remarks in particular to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill 1987. It is vital that legislation such as this be enacted for the Victorian Aboriginal community and that we see it as a move towards the regeneration of the Aboriginal culture in Victoria. However, it is of some concern to us that in the legislation before us today, as was the case in the original legislation presented to the Victorian Parliament, quite a considerable degree of emphasis is placed on the concept of ownership in relation to the heritage and culture of the Aboriginal community. This runs counter to the Aboriginal culture, which is one not of ownership but of stewardship. Indeed, in the preamble to the Bill reference is made to the Aboriginal people of Victoria as being the rightful owners of their heritage. We believe that this sort of terminology is somewhat inappropriate in this kind of legislation because, as I said, one of its major purposes should be towards the regeneration of a culture which is uniquely Australian and one which we should all-the whole community, including Aboriginals and all cultural backgrounds-see as part of our own, since, whatever our cultural heritage and background, we are now all Australians.

Strong elements of tribal values persist in Victoria despite enormous pressures on the original Aboriginal communities and culture in that State. Perhaps the strongest element is the continuing concept of stewardship, as opposed to ownership, of their Aboriginal culture and heritage. It is important that we, as a whole community, recognise the need to build the infrastructures of the Aboriginal community and to redevelop that cultural fabric in all of our interests, and that in order to do that, there is a need for a strong economic base for Aboriginal communities. It is encouraging to see that the development of such a base is well under way at Lake Condah. This is the sort of development which must be encouraged and, indeed, it is supported by the Australian Democrats. As I said, it is important when addressing issues of Aboriginal culture to see that culture as a feature of benefit to all sections of the community, so that in the end we can all share something which is part of our background.

This and other land rights legislation has a history of extensive and intensive consultation throughout the Victorian Aboriginal community, a community which is in a sense regionalised, which has bases around the State and which has been brought together on several occasions in the interests of developing legislation which will have the best result for all, as far as such a result can be achieved in the current situation. There are more than 7,000 known Aboriginal sites throughout Victoria. The future of these sites and of the Aboriginal heritage as a whole is in our minds when we consider legislation of this kind. It is important that those elements of this legislation which allow members of the Aboriginal community to retain their ability to be the stewards of their own culture be strongly supported. Deserving of congratulations is the fact that the communities and the Government in Victoria have spent a good deal of time addressing the issues and coming up with a solution which, although not supported unanimously, does the very best it can in a diverse environment to provide protection and an ongoing program for, as I said, not just the preservation but also the development of Aboriginal culture in Victoria, a State where I suppose the Aboriginal community is not as visible as perhaps it is in some of the other States. I refer, in particular, to the Northern Territory, in regard to which we are also now debating Bills cognately. In spite of a great deal of stress on the Aboriginal culture since white settlement there are very strong Aboriginal cultural elements in Victoria. The Aboriginal community is struggling very hard, through its own initiatives and through co-operation such as this, to make sure that its heritage survives and is shared.

I reiterate that the Bills before us have been referred to us from the Victorian Parliament because multipartisan support for it was not able to be achieved in Victoria. In the debate a couple of weeks ago it was pointed out by a Government senator that the situation in Victoria is similar to the situation in the Federal Parliament in that the Victorian Government does not have control of that State's upper House, the Legislative Council. However, there is one difference. In Victoria the Legislative Council numbers are held by the Opposition Liberal and National parties, which did not express support for this legislation and which campaigned publicly against the provision of inalienable land rights for the Victorian Aboriginal community.

There is a major difference between the situation with Victoria's upper House and the situation here. In the Senate these Bills receive the support of the Australian Democrats because of our very strong commitment to Aboriginal land rights and related legislation. Regrettably, at this time the Victorian Parliament does not have the advantage of having the Australian Democrats hold the balance of power in the Legislative Council. I confidently expect that after the next Victorian State election that position will have changed. Certainly, if the Framlingham people choose-as it appears they might-not to incorporate under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act and if they take their claim back to the Victorian Parliament, subsequent to the next Victorian election should there be a return of an Australian Labor Party government and the Australian Democrats have a position in the Legislative Council, the legislation should have a much more successful fate than it had earlier this year. There would have been no necessity for this matter to come to this Parliament had that parliamentary situation already been the case in Victoria. Twenty years ago black Australians were made Australian citizens. As we get into this debate again this is a significant anniversary. It is my pleasure to express support for these Bills on such an occasion and to express the support of the Australian Democrats for the national referendum which said that Aboriginal affairs should be in the hands of the Federal Government. I remind the Senate that over 90 per cent of Victorians supported that view and therefore, I believe, support the passage of these Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of four Bills before the Senate, dealing with Aboriginal land rights and related issues, is very important in its totality. I wish to address my remarks, however, to only two of those Bills, namely the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill. They relate very importantly to Aboriginal land rights and related issues, so far as artefacts and so on are concerned, in my State of Victoria. Some of the principles involved in the two Bills, of course, have much wider application. Let me say at the outset, to refute any implication that Senator Powell may have conveyed in her remarks, that the Liberal Party-as has every party in Australia, I believe-has a very strong commitment to appropriate, proper and right Aboriginal land rights. That is not an issue on which any one political party has a prerogative or monopoly of virtue.

SPEECH.PARA: What we say, which is contrary to the thinking of Senator Powell and the Australian Democrats, is that there are proper ways of going about such matters and less than proper ways. So far as we are concerned the Bills before the chamber do not reflect the right way in which parliaments of Australia ought to be going about the very important process of furthering the bipartisan development of land rights legislation. I say that in relation to the two Bills I want to discuss because the reason given for the two Bills being before us now is that the Victorian Labor Government under Mr Cain put pressure on the Federal Labor Government to introduce these Bills into this Parliament as the Victorian Government was unable to get them through the Victorian Parliament. However, it was not totally the case that it was unable to get them through the Victorian Parliament; in the case of one of them, the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill, the Victorian Cain Government refused to put to the vote in the upper House in Victoria certain important amendments moved by the Opposition which would have greatly improved the nature of the Bill. Those amendments were not defeated; rather, the Government, in a cowardly fashion and in an attempt to score cheap political points, refused to put the amendments to the vote. As a result, it has further abrogated its responsibilities as the Victorian State Government and, to my mind, it has incredibly conned the Federal Government into introducing the Bills which are before us. We on this side of the chamber say that that is a totally wrong thing to do.

We have before us matters that are very importantly matters for State governments being brought into this Federal Parliament for cheap political reasons, and I think the people of Australia ought to be aware of that. The Labor Government in Victoria should not be calling on the Federal Government to intervene in what, quite clearly, is an area of State responsibility simply because it claims to have some problems with its numbers in its Parliament. We are seeing here an attempt to circumvent the due processes of the State legislature. I guess that, having seen the record of State and Federal Labor governments over many years, perhaps we should not be surprised at what is going on. State Labor governments, but more particularly Federal Labor governments in Australia throughout our history, have shown a great penchant for centralisation as opposed to State rights and one must wonder what the people of Victoria feel when their own Premier abrogates his responsibilities to Canberra in important areas such as this.

Both Bills that I am speaking to have been introduced into this place as a result of the failure of the Victorian Government to exercise its own responsibilities. These Bills have been introduced into this place as a direct consequence of a request by the Victorian Government. For that reason, if for no other, the legislation is quite wrong in principle and it is certainly wrong in practice.

I would like now to turn to some of the details of the two pieces of legislation. First, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill contains provisions of the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Bill of Victoria. It allows for a revised regime for the protection of Aboriginal culture in Victoria. In particular, it states that any person may apply for an emergency declaration granted by the Minister, an inspector or magistrate providing that an Aboriginal place or object is under threat of injury or interference.

There have been various amendments to the original legislation. Briefly, amendments to the Schedules in the legislation may be made by regulation rather than by ministerial order. The inspector involved at the time will not have to rely on the advice of local Aboriginal communities to vary or revoke an emergency declaration. I point out that that is an overriding of the requirement to seek local Aboriginal community participation. When an arbiter decides to vary the Minister's decision it will take effect from the time of the decision first made by the Minister. Again, that is a notable change and one which is very questionable in my view. Relevant Aboriginal communities will be able to authorise in writing a person to enter land for the purpose of placing a notice. Clarification of the power of the Federal Court to grant injunctions under the principal Act with respect to Aboriginal objects and places, defined in proposed new section 21a of this amendment Bill, has also been made.

The legislation has been designed ostensibly to protect Aboriginal relics and cultural heritage. I believe very strongly, though, that it can be argued that it does the opposite. But certainly the point to be made is that these amendments that are being presented do not alter the substance of the Bill; it remains legislation which is very seriously defective. However, the objects of the legislation-and I have no objection to the broad objects-are contained in Victoria under the Archaeological and Aboriginal Relics Preservation Act 1972. The definitions of an Aboriginal object and an Aboriginal place in the Bill before the Senate are extremely broad. For example, an `Aboriginal object' is defined as including a natural object, whether living or inanimate, that is or has been of particular ritual or ceremonial importance to Aborigines from any part of Australia. The definition continues:
(b) that is or has been made, used or adapted for use for any purpose connected with the life of Aborigines in any part of Australia; or
(c) that is of particular historical importance and that was made, after the European settlement of Australia, by Aborigines for their own use or for sale.

An `Aboriginal place' is defined as a place to which a cultural, historical or religious significance is attached by Aborigines. The definition of `Aborigine' is also very broad. The legislation states that `Aborigine' means a person who is descended from an Aborigine, identifies as an Aborigine and is accepted as an Aborigine by the community of elders on behalf of the Kerrup-Jmara community.

The Bill empowers the Minister compulsorily to acquire Aboriginal artefacts. In addition, he will appoint inspectors, the inspectors being nominated by the local Aboriginal group. There is no limit, however, to the number of inspectors who can be appointed, nor are they required to have any special training or qualifications. These inspectors will have unrestricted entry into thousands of private properties but there is no provision for protection for owners of property or artefacts. Farmers, for example, have no incentive under the Bill to report such relics as they may find because they may well be fearful of the repercussions. Untrained, unqualified inspectors nominated by local Aboriginal communities and appointed by the Minister will have legal access to enter and search any Aboriginal site in Victoria. On the present figures, there are 7,000 known Aboriginal sites in Victoria alone.

These provisions will discourage research and public information about Aboriginal cultural heritage in Victoria. Anthropologists will be seriously restricted in their studies because access to Aboriginal relics will be limited. This, in turn, of course, has serious implications for the quality and quantity of anthropological research of Aboriginal culture. The Bill contains no research provision that would lead to the production of information so that the whole Victorian community could become familiar with Aboriginal culture and archaeological and scientific materials. It is also uncertain as to the preservation and ownership of skeletal material.

The irony of this legislation, Mr Acting Deputy President, is that it may well lead to the reckless removal of Aboriginal artefacts from places where they are currently extremely well cared for and preserved and where all Australians can have access to them. For instance, the Bill covers artefacts contained in certain museums. I have had representations in my State from representatives of the Daylesford community in Victoria, a community that is well respected for its wish to preserve culture and heritage of an Aboriginal or other nature.

The Daylesford museum is requesting the Government to exempt the artefacts it has in its museum in the same way as exemption has been granted to Alcoa of Australia Ltd in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill. I totally support this request by the Daylesford community. The artefacts belonged to the Loddon Valley tribes in Victoria and must not be removed from their traditional grounds. Already, other groups have announced their interest in these artefacts, wanting to shift them away to Ballarat or Melbourne, where the original tribes had no links with the Loddon Valley. The Daylesford people are proud, and very rightly so, of their zealous care and preservation of these artefacts. In their present location at the museum they are not only well secured but also available to be viewed by tens of thousands of school children and adults each year. In that sense the existence of the artefacts in the museum at Daylesford fulfils a very important purpose.

The provision providing for protection against unlawful seizure of artefacts from other tribal areas is inadequate and, I believe, consequently it is ineffective. Because the provisions of the Bill allowing for agreements to be made by Aboriginal communities, even if they have no tribal relationship with an area in which they have no traditional links, are weak and one-sided they will be ineffective in preserving artefacts in their natural tribal areas.

Appeal to the Minister is, in fact, no appeal at all. The grounds of appeal regarding the preservation of recognised collections should be spelt out in detail. That is not the case now and until the grounds are spelt out very considerable doubts must be held about the real power and value of the right of appeal contained in the Bill.

I turn now, briefly, to the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill, which seeks to provide for the vesting in Aboriginal communities of land in Victoria at Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest. It provides for the return of Framlingham Forest, which covers 1,130 hectares, and Lake Condah, which involves 53 hectares-both of which are Crown land administered under the Forests Act-to the Kerrup-Jmara community. This Bill, too, I believe, is wrong in principle and it is wrong in practice. Land usage under the Constitution is a State matter and the State should handle it whether it relates to Aboriginal land or to other land. That policy has been firmly entrenched in Liberal Party thinking and in the thinking of many Australians after very long and serious debate on it over many years. Of course, we are not-nor is anyone of whom I know-questioning the right of the Kerrup-Jmara and Kirrae Whurrong Aborigines to have title to the respective pieces of land. We totally support that right of theirs but what we do oppose is the need to involve the Federal Parliament.

The Government claims that the legislation before us has come about after consultation but the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has not even been to Framlingham Forest since he became the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I point out for those not familiar with the area that the Framlingham Forest is approximately three to four hours drive from Melbourne and a one-hour flight in a plane but the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who is based in Melbourne, has not been to Framlingham Forest since he has been the responsible Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good basis on which to draft proposed legislation!

—Quite right. It shows the absolute hypocrisy of the Hawke Government and particularly the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in his dealings with the very important and sensitive issues affecting the rights and values of the Aboriginal community in Australia. It is absolute hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only has the Minister not been to the Framlingham Forest but also he has not even consulted with the local government authorities in the area. If he had, he would have realised that this Bill he has brought into the Parliament has very considerable problems of a practical nature, apart from anything else. For example, the Bill provides for the closure of a road along the northern boundary of the land involved but if that road were closed it would prevent access to a section of the Darlet Creek and that is opposed by the Portland shire. It is an essential road and it cannot be closed.

The Shire of Warrnambool, which is the responsible local government authority in this matter, has pointed out that the road that now runs through Framlingham Forest is currently used by a milk tanker and by school buses and the like. If the road were closed it could reduce access for those sorts of purposes and also, very importantly, for firefighting vehicles in the area. The Bill is a very curious piece of legislation, not just to us on this side of the House but also to members of the Aboriginal community in the area. I quote from the comments of one Aboriginal leader which appeared in the Warrnambool Press recently, in March. He claimed that Mr Holding was trying to set himself up as some sort of white messiah. An article in the Warrnambool Standard of 26 March headed `Aborigines to fight land Bill' states:

Community leader Mr Geoff Clark said yesterday that Federal Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Mr Holding, was sweeping aside matters which had taken eight years of negotiations between the community and the State Government.

He said the Minister is an apologist for the Cain Government simply because the Cain Government was unable to get the confidence of its own Parliament. This legislation sets a very dangerous precedent indeed for the Commonwealth to pick up legislation of any nature that State governments are unable to get through their own parliaments, perhaps even if they are unwilling to try hard enough to do so.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has drawn attention to the enormous powers of delegation that are given under this Bill. I will quote from Alert Digest No. 5 of 1987 of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Under the heading `Sub-clause 5 (2)-Delegation' it says:

Subclause 5 (1) empowers the Minister to delegate to a Minister of the Crown of the State of Victoria all or any of the powers conferred on the Minister by the Act. Subclause 5 (2) enables a Victorian Minister to whom a power has been so delegated to authorise another person to exercise the power. It therefore enables the power to be delegated, in effect, to any person or the holder of any office whom the State Minister may nominate.

In other words, we are being asked to pass legislation whereby a Federal Minister can pass to a Minister in another government the power not only to act himself or herself but also to delegate to any other person the powers under this Bill. That is totally wrong, and it is very dangerous legislation indeed. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that it:
. . . has been critical of such powers of delegation which impose no limitation, and give no guidance as to the attributes of the person to whom a delegation may be made.
The Committee therefore drew the Senate's attention to sub-clause 5 (2) on the basis that:
. . . it may be considered to make rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers.

That is the type of dangerous, foolhardy and ill-thought through legislation that has been a hallmark of this Hawke Labor Government over the last four years. No wonder the community is confused as to the nature of some of the legislation coming into this place. More often than not, such legislation is pre-announced, months before its introduction, and the Bill that is subsequently introduced to give effect to the Press release method of legislation often bears little resemblance to that original Press release. A gap of months can be involved, and this produces fear, uncertainty and confusion in the minds of all those people who may be involved with that legislation. That has not been the case with these Bills. They are not an example of legislation by Press release. But the sloppiness of and dangers in this Bill which have been drawn to the Senate's attention by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee are typical of the concerns of senators on this side of the chamber.

The Bill does not accord the Aboriginal communities involved the same rights as normal property holders. For example, the title being offered to the Kerrup-Jmara community is without right of sale, without right of mortgage and without right of transfer except to other Aboriginal groups. The constriction on the Aboriginal community concerned is very tight indeed. That in turn puts it in a disadvantaged position with respect to any other section of the community. To give another example, the Bill allows Aboriginals to claim and be awarded more compensation and disturbance allowance as a result of mining than non-Aboriginal Victorian landowners. So on the one hand there are very tight restrictions on the Aboriginal community in terms of what it can do with the land, which disadvantages it; on the other hand, non-Aboriginal Victorians are disadvantaged vis-a-vis the Aboriginal groups in terms of compensation provisions. Again, this is a classic example of the confusion that arises in this Bill. Another example is that the Bill allows Aboriginals to veto the grant of exploration and mining titles over their land. Whilst the veto can be overturned by an arbiter, the whole process promotes direct confrontation between Aboriginals and miners. That, surely, is the last thing in which this Parliament ought to be getting involved in. What we should be involved in is attempting to promote harmony in racial relationships in this country, whether they involve Aboriginals or any other groups in our community.

The two Bills that I have been debating this morning-the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill-are bad legislation. They are bad in principle; they are bad in practice. They set dangerous precedents for the Federal Parliament to take over any legislation that State governments cannot get through their parliaments. The details of the legislation may well lead to the removal of Aboriginal artefacts from their traditional keeping places and to the loss of access by archaeologists and the Australian public. There is a wide resentment by Aboriginals in the wider community about aspects of this Bill, and other aspects of it will in turn lead the wider community to have feelings of resentment towards the Aboriginal communities. It is a very sad situation indeed that we in this Parliament could be involved in passing legislation that leads to those divisions in our community. The loss of control by the wider Aboriginal community of its cultural heritage and the ability to share in the economic benefits arising from the transfer and mining of its land is another matter of very serious concern to which I have already alluded.

I turn to a matter of a more technical nature. In terms of the economic aspects involved with these Bills-economic aspects which have social implications-various concerns have been expressed about the Bills by a wide variety of sources. The comments I have made to date have not referred at all to the views of the mining industry in Victoria, or in Australia. But the mining industry, through the Australian Mining Industry Council, does have very real and legitimate concerns to express about these Bills, particularly the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill. I will summarise two or three of those concerns. The industry, through the Australian Mining Industry Council, points out that the Victorian Government has given no public indication of the final extent of land to be granted to Aboriginals in Victoria under special tenure arrangements. The mining provisions in the original Victorian Bills for Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest were developed on the understanding that they would serve as a model for general Aboriginal land legislation in Victoria. The equivalent provisions in the Federal Bill will therefore stand as a precedent for further Bills both in Victoria and elsewhere. The Bill is not consistent with the Victorian Mines Act procedures and will therefore create an administrative nightmare.

As I said before, the Bill will discriminate between Aboriginals and other members of the community in both an advantageous and a disadvantageous way, depending on the various clauses or aspects of the Bill involved. It will therefore be very damaging to the promotion of racial harmony and mutual understanding of the needs of Aboriginal communities in Victoria. The Bill ignores the fundamental principles of Victoria's own economic strategy. It obscures the royalty arrangements that will apply to minerals mined in the two areas under the preserve of these Bills, and there are many other problems with the legislation as well. I am concerned about both these Bills, on behalf of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Victorians. They are bad and dangerous pieces of legislation which set extra- ordinarily bad precedents, not only in terms of Aboriginal land rights legislation but also across the whole board of legislative practices in this Parliament. The Bills should be withdrawn, and certainly should be strongly opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak primarily this morning on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986 and, time permitting, I shall make some comments about the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill. The legislation affecting the Northern Territory is another illustration of the tragic effects of national Australian Labor Party policy on Aboriginal affairs. It fails to rectify the injustices of the 1976 Aboriginal land rights legislation and it continues to express contempt for the legitimate authority of the elected Northern Territory Government. Not only does it tinker with the edges of major problems, but also it adds to those problems by increasing the powers and lessening the responsibilities of Aboriginal land councils.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986 is a timely reminder of why the Liberal Party opposes the imposition of national land rights legislation. The people of the Northern Territory have been made to serve as an experimental laboratory for a policy that has been proven unjust, however generous its original intention. The ALP Government lacks the courage and the capacity to correct some of the errors of the past. It cannot even claim that its actions uphold the rights of the minority, even though the Liberal Party would still dispute the principle that assistance to minorities should override the proper rights of majorities, or indeed the national interest.

The Bill does not further or protect the interests of the whole Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory. Legislating in favour of land councils should not be seen as the same as legislating in favour of Aboriginal Territorians. The Hawke ALP Government has rejected any amendment to the existing Act that would give the Northern Territory Government a so-called estate of interest in Aboriginal land that would enable entry to that land for public purposes.

Australian citizens in the Northern Territory, both black and white, are entitled, as they are anywhere else, to the provision of such government services as roads, water and electricity. As a Liberal, I believe it is not reasonable or just for land owners to be able to deny the provision of those services to the community. As a Liberal and a federalist, I believe it is unjust that legislation of this Parliament should constrain an elected Territory government from fulfilling the essential practical duties of a government at State level. National land rights legislation that imposed the same constraints on the six State governments would be outrageous. This is not a theoretic concern but a practical one. Roads cannot be made or upgraded because the hands of the Northern Territory Government are tied. That not only causes problems for specific communities but also harms the national interest when, for example, tourist traffic on the road from Ayres Rock to the Olgas is hampered by lack of road maintenance. That incidentally happens often.

Mr Justice Toohey's review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act recommended three years ago that, subject to the consent of the Federal Minister, the Northern Territory Government should be able to acquire land for public purposes. An earlier draft of the Bill reduced this to essential services. This Bill will do nothing whatsoever to enable the Territory Government to acquire any small amount of Aboriginal land for the most essential services.

The Hawke Government has totally caved in to its Left at the expense of the people of the Northern Territory. It is even more tragic that the Government could not care less. By way of amendment, the Opposition seeks to rectify the problem in a cautious manner. It proposes that a Northern Territory Government Minister may apply to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who, in turn, may be required to decide under what conditions and at what level compensation may be payable. That hardly represents a massive overturning of Aboriginal land ownership, but I am certain that for blind ideological reasons the ALP and Australian Democrat senators will not be supporting it. In so doing, they will be preventing the provision of power, water, sewerage, communication, health, education, roads, tourist facilities and police stations.

The spinelessness of the Government will condemn many Australians to be second class citizens. That is not the role or the responsibility of any government. The veto of exploration and mining on Aboriginal land has for years stifled further mineral development in the Northern Territory, and I hope we may be spared the kind of cheap rhetoric about rich and powerful mining companies that are called to answer on occasion for their sins of being multinationals or being associated with such figures as Mr Charles Copeman. It is time we spoke more about the importance of mining as an export industry, an industry keeping this nation afloat. It is an industry vulnerable to price falls abroad and cost hikes at home, and it also pays over 60 per cent of its pre-tax profit to government. Yet this Government has no regard whatsoever for the export and tax income potential of such a vital industry to Australia.

Australia has been losing out on export income and jobs because of the mining exploration veto, a privilege not enjoyed by all landholders in the Territory. That veto has allowed land councils to hold miners to ransom. The Liberal Party has been prepared to tackle this problem in a constructive manner to prevent the strangling of mining while recognising the need for Aborigines to protect their lifestyle. In December 1985, Senator Kilgariff introduced an amending Bill to the same legislation, but debate on that Bill has now been adjourned by the Government for nearly 12 months. The ALP is still allowing Aboriginal landholders to exercise privileges over permission to explore for mining, and the amendments now being proposed are far less effective than clauses 40 to 49 of Senator Kilgariff's Bill. The mechanisms that Bill provides to protect the lifestyles of Aboriginal communities are a far better solution than attempting to modify the veto power as the Government now proposes.

While the veto power would go, agreements with land councils covering compensation payments, restoration work, protection of sacred sites and employment opportunities for Aborigines would have to be negotiated subject to the arbitration of a warden's court. The Liberal Party supports Senator Kilgariff's Bill which would protect Aboriginal communities from disruption because it recognises that they might have special needs. The Liberal Party differs from the ALP Government in that its method would not hamper mineral development and exploration at a time when all Australians, both black and white, need the export earnings that only mining can produce.

Failure to address the question of the provision of services is only one of the defects of the Bill. When 33 per cent of the land area of the Northern Territory has been granted to Aborigines and a further 18 per cent is subject to claims and has effectively passed outside the control of the Northern Territory Government, one can see that the Bill will be totally inadequate in limiting further claims. The time limit of 10 years under clause 25 will not change the existing situation as actual hearings will proceed well beyond that point. Nothing will preclude the resubmission of unsuccessful claims. Unless the proposal of the Liberal Party for a cut-off period of 12 months is adopted, the only effective halt to the process will be the total disappearance of remaining crown land.

I remind the Senate that land under claim is, in practice, locked away once the claim is lodged as it cannot be alienated for any public purpose. About 50 per cent of the land area of the Northern Territory is beyond the control of its elected government; a fate that would befall western Western Australia under the land rights legislation. Clause 33 explicitly perpetuates that situation. A government that is truly concerned for Australia's pastoral industries would take firm steps to ensure that stock routes and stock reserves are removed from the ambit of land rights claims. Instead, clause 25 of this Bill does this only in part, enabling the Federal Minister to declare that certain stock reserves will be available for claim and to allow claims for stock routes when they cut through the centre of a claim. Of course, such a qualification negates the reform. It should be obvious to most of us that a stock route is not much good if parts of it can be claimed, just as our public roads would lose their usefulness if some people were able to build stone walls across them or to levy private tolls. We in the Liberal Party of Australia would argue for full protection of stock routes and reserves from any further land claims. The fact that pastoral leases can be subject to land claim by Aboriginal communities and organisations after they have been purchased on the open market is a feature of land rights legislation that has caused community grievance and division. It strikes most people as being a particularly underhanded feature of the whole process, creating as it does a class of privileged owners of pastoral leases with the potential of converting those leases to inalienable freehold. This would in fact maintain the possibility that as much as 70 per cent of the land area of the Northern Territory could pass under the control of land councils rather than an elected government. Once again, this legislation does nothing to remove pastoral leases from the ambit of land claims.

These are some notable sins of omission in a Bill distinguished by its failure to reform obvious injustice. Not content with that, with this Bill the Government will create new injustice by its privileged treatment of Aboriginal land councils. Under clause 13, land councils are now to be given the right to assist in the protection of sacred sites on land in their areas even if it is not Aboriginal land. Not content with giving land councils effective jurisdiction over half the Northern Territory, the Australian Labor Party now proposes to give them what could be a potentially limitless power of interference. I am not surprised that in the second reading speech of this Bill provided last December this matter was scarcely mentioned let alone justified. This ALP Government has already on the statute book a potentially draconian piece of legislation-the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act-which extends blanket authority for the protection of sacred sites. It gives to the Minister enormous reserve powers. The Northern Territory has its own sacred sites protection authority. I fear, however, that the prospect of the Northern Territory Government in reviewing these matters somehow displeasing militant Aboriginals has led the Hawke ALP Government to forestall them in this crude and rather irresponsible manner.

The protection of sacred sites is a vexed question. Some three years ago the Western Australian Museum had catalogued 750,000 sites of significance to Aboriginal people in Western Australian, my State, but it would be absurd to argue that every one of those sites is equally sacred. This Government persistently shuts its eyes to the fact that there is all the difference in the world between places which have deep religious significance to people and others of far less importance but which nonetheless can be used as bargaining counters to ensure advantage for community militants. In recent weeks, construction of the Roe Highway, on the outskirts of Perth, has been delayed because of disputes over Aboriginal sites. This Bill will vastly increase the powers of land councils in the Northern Territory to paralyse developments which are in the interests of the whole community but of which they may disapprove. It is bad enough that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been given enormous power to proclaim and preserve so-called significant Aboriginal areas, but at least he and his Government are accountable to Parliament. The same cannot be said for these land councils.

While Aboriginal land councils are to enjoy an unwarranted and dangerous increase in their powers outside their original function, clause 16 of the Bill reduces their responsibility towards Aboriginal people. This clause removes the obligation of land councils to maintain a register of traditional owners of Aboriginal land. If we are going to have land rights legislation-and we would accept that it cannot disappear overnight in the Northern Territory-then surely it is these comparatively small communities, these traditional owners whom we should protect. It is they who should be making decisions about their land, if we are to uphold the time-honoured principle of land ownership. But that time-honoured principle is simply going out the window. Mining companies need to know who the traditional owners are so that they may talk with them directly. I refer to the absurdity that we saw a couple of years ago in relation to action taken by the Western Australian Government. It now claims that it has not introduced land rights legislation and did not ever want to introduce lands rights legislation and yet it was the Premier who not once but twice introduced such legislation into the State Parliament. It proposed that the Aboriginal communities should go out with the mining companies when such companies were looking for possible mining areas. Honourable senators can imagine the absurdity of that: The moment the Aborigines went out with the mining companies and the mining companies showed any interest in an area of land the Aborigines felt a sacred site coming on.

The absurdity of this whole thing has reached a ridiculous level. It is a farce for the Government in clause 8 to give the land councils further rights to enter agreements over land under claim, as there are only vague assurances as to the rights of traditional owners, and there is no necessity for the councils to follow correct procedures. In a sense, the Hawke Government is well and truly pushing Aboriginal people into socialism. Traditional owners will lose property rights and, in effect, all decisions will be made by land councils which are more likely to reflect political activism than genuine grass-roots concerns. Again, we heard from Senator Short a little while ago that the Federal Minister has not even been to Framlingham Forest, for example, to assess the situation there. If the Minister bothered to go to some of these land rights areas in question and to go to talk with some of the Aboriginal communities he would find that many people in Aboriginal communities simply do not want land rights and see this as being absolutely patronising behaviour by governments trying to decide the fortunes of their lives.

It is not an exaggeration to say that land councils will become rival governments. The ALP seems to have forgotten that Aboriginal Territorians all vote in the Northern Territory elections and that they have the right to participate directly in the governing of their part of Australia. One would have thought that the essential purpose of the land councils would be to safeguard the rights of traditional owners-and yet this Bill absolves them of this basic responsibility. This step backwards into absolute collectivism for many of the 29,000 Aboriginal Australians in the Northern Territory will mean that land councils will provide the only communication between them and the rest of the Australian nation. I do not believe that that is a power that they should have. The point has been well made that, while these 29,000 Australians occupy 686,000 square kilometres of land, some 520,000 Indians and Eskimos in Canada have reserves that cover only 260,000 square kilometres. We should be even more concerned that this ALP Government is intent on giving effective jurisdiction over this land to what is comparatively only a handful of activists who may dominate land councils.

This Bill does nothing for ordinary Aboriginal Australians. As I have said before, one needs to go out and talk to the Aboriginal communities to find out exactly whether they want it-and the majority of them do not want it. The Bill will maintain a great deal of injustice, affecting all citizens of a vital part of Australia. It will continue to hamstring essential mineral development and it does not permit an elected government to fulfil its responsibilities. Unless the Senate is prepared to accept the constructive amendments to which the Opposition is committed, this legislation will be, at best, a wasted opportunity and, at worst, a step backwards for Aboriginal Australians. There is even further concern in relation to measures in the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987 in that Aboriginals will have greater compensation rights than other land holders. Is that favouring of one group fair and equitable to the community of Australia? All people, whether they are black or white, should have the same rights. But under this legislation the Aborigines will have greater compensation rights. Legislation based on the South Australian Pitjantjatjara model has been a total, absolute, and unequivocal failure. Yet this Government still has not learned. It is putting measures before the Parliament that are based on failures and the Aborigines will, of course, have more rights than any other Australians to control mining as well. It might be fair to suggest that Aboriginal communities in Victoria are hardly living in tribal conditions and do not need the kinds of safeguards for lifestyle disruption that could apply to those in other parts of Australia.

The Pitjantjatjara legislation in 1981 and the Maralinga legislation in 1983 have resulted in no new exploration of mining tenements, and that is a disgrace. The 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Bill has resulted in only one new exploration tenement and no mining. Neither the Federal Government nor the Victorian Government has said what land Aborigines may ultimately get in Victoria. We have seen more than 50 per cent of Western Australia up for grabs in recent times. The Premier of Western Australia understood only recently that 78 per cent of the Western Australian community did not see land rights as a just measure.

The Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill takes away the discretionary power of the Minister and vests it with an arbitrator. Under clause 33 of the Bill the Aborigines have the initial right of veto which an arbitrator can override and this is an obvious cause of political odium. It is far better to keep a procedure where all interested parties have the right to object to mining and the Government waives all interests in the balance and then makes the final decision. There will now be dual controls and a dual review system.

The Commonwealth is spending $1.3m on acquiring and transferring the land. That could have been achieved under State legislation at no cost. But once again, as we have seen in Western Australia, the State Government did not have the courage to carry on. It wanted to palm it off to the Federal Government and the Federal Government went a little bit weak in the knees.
