But it is certainly not weak in the knees when it comes to the legislation that is before us today. This legislation is at best a wasted opportunity and at worst a step backwards for Aboriginal Australians. Our amendments should be supported. If they are not supported the Bill should be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, it is a matter of regret to me that on the day of the twentieth anniversary of the referendum which extended the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth with respect to Aboriginal affairs the Senate should be debating this mishmash of legislation which sums up the betrayal of promises made to Aborigines by the Australian Labor Party during most of my active political life. In entering this debate I would like to register my disgust at the way in which the Labor Party bought the votes of Aborigines, not least in my State of Western Australia, and then refused to pay the purchase price that it offered. That is a strong statement about this Government and I make it in very good company.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to read Robert Haupt's comments yesterday when he expressed surprise at the history of this 20 years. He said that there would be so much that would have surprised anyone who was looking ahead at the time and who supported the Aboriginal cause. He said:

. . . above all, that the cycle of reform begun under a conservative government would have come to a halt, in exhaustion and boredom, under a cynical Labor Government-had you said that to my generation in 1967, it's not that we would not have disagreed with you: we would have been utterly unable to understand you.

I do not think Mr Haupt is writing as some sort of creature of the Liberal Party of Australia. I do not think that others who have criticised this Government for its sell-out of the promise that it made to Aborigines are creatures of the Liberal or National parties. I have quoted before in this place the comments of Father Frank Brennan, the Jesuit who advises the Catholic Bishops in Australia on the vexed issue of land rights. He wrote in April 1986 about the fact that the Commonwealth Government has at last come clean, that there will be no national land rights legislation and that the matter is to be left to the States. He said:

The broken promises are the greatest breach of faith committed by any government towards Aboriginal people since white settlement. Aboriginals no longer have a voice or an advocate in the major political parties at a national level in relation to the land rights question. They are an electoral liability. Their votes having been bought, they have been betrayed totally less than two years before we, as a nation, will dare to celebrate the events of January 26, 1788.

I think that when the history of the Hawke Labor Government is written the chapter on Aboriginal affairs will be the low point of its assessment. It will not be because there are not people in the Labor party who are deeply committed to the welfare of Aboriginal Australians, but it will be because the Government chose to buy its way into government by making promises which we as the then Government-the Liberal and National Parties-said were promises which should not be made and which could not be fulfilled. The Labor Party went ahead and made those promises which led the Aboriginal people into expecting and demanding things that would never happen. It produced a destruction of the positive community attitudes towards Aborigines which, I think, is the greatest tragedy of this 20 years.

As I have said before, this grab-bag of legislation is a classic illustration of this Government's record of achievement. We have two Bills which start a necessary process of amendment of the land rights legislation which was carried through this Parliament by the Fraser Government in 1976. That legislation was novel; it was an experiment; it was passed with substantial bipartisan support through this Parliament and it was acknowledged at the time that it was an experiment and that it would need assessment and probably amendment. But for the whole of the time that we were in government and from 1976 on, we had that living experience with the land rights legislation in the Northern Territory. Any attempts that the Liberal and National parties, then in coalition, made to remove some of the difficulties of the land rights legislation were obstructed by the Australian Labor Party, which continually urged the Aborigines not to move on any of these issues. As a result, the unsatisfactory operational elements of land rights legislation were not able to be touched or rectified and a great deal of resentment ensued.

The whole proposition, the whole concept, of land rights became a matter of very great political disagreement where once there had been agreement. The fact that the Labor Party was continually opposed to any change and continually promising that national land rights would be enacted by a Labor government was the prime cause both of the inability of the Liberal-National Party Government to remove some of the difficulties which emerged in the Northern Territory and of the growing distrust of the concept of land rights around Australia. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) explained his craven and pathetic attitude to keeping the promises of the Labor Party towards the Aboriginal people he hid behind the claim that Australians had become less compassionate towards Aboriginals in the past 20 years. I throw that back in his teeth because the lack of compassion and the loss of public support for the Aboriginal cause were, I believe, caused substantially by the Labor Party-by its totally irresponsible and totally cynical attitude in its period in opposition in particular. I do not believe that Australians are less compassionate.

I believe instead that Australians have become impatient with what they have seen as both excessive Aboriginal demands and unsuccessful government programs. I believe that the excessive Aboriginal demands which have given rise to a loss of public support can be laid fairly and squarely at the feet of those Labor Party apparatchiks who within the Aboriginal communities of Australia and who as political candidates around Australia went round egging on the Aboriginal people to make ever-increasing demands which were undercutting the public sympathy which Aboriginals had enjoyed in this country. I condemn the short term and totally political approach which is adopted to this day on Aboriginal affairs issues by this Government which has at its senior levels no real interest in this matter, unlike the previous Government, which leaves the administration of Aboriginal affairs to Mr Holding and which undercuts Mr Holding when he, as any Minister would, tries to implement the policies on which the Government was elected.

The most recent example of the Government's cynicism is its criticism of our policy which reasserts the role of the States, which reasserts the fact that the States have a significant role to play in dealing with Aboriginal matters, yet it totally ignores the fact that when the Department of Aboriginal Affairs was established in 1973 by the Whitlam Labor Government the then Minister, the Hon. Gordon Bryant, said:

The Australian Government does not seek the transfer from the States of particular responsibilities in the field of health, housing, education and other functional areas which in its view should preferably be carried out by the appropriate Australian or State Departments having responsibility in these areas partly on the basis of the continued provision of funds by the Australian Government.

That was the Labor Party's attitude in 1973 and it mirrors the attitude expressed by the Prime Minister in his letters to the Premiers dated 2 December 1986 in which he reaffirmed that the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council, which is the meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers with relevant responsibilities, should proceed with its review of Commonwealth-State financial arrangements for Aboriginal programs.

It is very hard to know where to start in dealing with these Bills because the first two Bills, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986, which relate to amendment to the Aboriginal land rights legislation which covers the Northern Territory, contain changes which we believe are a small step towards what is required but which are classically a case of too little and too late. The Opposition therefore does not oppose the idea of there being amendments to the land rights legislation, but it will be moving very substantial amendments to this legislation to try to deal with some of the problems which have been the subject of great discussion within the Government, within the Caucus, but on which the Government has decided not to bring forward amendments at this time. Substantial amendments will be moved by the Opposition, and they arise from its deep concern to see the Northern Territory legislation operating successfully and to see that that legislation operates to the satisfaction not merely of Aboriginal citizens of the Northern Territory but of the wider community of the Northern Territory. After all, it is essential that the administration of Aboriginal land, which could get to the point of being about 50 per cent of the Northern Territory, should be undertaken in a way which is harmonious to the needs of the whole of the Territory, not merely to the Aboriginal inhabitants.

With respect to the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill 1987 which desire to enact very limited land grants to Aboriginal communities in Victoria, I simply express my contempt for the tokenism and the constitutional nonsense that is involved. I hope that the Department did not advise the Government to undertake this legislative folly, but we have a situation where the Victorian Government, following decades of agitation on the part of Victorians for extensive land rights to be granted to Aboriginals in the rest of Australia, moved reluctantly to provide very small areas of land in Victoria. There was a dispute within the Victorian Parliament about the nature of the title which should be granted, not about whether title should be granted, and some of the ancillary rights which are to be related to the grant of title to a number of Aboriginal communities.

What did the Victorian Government do? It did not proceed to complete the consideration of the legislation in the Victorian Parliament but instead it made a request to the Commonwealth Parliament that it should enact the necessary legislation. That is presented as an exercise in morality by this pathetic Government which has sold out on the Aboriginal promises that it made so freely in opposition. I ask the Government: If it is so determined to ensure that the form of title granted in Victoria is in accordance with some ideal Labor party objective, why is it-I ask the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) who is at the table, and perhaps he will be able to give us an answer-that the Commonwealth Government is prepared to see a totally different form of title provided by the Queensland Government, deeds of grant in trust, which seems to me to bear very little relationship to what is being demanded concerning the title that is to be available in Victoria?

Why is it that when the Government of the ex-Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, enacted legislation dealing with land for Aboriginals, which I think granted some 7,000 hectares in the whole of that State-a few pocket handkerchief bits of land scattered around New South Wales-it made provision for the subsequent purchase of land by using certain funds that would be made available for Aboriginals but exactly the same conditions were not imposed in that case? Why is it that it is permissible to have a variety of title forms in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland until we get this legislation that is before us now which says that the Victorian Parliament is not to be allowed to determine the variety of the title in this case because we have some great principle at stake? It is so obviously a political sham. It is so obviously just one more step in the Labor Party's desperate attempt to produce some evidence that it has a genuine concern for Aboriginal Australians, yet its performance bears no relationship to the policy which it has generally advanced or the promises that it has made to Aboriginal people.

We have here today the first sign that this Government is prepared to legislate with respect to Aboriginal land, and we find that it is doing it with the acquiescence of and at the request of the Victorian Government, which seems to be prepared to sell out its constitutional responsibility-not, I think, an unusual thing for the State Government of Victoria: Why not hand-ball it to the Commonwealth; it might pick up some of the cost. I want to draw the Senate's attention to what the Australian Labor Party was saying in 1983 when Senator Susan Ryan was the shadow Minister responsible for Aborigines. She issued a summary of the Australian Labor Party's 1983 election commitments to Aboriginal affairs. She talked about Aboriginal land rights and said this:

Labor will enact legislation to provide land rights to Queensland Aboriginal reserves immediately. Negotiations with the States to enact land rights legislation in line with the above principles will proceed. Where any State refuses to enact appropriate land rights legislation, the Labor Government will use Commonwealth constitutional powers to achieve its objective.
They are bold words. This Government has been in office for four years, and here we have this Bill relating to a couple of small parcels of land in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what has Queensland done?

—What of Queensland? What has the Government done with respect to Queensland, let me ask instead? What has it done with respect to its brothers in Labor in my State of Western Australia, where 8.9 per cent of the State is reserved for Aboriginal purposes but where there are no Aboriginal land rights in the terms that Labor promised in 1982, 1983 and 1984? It has done nothing because the Prime Minister is frightened of the political unpopularity that he would engender.
—He governs by polls.

—The honourable senator is absolutely right. The sad reality is that for all the talk of principle that we have had in the Senate over the years from members of the Australian Labor Party, none of them are present in the chamber for this debate. And I do not blame them, because they ought to be out drinking strong whiskies and trying to forget the promises that they made over the years when they were in opposition. Let me go back--
—Would you like to be reminded of your family's activities?

—When the Labor Party Whip tries to traduce my brother, when a royal commission indicated what my brother's position was, all I can say is that this is a sign of the honourable senator's desperation. What did the shadow Minister, whom Senator Robertson supported in this place, say when she was representing Senator Robertson and his colleagues in opposition and making promises to Aboriginals? I quote from the Senate Hansard of 14 October 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the first acts of that Federal Labor government will be to pass my private member's Bill, which will be Labor legislation, to grant freehold title, not any other form of lease, over to the Aboriginal and Islander reserves in Queensland, which will then resolve the situation.

I could go on and on quoting the promises which were made inside and outside the Parliament about what this government would do. The simple point I am making is that it has refused to do anything in any circumstances which would cost it votes. Let me make my political position quite clear. I have always argued that national land rights legislation would not be the answer to this problem. The Liberal and National parties have set their face against national land rights legislation. We believe that the Government should not have made the promises which, if kept, would have caused enormous constitutional and community division in this country.

The burden of my complaint in my speech today is the highly unsatisfactory situation in Aboriginal affairs today. It is a situation in which community attitudes have retreated greatly from the very positive attitudes of the 1967 referendum days and, indeed, the period of the 1970s. The blame for that can be laid squarely at the feet of this Labor Party which raised Aboriginal expectations absurdly. It led Aboriginal people to put themselves in a position in which they made demands which cost them the support of the reasonable men and women of Australia. It will take the Labor Party a long time to expunge that action. I do not know how it will do it; I believe that it will take it a generation to undo the damage it has done. However, I urge it to acknowledge its contribution to the negatives in this field and to try to encourage Aboriginal Australians to accept the limitations on what a Federal government can offer and to accept that a good deal of the progress which is required will have to come from a willing partnership between government and Aboriginal individuals, with Aboriginal individuals carrying a very heavy burden of responsibility in achieving solutions to current Aboriginal problems.

The attitude which has been adopted by the Liberal Party-indeed, Liberal and National parties in this case, because I think our attitudes with respect to these Bills are very similar, if not exactly the same-is squarely in line with the approach to Aboriginal affairs which it laid out in its Aboriginal affairs policy issued recently by the shadow Minister, David Connolly, in which it set out its fundamental principles in its approach to these matters. One of the principles that we adopt-it is in common with the principle we followed in government-is that we accept that in many key areas, including land within the States, the key functioning government will be the State government, and that is vital, as it was vital in 1973 when the Labor Party established the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

We talk about the real need for equality of opportunity for Australian Aboriginal people; we talk about the issues of rights and responsibilities. Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders should be assisted and encouraged not only to enjoy the many benefits but also to accept the social and economic responsibilities of being full and equal members of the Australian community. This is essential to their gaining respect within the wider community and to improving their self-image. That is a very important message which is being put forward by the Liberal Party. As I have said, the central core of our message is also similar to that which would be put forward by the National Party. I urge the Government to reconsider its approach to these matters and to look to a considerably improved performance in the field of Aboriginal affairs.

I will go back briefly to the record of the Liberal and National parties. In the whole of the period when we were in government and when Labor and, indeed, the media were so deeply involved in the discussion on Aboriginal affairs, we were constantly criticised for not taking the steps which Labor in government had refused to take-namely, to enact national land rights legislation. That was a central core of dispute during those times. I think the very significant and clear difference between the records of the present Opposition-the Liberal and National parties-and the Government since the mid-1970s, is that where we made promises to Aboriginal Australians, as we did in our Aboriginal affairs policy in 1975, we kept those promises to the letter.

I commend to Labor members a study of the history of that time. In 1975 we promised that we would enact land rights legislation in the Northern Territory. We did it. That was an extraordinary step for a conservative-as some people labelled us-government, but we promised it and we did it. Anyone who was involved in politics at that time would know that the legislation was contentious then as it would be now, but we kept our promise. We promised that we would establish a capital fund for Aboriginal people. We did it. The land rights legislation was enacted in 1976. The Aboriginal Development Commission legislation, which included provision for a capital fund, was enacted during my period as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1979 or 1980-I forget which year. The important thing is that in the circumstances which applied during the period of the Fraser Government, it would be quite wrong to say that there were no political pressures upon the Government to step back from its promises. Senator Boswell-he may be involved in this debate-would know that within the coalition, and not just on the part of the National Party but also members of the Liberal Party, at times there was very great concern about whether we should have kept some of the promises that we made to the Aboriginal people; but the fact is that we did keep them.

There were mistakes. I think all of us would now agree that if we were re-enacting the 1976 legislation, we would have changed many of the provisions, particularly those relating to the mining sector which we do not think have been effective. When one looks at the provisions that relate to the unlimited right to claim that was given over pastoral lease land that became Aboriginal owned, and when one looks at the limitations on the rights of the Northern Territory Government to obtain land for public purposes, one sees there are many matters, a few of which are dealt with in the legislation before us today, which most of us would agree we would have dealt with differently. But again, I ask the Labor Party and the people of Australia to look at why those deficiencies were not remedied during our period in government, because the reality is that whatever change we sought to make was blocked by the Labor Party, and there was never any concession that, at times, some stepping back by Aboriginal claimants would be in the interests of Aboriginal people and also the broader community. I believe that it was a case of the Labor Party hanging out for every possible Aboriginal vote. It was one of the least seemly, least admirable things I have ever seen in my political life.

The last matter on which I wish to touch is the sort of response one gets from Labor on these issues-namely, that my Party in Western Australia and the mining industry have been part of creating the problem of the white backlash. That is a very frequently made comment. When I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1979 I had discussions with the mining industry over what it saw as the deficiencies of the land rights legislation. I told the industry that I agreed, that I thought there were emerging problems. The industry wanted to kick up a fuss about them but I said: `Please don't. Race relations in this country are very difficult. I think you should give me a chance to work these things out quietly. I accept that there is a problem, and we should try to fix it'. The mining industry, to its credit, showed the restraint I asked for. I appointed a Queen's Counsel from Western Australia to examine the Act and to look at these difficulties. That process was not concluded when I ceased to be Minister but my successor, Senator Peter Baume, undertook a continuation of the process which had begun during my period as the Minister of trying to work through changes to the land rights legislation. We got nowhere-not because Senator Baume and his successor, Mr Wilson, did not try hard, but because of the obstruction I have talked about before, with the Labor Party egging on the land councils to obstruct us at every point in the process.

When the mining industry in the mid-1980s took a much more public stance on this issue it quite correctly said to me: `We did exactly as you asked. We tried to deal with this thing without informing the public of what the problems were and it got us nowhere'. Again, I believe that to the extent that this issue was able to be made so divisive, it was. I regret that it was; it gave me no pleasure and no satisfaction. I again say to the Labor Party that, given the unreasonableness that has applied for so long in this field, virtually from the time the Labor Party left the bipartisanship we had enjoyed through to 1976 inevitably the matter became very contentious. I commend to the Government an approach to Aboriginal affairs which accepts that in a sense one has to accommodate the interests of the whole community and not adopt the sort of attitude which in the 1970s was so instrumental in producing public division and which made so many Labor members of parliament feel very good inside but which produced nothing at all for their Aboriginal constituency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a privilege for me to speak in the debate on an issue such as this. It is a matter of profound regret that we have reached the stage of being presented in this Parliament with what is much more in the nature of an ideological commitment and response in political terms than a genuine endeavour to come to grips with the very real problems that face the Aboriginal communities in Australia. I would like to go back to the 1970s because I well recall reading the Woodward Aboriginal land rights commission report and the very many suggestions which were around at the time and which ultimately led to the introduction in 1976 of the Northern Territory land rights legislation. There was a very widespread feeling of compassion and support for a community which I think even today can be regarded as genuinely disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who was familiar with the statistics of Professor Fred Hollows, which demonstrated the extent to which both adults and children in the Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, in particular, suffered from trachoma and had a much shortened life expectancy and literacy rates so low they could certainly be compared to many Third World countries, or anyone who was aware of the suffering of very many Aboriginals who did not have a roof over their heads and who were genuinely in very great need of government assistance, was very supportive of the efforts made by government during the 1970s.

The introduction of the Northern Territory land rights legislation was a landmark. It was explained at the time as being, and it subsequently remained, an endeavour to find a formula that would go some way towards coming to grips with those very real social problems. It was not, I believe-I hope it was not-an attempt somehow to redress historical wrongs because that is a fundamentally incorrect approach to take. If that were the prescriptive formula adopted in determining how one comes to grips with racial problems, one would clearly have to apply it around the world. One simply could not contemplate the negroes in America somehow being entitled to vast amounts of compensation or indeed the Indian communities of northern and southern America. It is simply not a helpful approach. It is divisive. It ignores the real problems. The problems that confront Aboriginal communities are social problems. They result from economic deprivation, and need to be tackled in a humanitarian and sympathetic manner.

When the land rights legislation was introduced it very quickly became a political football. The expectations of the Aboriginal community were raised unrealistically because although that community constitutes only some one per cent of the total Australian population, the way in which the media presented the debate-a manner not restricted to the Aboriginal community-led a great majority of Australians to believe that somehow there was a fundamental polarisation in the community, that two groups were at loggerheads, engaging in some sort of political warfare which would inevitably put Australians on either side of a very serious question. The Labor Party did a great disservice to this country by fuelling those expectations, by talking in terms of national land rights legislation as an ideological prescription rather than looking at the way the model legislation in the Northern Territory operated.

We now know from bitter experience that the legislation did not operate in the way it was meant to. It was meant to establish land councils that were to have access to funds which they would then spend for the benefit of local communities. What happened was that a degree of intransigence set in. Although the legislation provided for negotiations with mining companies and others, inevitably there were those on the outside who urged that strong political stances be taken, that ambit claims be made and that no compromise be achieved. I find it a matter of great regret that the interests of the Aboriginal community became very quickly submerged in a wider political battle. Land rights became some sort of symbolic commitment to whether or not one was in favour of assisting the Aboriginal community, whereas the reality is that the vast majority of Australians acknowledge that Aboriginal people are in a position of need and in broad terms suffer from a great many social and economic deprivations that do not afflict them.

During the 1970s, when I was the President of the United Nations Association of Australia, I was privileged to visit a number of Aboriginal communities in South Australia and the Northern Territory. I travelled to Docker River in the Northern Territory with the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, the then Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Viner, and a then Labor back bencher, John Dawkins.

TALK.START.PARA: —And me.

—Indeed. I well recall that visit and pay tribute to Senator Robertson's role in that venture. We were invited to explore the sacred sites that were the province of the Docker River community with a view to examining whether the Western Australian Government might be prevailed upon to grant analagous land rights. At that time the title deeds for the Petermann Ranges Reserve were handed over to the community. There was a great deal of goodwill and benevolence towards the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways we were then overtaken by the high level of political polarisation that developed, perhaps fuelled by activists or by party functionaries, but in any event we ignored what was fundamentally the aim of the legislation-to achieve a balance between interests, to allow mining to go ahead on responsible terms and to provide members of the Aboriginal community with a kitty which they could then use for their own development purposes. What was so important about that was that it gave them a degree of control over their own lives and a much greater measure of self-reliance. It also put into practice the principle of self-determination. If that polarisation had simply been allowed to continue through, this obsession would have continued to develop towards claiming more and more land and obtaining more and more funds without concern for how that money was spent or for those in particular need of assistance. The political battle simply was to gain more and more.

As we know, in the Northern Territory where the Aboriginal community numbers about 40,000 out of a population of 160,000-about 25 per cent of the population-because the legislation provided for claims to unalienated Crown land, the spectre was raised that perhaps half the total land area of the Northern Territory might be handed over to a community which was only a minor proportion of the total community. That generated very real fears amongst the rest of the community there. It was not as if the community was suddenly presented with a fait accompli and had to learn to cope with it. What happened was that there was this creeping spectre. Claims were made, claims were granted and more claims were made. It even got to the stage where by a device subsequently overturned in the High Court of Australia the Government of the Northern Territory felt it necessary to proclaim the outer limits of the town of Darwin to deter land claims over the very centre of that place. That was an unfortunate evolution of what was almost inevitable.

The great tragedy is that even the Hawke Labor Government finally came to realise that these forms of unyielding ideological prescriptions simply do not work; that local factors operate and ultimately the best decisions are made by those on the ground. I can understand concern about the way the Queensland Government traditionally has approached the question of Aboriginal land rights and its treatment of the Aboriginal community. There is a measure of validity in the proposition that it has not been as enthusiastic about real self-determination as have other States. But what is critically important in this debate is that the present Labor Government acknowledged that despite the differential treatment and attitudes around Australia, Queensland should be allowed to have a system of deeds of grants in trust which are very different from inalienable Crown land and from some of the other forms of land holdings that apply to Aboriginal communities in other States. In other words, the Government has accepted the principle that we espouse; that is, that it is not appropriate to have a national model. It is appropriate to leave such matters up to each State. To that extent we will find differences of attitudes and priorities but that is what has to be dealt with at the local level. I have confidence that if that system is allowed to apply, in all States the balance will be struck and there will be a degree of harmony and lack of polarisation that is so critical.

What we do not want are divisions and these passionate political debates on racial questions. We all know how easy it is to inflame matters in that area. The last thing that one wants to do is set up a blueprint which then provokes at least a violent rhetorical counter-reaction. The Government grudgingly has come to realise that. It came to power talking about overriding the States and using its constitutional powers. It had those powers prior to the Franklin Dam case. The Government sensibly came to realise that that decision provided no solution and that all it was doing was playing into the hands of a few activists and was not able to see the wood for the trees.

Unfortunately we now have a situation in Victoria where the State Labor Government has embarked upon a program to consolidate several forms of land holding which for very many years have been under the control of Aboriginal communities. It put forward legislation to transfer title deeds to those communities but because of the form in which it wanted to make that transfer the legislation was opposed by the Opposition. The Opposition in the Upper House made it clear that it would oppose amendments. As a result, the Government backed off. I think it was Mr Kennan, as the responsible Minister, who then thought it would be a very clever trick to prevail upon his Federal colleagues. As a result we are now faced with an attempt via the back door to overturn the very sort of principle that operates de facto in the Federal Labor Government at the present time. It is clear that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others, I think persuaded in large measure by the Premier of Western Australia, have taken the view elsewhere that this is a matter for local determination.

What is at stake in Victoria is approximately 11 square kilometres of State forest immediately adjacent to an area at Framlingham Forest which had been granted to the Kirrae Whurrong people in 1970 and an area in the Lake Condah region involving one-half of a square kilometre of land on which the historic Lake Condah mission station is situated. The proposal was that that should be handed to the Kerrup-Jmara people. No one doubts that these areas are of considerable social, architectural and historical significance to the local Aboriginal communities. That was recognised as long ago as 1970. Even in the second reading speech of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) on this legislation there was a grudging concession that the Bolte Government saw fit to grant what amounted to inalienable freehold to the Lake Tyers and Framlingham communities in the 1970s. At that time the Victorian Parliament enacted an Aboriginal lands Act which transferred title to these two communities living on the remnants of Aboriginal reserves.

There have always been definable Aboriginal communities in Victoria. Previous Liberal governments in that State have been very careful to ensure that protection is granted to those communities. I visited Lake Tyers. I am sure that my colleague Senator Lewis, who hails from the environs of Framlingham Forest, would be aware of the way those communities have operated harmoniously, have not experienced difficulties that have brought them into confrontation with the rest of the local community and generally have played a very constructive role in determining their own lives.

What the State Government is now proposing to do in Victoria is transfer inalienable land title to those communities. The Opposition has said that it is wrong in principle to tie up land for ever and a day. To the extent that the Aboriginal communities regard that land as sacred and historic and not to be transferred, the future is in their own hands. That is precisely what the Opposition parties proposed in Victoria; that those title deeds should be for alienable Crown land but that the communities should determine what should be done with the land. In many ways one would have thought that that is the ultimately responsible approach to self- determination, self-reliance and genuine independence-to give those communities control over their own lives and their land.

I do not know the precise quantity of that 11 square kilometres of State forest that could be regarded as being of vital social, cultural, historic and architectural significance to the Aboriginal communities. It may well be-and probably is-that this does not encompass every square inch, to mix the metaphor, of the 11 square kilometres. To that extent it may well be appropriate in future years for the communities either to make that land available for mining or other purposes or simply to sell it off if it is not required and perhaps to put the funds in trust for the benefit of the local communities. But the discretion could be vested in them, with the power to determine their own future.

No one suggests that a group of trustees or elders of an Aboriginal community will suddenly be seduced into selling off land that has such an emotional and historic significance to them. It has not happened to date. There has been no suggestion from any Aboriginal community that it should happen and I could not contemplate it happening. But ultimately it is that community that should make its own decisions. There may well come a time when parts of those areas no longer have the same degree of significance. It may well be that, with the passage of time, as the members of those communities move away from the area, only a very small number will be left who do not regard the area with the same degree of reverence that the people living there today no doubt do. That tells us the sensible approach to land rights in this country is to have the decisions made at local level. That means, in a Federal system, that the State governments should be the ones responsible. That is why we oppose the whole back door approach of the Government to this current legislation.

But, more importantly, we do not want to see a situation where people are simply locked into a national formula. We regard that as unhelpful and we regard it as an ideological commitment which ignores the realities and which has a potential for polarisation and division in the community, which is the last thing that we should be aiming for. It is quite clear that different regimes apply in different States but it is also clear that, by adopting the stance that we are, we are acting in the best interests of the Aboriginal communities. It is a canard of the highest order for it to be suggested in this debate, or elsewhere, that the Liberal Party of Australia in particular is lacking in compassion or is not proceeding with the best interests of the local communities at heart. It is unarguable that in Victoria the Bolte Government took the steps it did in relation to those local communities and granted those title deeds to those two Aboriginal communities at Framlingham and Lake Tyers. It is incontestable that the Liberal-National parties in government at Federal level introduced that model Bill in the Northern Territory.

Our commitment is clear. Our concern remains that members of the Aboriginal community should not be the victims of a political football game and should not find themselves being vilified as activists when the vast majority of them simply want to improve their standards of living, their way of life, their life survival rates, their degree of literacy and their general state of health. Their concern is not to claim as much as possible for as long as possible to the extent that it can be demonstrated as a political gain to the disadvantage of the rest of the Australian community. That is a recipe for disaster.

We fondly and perhaps naively believe that the Government will come to realise that the approach that it has taken in every other State is appropriate to Victoria. No doubt the Government has been misled into thinking that there is some political capital in Victoria; that somehow this can be used as a weapon to play politics in that State with not much downside risk at the Commonwealth level. I want to assure the Government that this sort of action is utterly counterproductive because it puts people in a position where they are forced to identify this type of legislation for what it is-a political instrument; something that will not assist in the resolution of the very real problems that beset the Aboriginal communities in Australia and, I think, in Victoria; and it certainly will not come to grips with the very real social difficulties that Australia experiences.

The problems in this country will be solved only by a degree of general realisation that we are all in it together, that there are sacrifices that need to be made. As of yesterday the Government backed down in relation to its industrial relations legislation, if we can take its explanation at face value. If it wants to consult more widely it should ensure that it will not simply railroad through some contentious legislation which will gravely offend a significant section of the community. If that approach is good enough in the industrial relations area where the Government has what it regards as a very significant clientele of unionists who are pushing for it, why is it not appropriate where we are dealing with 99 per cent of the community who are not of Aboriginal extraction and who have a very real concern that initiatives of the sort that the Australian Labor Party has been arguing for go too far and do not tackle the very real problems?

I am concerned to see a return to the days where the priority concern of those who had dealings with the Aboriginal community and the communities around Australia was that we should tackle the social problems that beset them. My travels around Aboriginal communities have convinced me that the great majority of persons in the Aboriginal communities are quite similar to the great majority of other Australians-that is, they are not political activists; they are not wanting to fight party political battles; and they are not wanting to go on a crusade to claim as much and more land as possible so that they can somehow claim that as a political victory. They want significant and real improvements in their standards of living and their quality of life. The tragedy is that a great amount of money has been misspent and misused by excessive bureaucracy playing politics when the people most in need have been deprived of those funds.

I support land rights legislation. I think it is necessary that there be a degree of security given to Aboriginal communities. I welcome some of the local initiatives that have been taken. For instance, I recall visiting Oenpelli some years ago and finding that the local community there had decided to pool its welfare moneys. Members of that community had voluntarily decided that they did not want to have access to alcohol within a radius of several hundred miles. They had transferred the retail liquor outlet points so far away that it became unattractive for them to drive there and very dangerous for them to try to drive back, and they were taking steps in their own interests to try to improve the way in which they lived their lives. I think the outstation movement was an outgrowth of that. It was not an attempt somehow to escape from the real world; it was an attempt to maintain contact with their roots but, at the same time, to remain a part of the wider society. Those are the sorts of self-help initiatives that I think can be very valuable.

There is no doubt that any Australian government should have a continuing commitment to improving the welfare of Aboriginals as a group. I do not accept the proposition that we should simply say that they are like everyone else. Whilst we might be able to point to a few members of the Aboriginal community who somehow do not have health and wealth problems, from my experience the vast majority of them can be regarded as disadvantaged. But that does not mean that they should then be given such a capacity and power over land that it has that divisive confrontation about it that we saw through the 1970s and 1980s in relation to the Northern Territory legislation. We do not want a situation where Aboriginals are forced either to exercise a right of veto over exploration which will bring them in direct confrontation with mining companies, or simply to cave in and be the victims of criticism on their own side. That is the sort of polarisation that this country does not want. I think the type of legislation that we are debating today simply goes down that tired and failed track of imposing a prescriptive solution that has not worked and that is really opposed to the best interests of the local communities who, by and large, have prospered under the current legislation. They do not need to have some political prescription imposed upon them. They do not need to have a Commonwealth government overriding a State government.

If we have four Labor governments in the States of Australia that all profess to have a commitment to federalism-we no longer hear calls for the regional forms of government that Mr Whitlam was so keen on in the 1970s-we can assume that the Labor governments around Australia believe in federalism and believe in what they used to think was sheer rhetoric, that we can make the best decisions at local level. If that is so, surely the Victorian Government and the Victorian people are the ones best placed to make decisions about the form of land transfer. After all, if we believe in democracy and the view that the Opposition espouses in that State, that the alienable transfers of title are the way to go, and if that view is not acceptable to the Victorian community, presumably that will be reflected at election time. My strong suspicion is that it simply would not be an election issue and that there is a very great opportunity for compromise which the Victorian Government is not wanting to take because it prefers to try to derive cheap political capital by turning this into some sort of one-off exception to the otherwise acknowledged principle on all sides of politics that State governments should be the ones dealing with this type of legislation.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I think we have come a long way in the past 10 or 15 years. I think the vast majority of Australians recognise that there is a lot that can be done to help our Aboriginal communities; there is a lot that they can do to help themselves. They will not be helped by ideological approaches; they will be helped by genuine local endeavours. One of the ways in which that can happen is leaving it to local communities and State governments to respond to local needs and demands. This legislation does nothing in that regard. It simply does not reflect the lessons from the Northern Territory legislation. It does retain all those powers of veto and the potential for division that became so apparent during the 1970s, with the result that mining exploration over a very fertile part of Australia fell away to almost zero. That is not the way to go and I am sure that there are many in the Aboriginal communities who regret that it ever got to the confrontationist level that it did. We do not want to have a situation where this legislation is simply an encouragement to make further claims for inalienable land transfers; what we want is to respond to the genuine needs of those local communities.

I believe this legislation does not have their best interests at heart. It is somehow a pandering to those who still believe that we are back in the early 1970s and who do not acknowledge that the world has changed and that Australia has very real and competing demands on it that must be reconciled, not by confrontation but by discussion, and that unless we are able to develop all of our resources we will simply continue to slide down the international league tables. I hope the Government will rethink. We will put forward a number of amendments that seek to tackle the legislation in line with the approach I believe we should be taking around Australia. I hope ultimately there will be a recognition that this legislation is the last way of achieving social cohesion among the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are today cognately debating four Bills. The first two were covered very satisfactorily by a senator for the Northern Territory, Senator Kilgariff. I shall address my remarks to the last two Bills. The legislation that is before us today is legislation that was unable to obtain passage through the Victorian Parliament. It is an affront to this Parliament to be treated as a branch office of the Victorian Parliament. The Victorian Parliament is made up of democratically elected representatives who are elected by the people of Victoria and they, for their own reasons, were not able to come to some decision on the passing of title of the two parcels of land covered by the two Bills. Therefore, the Premier of Victoria, Mr Cain, has asked the Federal Parliament to take over the legislation. I believe the Victorian voters have had their rights absolutely flouted by putting the legislation through this Parliament. I do not believe the Bills that are now before the Senate address the main problems that are facing the indigenous people of Australia. The Liberal and National parties will be moving amendment that in our view will bring the Bills into a form of legislation that will assist the indigenous people of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to stand in this Parliament as a senator for Queensland, a State that has done absolutely magnificent things for the Aboriginal people. As a senator, I find myself involved in the Torres Strait and to a lesser extent with Aboriginal communities as I move around Queensland as part of my duties. I am proud of what the Queensland Government has been able to achieve for the black people of Queensland. Not only has the Queensland Government made a valuable contribution by providing indigenous people with deeds of grants in trust but also a number of members of the Aboriginal and Islander communities have been asked by the National Party of Australia to represent the people of Queensland in Parliament. As a matter of fact, the first-and probably the only-full-blood Aborigine ever to be a representative in a parliament of Australia was Eric Deeral, who was the honourable member for Cook. At the last State election we offered candidacy to a young Islander, Getano Lui. The National Party believes in equal opportunity, no matter whether it involves sex discrimination and employment legislation or Aborigines being parliamentary representatives. The Queensland Minister for Community Services, the Hon. Bob Katter, has done a wonderful job and only this year a number of Aboriginal communities were handed their deeds of grant-Jarrobah, Cherbourg, Woorabinda and Palm Island. Fourteen of the inhabited islands in the Torres Strait have now received their deeds of grant and are operating in much the same way as a local municipal council would operate. The land is theirs in every way. The deed of grant passes the land across to the Aborigines and the Islanders and they hold exactly the same title as anyone else would receive, with the exception that the land can be sold or distributed only to community dwellers. In no way can a person who does not belong to a community go in and gain title to the land covered by the deed of grant in trust. So the Islanders and Aborigines are protected by the fact that that land will always be theirs and will always be in their communities.

What the Queensland Government, supported very strongly by the National Party, is trying to do and is achieving is gradually passing over control of these communities to the communities, so that the people will control their own destinies and their own local government. They, in turn, will be able to issue parcels of land for grazing, farming or small business. As time progresses, the Queensland Government will be withdrawing the white government officers so the whole communities will be run for the black people by the black people. This is what we call self-development and we support it. It is working very successfully now. The first deeds of grant in trust were handed over, I believe, last October or November to the island communities in Torres Strait and already a number of those communities are developing their own industries.

On Coconut Island they are developing a tourist industry that will allow visitors to live according to the traditional ways of the Islanders. Tourist accommodation is now being built on Coconut Island. It will not be flash but it will be reasonable and people will be able to visit the island and holiday or spend some time living in the traditional way of the Islanders. The Islanders will be able to provide them fishing and diving and many other types of pursuits.

On other islands people are engaged in trochus fishing. There is also a crayfishing industry up there. A very successful crayfishing operation is being controlled on Badu Island by the Badu community. I believe that that operation is bringing into the island something like $6m a year and it is providing jobs for many Islanders. So in only a short period of time-since October or November-we have seen the Islanders start to advance and develop their own industries. The Queensland Government and the National Party of Australia believe that we should be helping the Aboriginals and the Islanders to perform, gradually to control their own interests and gradually to take over the businesses that operate on the islands and in the communities. Only two or three weeks ago I visited the Hope Vale community, which has been given a deed of grant in trust for 11,000 hectares. Already people of that community have been given by their council 400 and 500-acre farms. They are prepared now. They have fenced them off; they have planted grasses for cattle feed; some of them have developed hardware stores; others have developed cattle properties. So the people in Hope Vale are moving towards self-determination.

But there are problems in these areas. These people are very keen to get on with developing their own future and that of their children. They are finding troubles. When I was in Hope Vale I visited a number of the community farms. Whilst the Queensland Government has given these people title of the land to be used for their own purposes, they are finding that they do not have sufficient tools, equipment or skills-such as marketing skills-to develop these blocks of land. There are 850 people in the Hope Vale community and I believe there are three tractors there. One is used exclusively to pull the garbage trailer; another is used for community services; and the third tractor has to be shared by 50 or 60 people who want to develop their own blocks. This is most unsatisfactory.

I say this to the Federal Government. The needs of the people are simple. They want tools, equipment, and a healthy way of life. They want a future and an education for their children. They want to control their own destinies. But these people who have had the initiative to clear their 400 or 500 acres with the sweat of their brow and an axe do not have the equipment to develop their own small farms. These people are feeling frustrated and they need help. This Government should give that type of help rather than pouring $1.3m into legislation that will not provide satisfactory land rights for the Aboriginals in the State of Victoria.

My concern for these Aboriginal and Islander people is that I feel that a lot of the funds are bypassing the mark. Funds that these people need to develop their own communities are not coming to them. A great amount of money is spent by the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and yet when we go out into the communities we find that this money is not getting through to the people who need assistance.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION: POSTPONEMENT OF DEBATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Leader of the Government in the Senate said he would give no undertaking that the Government's industrial relations legislation would be withdrawn. I ask: Is it not a fact that sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act have been successfully used to bring to an end at least 80 serious industrial disputes, including such well-known examples of union blackmail as the Mudginberri abattoir and plumbers and gasfitters disputes? Will the Government give the Senate and the Australian people a guarantee that it will abandon the proposal in the industrial relations legislation to restrict and delay access to sections 45d and 45e-action which could bankrupt many employers-and will it agree to leave these sections within the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I said that, following criticisms of the legislation by employer and union groups, the Government would embark on a process of further consultation.
—There wasn't any consultation.

—Presumably Senator Walters was under the bed when the consultations did take place. There is no point in her helping here. I said yesterday that the Government would embark on a further process of consultation with employer and union groups about the provisions of the legislation. Senator Chaney implied that the key phrase in this question is that the legislation would restrict and delay access to sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. That is an assertion which is not supported by any facts in the legislation. I know Senator Chaney is a new shadow Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs, but he may know that under the existing provisions of the Trade Practices Act-and he referred to 80 disputes having been resolved under those provisions-access to sections 45d and 45e has not been taken in a pre-emptory way by employers or manufacturers. It is not a matter in regard to which access will be delayed, denied or, in Senator Chaney's terms, restricted by the provisions of the proposed legislation.
—So why take it from the Federal Court?

—Senator Alston has not been here long so I shall tell him that it has been the view put by this Government for a long time that industrial relations matters are best dealt with initially in the one set of tribunals. The Government attaches tremendous importance to the conciliation function. Honourable senators on the Opposition benches can moan and groan and carry on, as they are now doing, but they are probably doing that because of a fact unpalatable to them-the fact that the instance of industrial disputes in this country has declined by more than half under this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to engage in debate with members of the Opposition, but I do not see any point in them shouting me down in their enthusiasm to ignore the fact that that is the level of industrial disputation the Government has attained by adhering to the process of consultation in respect of these issues. I come back to Senator Chaney's question. The issue of whether delay and restricted access might or might not occur as a result of the provisions of the legislation is a matter about which the Government is quite prepared to consult with employer organisations and others, and it will do so. The process of consultation will not be assisted by any noise from the Opposition in the Senate.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether his attention has been drawn to an article appearing on the front page of Monday's Australian Financial Review, headlined `Labor's $1 billion capital gains tax windfall'. Are the figures regarding the Government's capital gains tax cited in that article accurate? Does the Financial Review's interpretation of those figures accord with the Government's interpretation in terms of the stance of taxation policy in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article and it leaves the impression, or assumes, that capital gains tax revenue accruing to the Government as a result of the passage of the capital gains tax legislation would come in the 1986-87 financial year whereas, of course, it would come in in the 1987-88 financial year. That is one background point that needs to be straightened out. I do not know where the figures in the article written by Mr Hywood were obtained because there can be no certainty of figures until such time as at least a substantial number of the income tax returns for 1986-87 are submitted. The article estimated that $1 billion would be collected from the capital gains tax provisions per se in section 160, but that because the Income Tax Assessment Act now has an explicit capital gains taxation clause, much more revenue would be collected under section 25, which is the traders section, and section 26aaa, which is the section that imposes, and has done for the last 13 years, tax at the marginal income tax rate on profits made by the purchase and sale of assets within a 12-month period. Mr Hywood's figures assumed that $900m would be collected under those two sections, whereas I understand that the normal collection under those sections is of the order of $500m. It would have been somewhat more accurate, even on whatever assumptions lay behind that figuring, if the article had said that there would be a $500m increase in tax collections rather than $1 billion, which was the total figure.

ANSWER.PARA: Leaving that aside, however, the really important point on which the Treasurer has recently commented publicly is that there will be-I do not think the Treasurer has any definitive data on which to base his estimate, either-a capital gains tax section 160 collection vastly in excess of the $5m that was assumed at the time of the White Paper of May 1985 and in the 1986 Budget estimates. To that section 160 revenue collection, whatever it may be, should of course be added the increased collections under sections 25 and 26aaa. Whether Mr Hywood's figures are finally confirmed by the actual receipts or by more reliable estimates when a significant number of taxation returns have been received after the end of June, remains to be seen. The article does, however, draw attention to a very important point, and that is that it is absolutely essential to have an explicit capital gains tax clause in the Income Tax Assessment Act in order to put a safety net under the income tax base. That is evidenced by the fact that there is expected to be much larger collections under the pre-existing sections 25 and 26aaa.

Ever since the late 1970s, if not earlier, the Labor Party has been saying that it is absolutely essential to have a catch-all capital gains tax clause in the taxation act or the tax base will be continually eroded and much more revenue will be lost than is collected by the explicit clause. In other words, it emphasises that the policy proposed by the Opposition on this issue, as on almost every other issue that one can think of, is absolutely irresponsible and, if ever enacted, it would see the income tax base fretted away, in the way that it was the last time that Mr Howard was Treasurer of this country, although it occurred by a different mechanism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question, which also concerns the Government's industrial relations legislation, to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it not a fact that the union blockade of the Dollar Sweets factory in Melbourne was ended only by recourse to common law action? Will the Government give a guarantee that when it reconsiders the legislation it will delete clauses 216 and 217, which deny employers access to common law remedies against abuse of union power?
—Something you know nothing about.
—I know more about it than Senator Cook.

—Senator Knowles might know more about it than Senator Cook, and she might think that she knows more about it than I do, but that is not the point. As I have already said in answer to a question asked by Senator Chaney, the point is that the Government will be looking at renegotiating or consulting with industry groupings and unions about the provisions of the legislation. I would not anticipate that in those consultations the matter of recourse to common law would be argued by the major employer bodies as being of fundamental importance. It might be argued by people on the extreme right as being of fundamental importance--
—Try the CAI, for example.

—I am saying what I an- ticipate is likely to happen in the course of negotiations-but that is only what I anticipate. The fact remains, as I have already said, that we will undertake further consultations about these matters and when those consultations are complete the Government will announce the results of them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance, representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What recent indicators are available to access the performance of the Government's wages policy, and what do those indicators show?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two recent official publications have some relevance to this question. The first is the Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin on average weekly earnings for the February quarter. That showed that over the three months to February average weekly earnings for all employees had increased by 0.3 per cent, that full time adult average weekly ordinary-time earnings had increased by 6 per cent and that for the year ended February average weekly earnings had increased by 4.9 per cent and average weekly ordinary-time earnings had increased by some 6.3 per cent. Those movements in the major wage aggregates, as reported there, are modest. I would venture to suggest that they are more modest than anticipated when the Budget forecasts were drawn up. The results certainly reflect a more satisfactory outcome than may have been expected from the two previous quarterly figures which the statistician had produced towards the end of last year. The only statistically significant movement since the November 1986 survey concerned an increase of 0.8 per cent in ordinary-time earnings for full time adult female wage earners.

ANSWER.PARA: Those wage outcomes have been broadly confirmed-probably very substantially confirmed-by the national accounts figures, which have been published since then and about which the Treasurer has issued a Press release today. The Treasurer's Press release, based on a different measurement, that is, the quarterly accounts, as distinct from the ABS quarterly survey figures of wages paid, confirms that the wages outcome over the last year, and over the last quarter in particular, has been satisfactory and at least within the estimates made when the 1986 Budget was prepared.

My final point is that such wage outcomes do, of course, testify to the continuing success of the accord, and they stand in stark contrast to the wages explosions of 1981 and 1982, when wages increased by 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively, following the last government flirtation with a decentralised wage fixing system based on collective bargaining. However, given the weight of empirical evidence, Australia's recent experience, and that which has occurred in the United Kingdom, I find it quite astounding that there are people in this Parliament who are so bereft of the capacity which even the higher anthropoids are supposed to possess for trial and error learning that they want to return to the system which produced the disastrous outcomes of 1981 and 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate follows his answers to questions asked by me and Senator Knowles earlier in Question time in which he indicated that the Government would consult with industry and unions in respect of its industrial relations legislation, and in particular in respect of the impact that that legislation will have on sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act and on common law remedies at present available to employers for use against abuses of trade union power. I ask the Minister: Will he, on behalf of the Government, give a firm guarantee that the Government will carry out its consultation on the legislation? Further, will the Minister indicate the Government's intention in respect of the legislation and, in particular, its intentions with respect to both those sections which place the trade unions above the law and outside the ordinary courts and which restrict access to sections 45d and 45e and to common law remedies before the next federal election so that the people of Australia will be able to judge the Government's attitude?

—I said that the Government would undertake a series of consultations with employers and unions about the provisions of the legislation. I am not in a position, during Question Time in the Senate, to give a guarantee as to when that will occur. The rest of Senator Chaney's question was rather more crude propaganda, using Question Time as a device, than anything I can contribute by way of response. I have nothing further to add to what I said earlier.

—I ask a supplementary question. Ignoring the abuse from the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I ask by way of a supplementary question: Will the Government ensure that it has a clear position on this legislation prior to the next federal election, or does it intend to go to an election leaving the Australian people in doubt?
—I have nothing to add to what I have said three times.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the Minister confirm that Austen and Butta Ltd has today announced the closure of its Avon and Yellow Rock mines near Wollongong? What is the Government's reaction to this development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the announcement made today by Austen and Butta Ltd to close its Avon and Yellow Rock mines near Wollongong, with a loss of 208 jobs. Naturally, the Government is very concerned at the impact that this decision will have on the men and the communities concerned, and I might say that in recent times we have received very active representations on this subject from the local members involved, Messrs West, Hollis and Martin. The decision to close the Avon and Yellow Rock mines is the most recent of a number of moves which have been forced on companies in recent times as a result of the deterioration in the international coal market situation. The Fernbrook and Gross Valley mines near Lithgow have closed due to factors broadly similar to those which have led to the closure of the Avon and Yellow Rock mines, including the ability of buyers to select higher quality coals in the present over-supplied market.

ANSWER.PARA: Again, negotiations for the sale of the open cut Saxonvale mine in the Hunter Valley are presently under way with the prospect, as is well known, for a reduction of some 90 employees. There are closures in the West Moreton fields in Queensland scheduled next month. I have had occasion to refer to these recently with appropriately condemnatory references to the Queensland Premier. The Austen and Butta closures reflect a number of considerations including an aggregate productive capacity beyond the available market demand with the attendant unacceptable market exposure associated with it, coal quality considerations, which have been particularly important at these mines, and an inability to reduce costs at both mines sufficient to be competitive in existing markets. I might add that that is not as a result of any failure of effort and will on the part of either management or work force in this instance. The company's action is not a direct outcome of the steaming coal price negotiations currently under way in Japan although I must say that the expected flow-on of those lower prices is manifestly a consideration which is influencing assessments of the viability of most mines in this country. Again I must stress that the current closures to which I have referred give us an unhappy premonition of what may be ahead in a number of areas in the coal industry. The continued operation of several mines has been jeopardised as a direct result of the recent coking coal price settlements with the Japanese steel mills and now we have the prospect of significant reductions in steaming coal prices, constituting something of a double blow for some mines. The Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, and I have repeatedly emphasised to the Japanese in particular-and I take this occasion to do so again today-that if they require stable supplies in the future they must understand that prices need to be at levels that will enable the coal mines to obtain a fair return.

I turn now to the impact of these closures on the people concerned. This is a matter of concern to the Government which, for its part, stands ready to assist through labour market programs such as the labour adjustment training arrangements and the relocation assistance scheme. The burden of accommodating the market realities must ultimately be shared by not only the work force but also the community generally in terms of lower export earnings and the impact on the whole economy. We must appreciate the macro significance of these sorts of events that we are now witnessing.

My final point is that despite the present already oversupplied world situation, producers in other countries, such as Columbia, Venezuela and, above all, China, are planning to expand their exports. The implications for Australia, which relies on exports for some 70 per cent of our output, are clear. The message is very clear: We have no choice but to compete with the prices offered in the world market-place and if our coal companies cannot do so as a result of a co-operative effort between management and work force there will be further losses for all Australians in terms of exports, employment and all the economic and social benefits that flow from that. The closure of these two mines is a local tragedy; it is a premonition perhaps of larger tragedy looming on the national scene, which in turn is a function of world market realities. We must accept the existence of those realities and do everything we can at all levels-government, industry and union-to ensure that cost reductions and all the other policy strategies that are necessary to enable us to compete in that world market-place are brought about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce confirm that the sales tax on citrus juice raised about $35m this year, equivalent to $70 a tonne for fruit, at a cost to the industry of $240m in lost sales? Is it expected that growers' prices this year will be below $120 per tonne for navels and $140 per tonne for valencias, whereas the cost of production is between $140 and $180 per tonne? When will the final Industries Assistance Commission report into dumping protection for the citrus industry be available? It was due in March. Can the Minister assure the industry that the anti-dumping provisions will be held in force for at least three years in order to give time for the industry to adjust and for prices to stabilise in this extremely important industry for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, Senator Vigor seems to have a great command of the details, but at the beginning I must point out that there is no Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into the citrus industry and there is no report due in March. Having dealt with that fairly fundamental aspect, I turn to the other parts of the question. First, Senator Vigor asked me whether I could confirm that the sales tax on citrus juice had cost the industry so many millions of dollars. I am unable to confirm that; I think that it is unlikely. At the time of the introduction of sales tax on citrus juices that tax was also introduced on other non-alcoholic beverages and the information available does not differentiate between revenues raised on the different types of juices. However, should Senator Vigor wish to pursue that matter with me, I suggest that he put the question on notice.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, Senator Vigor mentioned the suggested cost of production as against the prices obtained by growers of citrus fruit for juices. Information from industry sources indicates that growers' prices for navel and valencia oranges are likely to be $95 per tonne and $130 per tonne respectively, not the price that Senator Vigor suggested. Again, industry sources have estimated the cost of production as $125 to $130 per tonne and this figure is based on the previous year's cost of production with some allowance for inflation. I referred earlier to the question of the IAC. There is no reference to the IAC, but the matter is being considered by the Australian Customs Service, which is carrying out an independent investigation into the alleged dumping of citrus juices in Australia. The Customs Service is currently finalising its formal investigations. In the meantime provisional measures in the form of securities have been imposed on any further imports that might take place in the period of the Customs investigation. Other assurances cannot be provided until I have received and considered the report from Customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy.
