How can the Queensland Government charge local councils for the construction of the Burdekin Dam when this has been constructed with funds provided by the Federal Government? Will the Minister investigate the options of a legal challenge to this unscrupulous move which once again sees the Queensland Government manipulating its access to Federal grants which do not always reach the intended beneficiaries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is, as we say in Melbourne, the Queensland Government has more front than Myers. I understand that at a meeting with the Townsville Thuringowa Joint Water Supply Board, the Queensland Minister for Water Resources, Martin Tenni, indicated that a standing charge of $35 per megalitre would be set for the entire water allocation from the Burdekin dam to the Board, whether it took it or not. This charge is in addition to an operating or delivery charge which is estimated at about $28 for each megalitre delivered. The Commonwealth Government supports policies that distribute the costs of water supplies equitably and provide incentives for the economic use of national water resources. My understanding of Mr Tenni's proposal is that these arrangements, by contrast, are anything but equitable for the hard pressed water consumers and ratepayers of the Townsville and Thuringowa shire. In effect they are being asked to pay the full capital charge for their very small share of Burdekin water, whether they use it or not, while irrigators using Burdekin water would not be so charged. In effect, the urban ratepayers of Townsville, whom Senator Reynolds so admirably represents in this place and elsewhere, would be subsidising the irrigators of the Burdekin delta.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth for its sins is providing a grant of $129m to the State of Queensland for the construction of the dam. For reasons best known to the Queensland Government the full benefit of this grant is being passed directly to the irrigators but is being denied to the people of Townsville. Along with the hidden taxes on the Queensland coal industry through rail freights, which I have mentioned on more than one occasion in this place before, this is just another example of the Bjelke-Petersen school of applied economics. Its basis is taxing non-rural industries and towns as hard as possible to give one's mates on the land a free ride. An editorial in today's Townsville Bulletin puts it very well in the following terms:
Townsville and Thuringowa residents are being held to ransom by their State Government over an essential commodity: water. The State Government was elected to help Queenslanders, not rip them off.
It is about time that message was understood. It is long overdue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. What actions have been taken to ensure that there is no repeat of last month's breach of the top security Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong when an employee became accidentally contaminated with Newcastle disease virus? Why did established emergency measures fail to ensure that the employee was totally free of the virus before re-entering the community? What assurances can the Minister give poultry producers that this dangerous virus has now been contained, and why has there still been no formal advice of the incident to the industry? Should there be an outbreak of disease as a result of the incident, what compensation arrangements for stock owners would apply if there were to be a mass slaughter of stock?

—I am not able to give a comprehensive answer to that question; I will see what I can get from Mr Kerin. From my recollection, there was a brief discussion about it almost two weeks ago. There was a possibility that the virus may have escaped outside the laboratory. It was not at that stage confirmed and, from my recollection of it, had it escaped it would now be known that it had. I will get a more adequate answer from Mr Kerin.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to an answer given by him in this place on 17 February and a reply given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 17 March on the use of Kerguelen Islands as a nuclear test site by the Government of France. I preface my question by indicating that, despite these assurances given on the abovementioned dates, considerable concern continues to be expressed by citizens of Western Australia about such a proposal. I ask the Minister: Has the Government investigated the Southern Raider incident, as reported in the New Zealand Sunday Times of 4 January? If so, can the Minister report on the conclusions of that investigation? Has the Government investigated a rumour that France is storing or proposing to store nuclear waste at the Kerguelen Islands? If France were to test nuclear weapons at the Kerguelen Islands, would such a test program be in breach of the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources which was signed in Canberra in 1980?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated previously, the Government has sought to check allegations by members of the crew of the fishing vessel Southern Raider concerning France's activities and intentions in the Kerguelen Islands. Indications remain that these reports are without foundation. French officials have firmly denied that France has any intention to move its nuclear testing program from Mururoa Atoll and repeatedly refer to President Mitterrand's authoritative statement of 3 February 1987, to which I have referred before, that Mururoa exists and will continue to exist for the purpose of carrying out nuclear testing activities. While the Government continues to monitor closely French activities and intentions in relation to nuclear testing, our assessment remains that a removal of the testing program from French Polynesia would be unattractive to France on political grounds and in view of the considerable economic cost that would be involved in relocation of facilities. As the Government has made clear on numerous occasions, we would be just as strongly opposed to French nuclear testing in the Indian Ocean as we are opposed to France's current testing in the Pacific Ocean. We simply have no evidence of the alleged French intention to store nuclear waste on the Kerguelen Islands, nor do we have any evidence that France is transporting, as has been suggested in some reports, large quantities of concrete there.

ANSWER.PARA: In the last part of the honourable senator's question he asked about the relevance of the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources as it bears upon the issue. Strictly speaking, the Kerguelen Islands do not fall within the area covered by that convention which, under Articles 3, 4 and 5, are also subject to the provisions of the Antarctic treaty concerning demilitarisation and preservation of the environment. The convention does not contain any provision of its own relating to demilitarisation or nuclear activities. Again I have to say that the convention is limited in scope to the conservation of Antarctic marine living resources by establishing the principles for harvesting and associated activities in the convention area. Notwithstanding all that, in the Australian Government's view, were France to undertake nuclear testing on the Kerguelen Islands its actions would certainly be contrary to the spirit of that convention and our reaction, as a government, would be governed in turn by that consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the statement made by the Chairman of the South Coast Labour Council workers compensation committee, Mr Paul Matters, that Australia `no longer has a steel industry' and that `there will be no coal, no grain and no steel from this region'. In view of the Minister's previously expressed concern about industrial action in the steel industry in breach of the Government's steel plan, will he join me in condemning yesterday's decision of New South Wales south coast unionists to strike indefinitely? What action can or will the Government take to bring an end to this destructive strike action? Will the Government support moves to deregister key unions involved in the dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much regret the industrial action which has been taking place at Port Kembla. I remind the Senate that in 1981 and 1982 in Port Kembla and Newcastle there was the worst record of industrial disputation that this country has seen since the Depression. Since 1983 there has been a continual improvement in the levels of industrial disputation, productivity and profitability for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, arising particularly from the activities at Port Kembla. The recent outbreak of disputation plus some technological difficulties which the company has encountered with new equipment have set back production significantly at Port Kembla. I spoke about this matter at the conference of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia on Monday. I made my views very clear on that occasion, and I have since been in constant touch with unions involved, the company and the New South Wales Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not particularly interested in the views of Mr Paul Matters. Currently I suppose he sees himself as being launched by this level of industrial disputation into a place of prominence in this country which he does not deserve and which in my view he will not maintain. It is unfortunate that a person who has the views which the honourable senator attributes to him in the comments that he made is in a position of influence in Wollongong. I am primarily concerned about the future of that city, which could revert to being an industrial ghetto if people espouse the sorts of views which Mr Matters is quoted in the newspapers as having expressed. I have a great affection for the people of that city and I have a great respect for the role that it has played in Australian industry and manufacturing over many years. I want to see that continue.

Insofar as action which can be taken in respect of this matter is concerned, as honourable senators are probably aware the company has made further applications to the New South Wales Industrial Commission for certain orders to be made. That matter is essentially between the parties to the dispute. The dispute is allegedly about changes to the New South Wales workers compensation legislation which will be passed, I believe, by the New South Wales Parliament on Thursday. At that stage there will possibly be a resolution or more capacity for a resolution of that problem.

It is very easy in a volatile industrial environment for people outside that environment to give advice and to say what they would do if they had magic wands. In respect of this matter there are no magic wands which can be waved by governments-either this Federal Government or the New South Wales Government. Anything I say is directed to the steel workers in the city of Wollongong. I am saying to them that I am more concerned about the future of their families, their children and their city in years to come than I am about the issues involved in the workers compensation legislation in New South Wales. I ask the steel workers to consider those issues in relation to the future of their industry when they meet again on Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I first thank the Minister for this reply, and I share his concern. However, I draw the Minister's attention to a portion of his response in which he said, in response to my asking him whether the Government would support moves to deregister key unions, that that is a matter between the parties. Do I take it from his answer that the Government will not overtly, covertly, or in any way, support moves to deregister key unions involved in the dispute, not simply the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia and the Australian Metal Workers Union to which he referred as the unions against which BHP will take action, but also the Waterside Workers Federation, the Seamen's Union, the Federated Firefighters Union, the Deckhands Union, the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the mining unions that are involved in closing down this vital region of Australia?

—Perhaps Senator Baume alone did not understand the answer I gave. I indicated in my answer that I was concerned about the future of Wollongong and the future of the steel industry and the workers in it and I repeat that statement. I suppose the honourable senator grew up in the days of Malcolm Fraser when governments believed they could--
—Do I look as young as that?

—Well, if the honourable senator ever grew up. Governments believed then that by intervening in these matters they could change the course of history. I do not believe that that would be sensible or tactful. As I have indicated, these matters have to be resolved by the best possible method and by the parties. I have said to both major parties that if there is anything the Government can do to assist a resolution of this dispute, it will do it, but it will not barge in on the basis of the sorts--
—Only if the unions let you.
—Oh, come on. Senator Baume interjected: `Only if the unions let you'.
—That is exactly what you said. You said that you would intervene if they let you in.

—I am trying to answer a question which is a difficult one-difficult not because the honourable senator asked it, but because it involves a difficult issue for this country. In the course of my answer I will not be misrepresented by lies from the honourable senator-because that is what I got.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and relates to the difficult legal situation faced by the Australian War Memorial in that it was possibly in breach of relevant legislation relating to its collection of firearms. A decision has recently been made to allow the Australian War Memorial to collect military firearms for exhibition and research as well as to endorse changes to the Customs regulations which allow for the importation of such items. Will the Minister outline the likely effects of these changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State and I issued a Press statement on this matter-within, I think, the last 24 hours-which recognised that the Australian War Memorial is the only institution in Australia which has a charter to collect military firearms for exhibition, reference and research. This matter has been given the approval and recognition that the Australian War Memorial needs by the Australian Police Ministers Council. I thank my colleague Senator Tate for the assistance he has provided in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Police Ministers Council has also agreed to a request by the Australian War Memorial to be exempted from the Customs regulations prohibiting the import of machine guns and semi-automatic grip firearms. The reason for that is that it enables us to acquire them and place them on public exhibition, an essential feature and function of the Australian War Memorial. I particularly welcome the decision because it puts on the public record the importance of the Australian War Memorial and it also puts it in the same classification, in an international arena, as such important overseas institutions as the Imperial War Museum, the Smithsonian Institute and the Canadian War Museum, which have already been able to get the approval of the appropriate authority for what has now been formally recognised by the Australian Police Ministers Council. This will enable the War Memorial to acquire many more weapons and place them on exhibition, and therefore it will be able to carry out its functions more effectively.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WHEAT SHIPMENTS TO FIJI: UNION BANS

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing both the Minister for Primary Industry and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations share the concern of the Australian Wheat Board that Australian farmers stand to lose millions of dollars because of union bans on shipments to Fiji? Is it a fact, as claimed by the Board's General Manager, that Fiji now has less than seven days' supply of wheat and that local millers are being offered American grain to replace the thousands of tonnes stranded on the docks by Australian Council of Trade Unions action? Will the Minister initiate action under section 45d of the Trade Practices Act to ensure that this market is not jeopardised by totally irresponsible secondary boycott action by trade unions? If not, what action does the Government intend to take?

—I understand advice is being sought from Fijian sources in Fiji-not Australian sources-as to what is the view of the local population about the matter. Of course, the Fijian situation is a very delicate one. The most substantial negative contribution that anybody who I can think of has made was the one made by the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and Deputy Leader of the Opposition when a couple of weeks ago he said, effectively, `Well, it was a leftist government in Fiji anyway, and therefore it was fair enough that it should have been swept from office by a military coup'.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Walsh has quite deliberately ignored the whole of the question that I asked, and I will repeat it. Is it a fact that, according to the Wheat Board's General Manager, Fiji has less than seven days' supply of wheat and that local millers are being offered American grain to replace that which is stranded on docks by ACTU action? Will the Minister initiate action under section 45d of the Trade Practices Act to ensure that the market is not lost by irresponsible secondary boycotts? If not, what action does the Government intend to take?

—I am not sure whether it was this morning or yesterday that I heard a statement on the wireless by a Mr Paice-I think that is his name-that Fiji had only seven days' wheat stocks left. I do not know whether that statement is true. One hears many things on the wireless that are not true. I will check with Mr Kerin and seek confirmation of that or otherwise.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY: RELOCATION TO JERVIS BAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether he has seen the article by A. W. Glazebrook in the Pacific Defence Reporter in which it is stated that there is no strategic justification, let alone necessity, for the Royal Australian Navy fleet relocation to Jervis Bay from Sydney Harbour and in which it is concluded that for the Navy there will probably always be much higher priorities on defence funds than the luxury of a new base. Could the Minister say whether the Government accepts this position in light of the recent defence cuts announced in the May economic statement and whether, as part of the cuts, it has considered dropping the $1 billion program for the move to Jervis Bay? How can the Government justify the $1.5m environmental study when no adequate notice of intent has been given for the full relocation, when there are obviously strong feelings against the move within the Navy and when we all know that the ultimate cost of the relocation will be vastly greater than $1 billion?

—As to the first part of the question, as a result of Senator Vallentine's anxieties on the subject I have become aware of the Glazebrook article in the Pacific Defence Reporter. The answer to the second part of the question, as to whether the Government has accepted the position to which Senator Vallentine refers in light of the recent defence cuts and as to whether we have considered dropping the $1 billion program for the move to Jervis Bay, is no. As to the third part of the question-that is, how can we justify the environmental study in relation to a move-the situation is this: The Minister for Defence, in his tabling speech on the fleet base relocation study report of 25 February this year, indicated the need to consider a fleet base at Jervis Bay against the longer term prospects of the need to move the base from Sydney. That situation has not changed. Environmental studies are, accordingly, necessary if the Government is to be aware of the options available to it and take them into account in decisions on future Navy facilities requirements.

—I refer the Minister for Education to her many recent Press releases on increased student retention rates to year 12 because of what she claims to be the result of the May economic statement. Is the Minister aware that Queensland has the highest retention rate of any State in Australia and that only one in four who qualify can gain entry to a tertiary institution in Queensland, compared to one in three only two years ago? If so, can the Minister explain where in the economc statement there is provision to rectify the totally unacceptable and discriminatory lack of tertiary places in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here I go again. Queensland has a high measured participation rate to the end of year 12, although it is also the case that the way of counting participation in Queensland includes technical and further education students whereas there is a different method of counting in the other States. So the Queensland figure probably comes out a little higher than it should. However, Queensland has a high participation rate to the end of year 12 and for that the Queensland Government should be commended. It is also true that our Government has assisted in increasing participation rates in Queensland, as in every other part of Australia, through increases in the Austudy allowances-that is, the education allowance paid to 16- and 17-year-olds; through the four-year participation and equity program funds which have flowed into many Queensland schools and assisted in their increased participation rates; and through the increased general recurrent payments to all students in government and non-government schools which again have assisted government and non-government systems to accommodate more students to the end of year 12.

ANSWER.PARA: However, it is not the case that Queensland has done badly in terms of its share of newly created higher education places. In recent years Queensland, which has about 16 per cent of the relevant population, has received about 22 per cent of the new higher education places. I have explained this to Senator Parer and the Senate before. It is true that Queensland was very much behind in the number of higher education places it had when we came into government. The reasons for that were that when funding of higher education was a State responsibility, prior to the Whitlam Government coming into power, Queensland State governments had not given a high priority to this area so there was an under-provision. There was a period of growth under the Whitlam Government. During the period of the Fraser Government there was an absolute contraction of funds available to higher education in all States, which badly affected Queensland because it was still behind.

In every year we have been in office we have given preferential treatment to Queensland and given an above-average number of new places for Queensland enrolments. I noted that the Queensland Minister for Education, Lin Powell, acknowledged publicly recently that we have been taking positive action to overcome the backlog which we inherited. As I said, about 22 per cent of new places have been going to Queensland whereas it has only 16 per cent of the appropriate population.

It is also the case that the higher unmet demand figures in Queensland reflect the fact that the Queensland Government spends less than other State governments in the TAFE area. It is basically the responsibility of State governments to fund enrolments in TAFE-we assist with this, but it is a basic responsibility of State governments-and the Queensland Government has been slower than other States in providing for growth in the TAFE sector. Therefore, many students who seek to do diploma or other award courses in the TAFE sector do not have that option and seek entrance into higher education institutions. There is unmet demand in Queensland, as there is in other States. Every year our Government has increased the number of places available. We have increased the number of new places available for higher education nationally by about 40,000 in the four years we have been in office, whereas the Fraser Government achieved an increase of only about 8,000 over a four-year period. We will continue to address in a positive way the question of unmet demand in Queensland as in the other States but with the recognition-it is a recognition, as I said, that the Queensland Minister has made publicly recently-that we are taking steps to give preferential treatment to Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism to the Government's policy to upgrade Australia's capacity to service the tourism market. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government is planning any initiatives designed to equip people in the tourism industry with foreign language and culture skills?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My answer to Senator Colston's question will provide another example of how our Government is sensitive to the education and economic needs of Queensland. I have been able to announce today the commencement of a new training course specifically designed to equip people in the tourism industry with Japanese language and culture skills. As every honourable senator will know, the tourism industry is of great importance to Australia generally, and to Queensland in particular, and the Japanese tourism market is the most important target market for us. Until now the tourism industry has had no special capacity to assist Japanese tourists while they are here to ensure that their visit to Australia is a positive one and, therefore, to create further demand by Japanese tourists for visits to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of an initiative by the Asian Studies Council, established by us recently, we are setting up a three-month Japanese language and culture course which will be carried out in co-operation with the Queensland Department of Education, the Queensland technical and further education sector, the Queensland tourism industry and the Commonwealth. Courses being piloted in Cairns and on the Gold Coast will enable people who are destined to work in the tourism industry to get a basic understanding of Japanese language-though obviously not fluent language skills in three months-Japanese culture and the expectations of Japanese tourists when they visit Australia, thereby enabling them to be better able to serve this very important and growing market. It is my expectation that the program will be a success and that we will be able to use the Queensland experience to extend this very important and economically relevant Department of Education initiative throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce anticipate that an increase in smuggling may occur as a result of the extension of the duties of Australian Customs Service officers into more closely valuing passengers' luggage items on the institution of the $400 duty free limit announced in the May statement? What additional staff, equipment and building alterations will be necessary to implement the decision and what is the budgeted cost thereof? Does the Minister see any risk that the revenue raising function of the Customs Service could impair its duties relating to the detection of contraband goods?

—I do not envisage any increase in smuggling, as Senator Archer puts it, arising from the decision. Senator Walsh has just drawn my attention to the fact that it will no longer be possible for people to smuggle colour television sets. We do not anticipate any great increase in smuggling as a result of the changes which have been made. The other matter to which Senator Archer directed my attention was that of additional staff and whether additional Budget appropriations would be required to administer the changed system. It is not the view of Customs that there would be any requirement for additional staff or revenue in respect of this decision. That view was put to the Government by appropriate officers of Customs when this matter was being considered. It is very important to remember that all items of clothing are excluded from the limit which is now imposed.
—But the bears aren't.
—Is the honourable senator interested in bears or in an answer to the question?
—Does that exemption cover the Treasurer's suits?

—I do not know whether it will cover the Treasurer's suits. That is not the point. The point of Senator Archer's question is the time that would be devoted by Customs officers to administering the new requirements. Their estimate is that there will be no increased demand for personnel or funds as a result of the decision. One of the difficulties which I was seeking to explain under the pre-existing regulations related particularly to clothing. That is removed under the changes which have been made. So the answer, I suppose, to the honourable senator's question is no, we do not anticipate an increase in smuggling; we do not anticipate that extra revenue will be required; we do not anticipate that additional staff will be required as a result of this decision. The honourable senator asks a question about Customs staff in general. That always is and always has been a difficulty in terms of a wide range of functions which Customs has to perform.
—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Government be able to maintain or improve the existing Customs Service without more staff.
—The answer to that part of the question is yes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator MacGibbon asked me a question about the status of serving Army personnel off Fiji. I now have a more detailed reply from the Minister for Defence in the following terms: As the Prime Minister's statement of 21 May made clear, the purpose of embarking the company is to assist in an evacuation operation should it be required. The company's role would be to assist with the security of Australian citizens and the provision of administrative and communications support. Again, as the Prime Minister stated, the company of about 110 personnel would be the minimum number of personnel required for such a task and would be totally inadequate for any broader purpose.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Defence Force personnel serving in the vicinity of Fiji are not on active service. Consequently, they are not entitled to the benefits that active service attract. Contingency rules of engagement for the company have been promulgated to operational commanders and relevant personnel have been briefed. The rules of engagement are strict and entirely consistent with the limited purpose of embarking the company, as explained by the Prime Minister; that is, administrative support and assistance with any protective measures which may be necessary for Australian nationals. More specific details of contingent rules of engagement are of necessity classified and must remain so if the effectiveness of possible evacuation operations is not to be impaired.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 27 May, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for a clear undertaking from the Government that it will delete from its industrial relations legislation all provisions which further entrench the privileged position of trade unions and which in any way restrict or limit existing legal sanctions.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for a clear undertaking from the Government that it will delete from its industrial relations legislation all provisions which further entrench the privileged position of trade unions and which in any way restrict or limit existing legal sanctions.

We bring this forward as a matter of urgency because we believe that the Government in the legislation it has brought into this Parliament is seeking to place trade unions above the law. We believe that that is not the wish of the Australian people and the Government, knowing that, is seeking to obscure its intention by temporarily withdrawing the legislation until it can have its Federal election. We regard that situation as sleight-of-hand and politically dishonest. It is a matter on which the Australian people feel very considerable dissatisfaction with this Government. Today in Question Time, as yesterday in Question Time, we sought by questions of Senator Button to get some assurance as to the Government's intentions. All that Senator Button would tell us was that there would be consultation. He was able to give us no indication at all as to whether the Government was prepared to move away from provisions which will further weight the power balance in favour of trade unions and reduce the capacity of employers to take action to remedy abuses of trade union power. Instead we have the sort of sleight-of-hand to which I have referred-a situation in which the Australian people are left in doubt as to the Government's intentions.

Yesterday we had the quite extraordinary spectacle of legislation which had been under preparation for some four years-a couple of years of inquiry by the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, a couple of years of consideration by the Government and extensive consultation among the Government, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-and which clearly had the full backing of the current Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), being withdrawn on the very morning that a widespread and representative meeting of employers had determined to campaign against this legislation. There is no doubt about the Government's political cynicism in this matter. We believe that this Senate should state the view that it is time the Government gave a clear undertaking as to its intentions and, in particular, undertook to remove those provisions which place trade unions above the law.

The issue of principle that lies between the Government and the Opposition on this matter, and indeed between the Government and the Australian people, is very clearly set out in a paragraph of the report which the Government's Hancock Committee brought down a couple of years ago. This paragraph in the report explains better than anything else the attitude which the Government brings to bear when questions of controlling the activities of trade unions arise. This question of the control of trade unions is not an academic matter. A Government senator asked a question about the coal industry today. The coal industry has a record in industrial relations of having over 40 times as many strikes as Australian industry generally. Whether we look at the coal industry in Queensland or New South Wales we find a hair-raising record of strikes. It was four times as bad last year as that of the mining industry generally, and 45 times as bad as Australian industry generally and that is in our key export commodity.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) today in the Senate bemoaned what the trade unions are doing in Port Kembla. They are destroying the future of the steel industry and the future of the men and their families and children who will be affected by this destruction which is being undertaken by the trade union movement in Port Kembla at the moment. Yesterday there were reports of the despair of primary producers in New South Wales that the endless industrial dispute, again at Port Kembla, at the erection of a grain terminal will impede the export of grains from New South Wales. Notwithstanding all the claims of the Government about an improved situation, postal workers are preventing the delivery of tax payments to this Government. In other words, the Government's own servants are preventing the delivery of mail to it. A succession of strikes go to the welfare of our country and are destructive of our welfare. Why has the Government this attitude? Let us see what Professor Hancock and his colleagues said. They talked about how we can make unions accountable for their actions. They said in paragraph 10.293:
. . . the analogy with civil litigants and sporting contestants ignores a major ingredient of the industrial relations scene--

I interpolate that the analogy being drawn is that civil litigants are required to obey the law and to submit to the judgments of courts and sporting contestants are obliged to follow the decisions of umpires but, of course, trade unions seem to follow the dictates of no-one. The report went on:
. . . the phenomenon of power--
Again I interpolate that that is the distinguishing feature of trade unions as against civil litigants and sporting contestants. The Committee went on:

If we ask why litigants and sportsmen usually accept the adjudicators' decisions, we find part of the answer in the ethics accepted by the disputants; but part, too, lies in their relative weakness. The two factors are interrelated: the ethic of accepting decisions gains strength from the difficulty of doing otherwise. By contrast, trade unions are, to varying degrees, centres of power: they replace the powerlessness of individual workers with collective strength. It is a mistaken view of the pluralistic society to assume that every `subject' is equally dominated by the might of the state and its arms of enforcement. Some may wish that things were different: but vain hopes are no basis for effective policy.

The important thing is that the Hancock Committee is saying that, because trade unions are powerful, they cannot be made subject to the law. Honourable senators opposite are bound by the law, I am bound by the law, the corporations and the great employers are bound by the law. But, according the Hancock Committee, we cannot expect trade unions to be bound by the law because they are too powerful. We made an attack on that proposition back in 1977 in the days of the Fraser Government when we referred to section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. Section 45d made trade unions accountable for secondary boycotts. Recent years have shown that section 45d and its companion, section 45e, are capable of bringing trade unions within the law and of applying the same rule to trade unions as applies to the rest of the community. That is what the people of Australia want. They do not want trade unions running out of control. They do not want the sort of pathetic situation that was described by the Leader of the Government in the Senate today where a few renegade trade unionists can hold Australia's future and a city's future to ransom. They want a situation where trade unions, like other sections of the Australian community, obey the law, obey the rules and are subject to penalties if they do not.

We in the Liberal Party of Australia-we are joined in this matter of urgency by our colleagues in the National Party of Australia-espouse the view that the trade unions, just like everybody else, should be subject to the law. Honourable senators opposite giggle because most of them in their working lives, before they came into this Parliament to loll around on the back benches, were lawless trade unionists who upset the Australian community, who drove employers broke, and who generally behaved in a disgraceful way. I am sorry that Senator Peter Cook is not in the chamber because he is notorious for his activities as a leading official in the Trades and Labour Council in Western Australia. The approach of the Liberal Party and the policy which we have adopted in common with our National Party colleagues are to ensure that we have an industrial relations system in which trade unions, employers and others involved in industrial matters are equal before the law; that the law applies to all; and that it is enforced. We say in our policy statement, which we have jointly adopted, that we will encourage the use of the common law in the civil courts in appropriate cases as a means of obtaining redress for unjustified industrial action. We stress that we stand for the streamlining of procedures to such court actions to ensure more simplified and swifter trials.

When we originally embraced the concept of section 45d in the Trade Practices Act that was a matter of academic understanding. The people of Australia did not really understand what a boon that would be to them. It took the actual use of the sections within that Act to demonstrate to the people of Australia that unions can be brought within the rule of law. Honourable senators should just remember the Mudginberri dispute, which has been much discussed in this Senate chamber. The significance of Mudginberri was that it provided the working example that the Australian people needed to understand-that trade unions, just like everybody else, can be made subject to the jurisdiction of the courts. In the Mudginberri case we saw the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union thumbing its collective nose at the employer and his employees-not just at the employer, Mr Pendarvis, but at the employees who were trying to work with him within the confines of a decision made by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We saw that union thumbing its nose at the Arbitration Commission, the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth, and we saw that union capitulate only when the courts came into it and when proper penalties were imposed for the breaches of the law that that trade union undertook.

The Mudginberri case and cases like it have taught Australia that there is an alternative to this pathetic assumption by the Hancock Committee that trade unions are too powerful to be subject to control. In Australia in 1987 there is a great public demand for the trade unions to be made subject to the same laws as everybody else. People are sick of a country in which the trade unions are above the law and where they can get away with murder.

We find in the Hancock Committee report itself an acknowledgment of the public demand for improved sanctions against trade unions, not the reduction of sanctions against trade unions. In the section of the report headed `Public Opinion', we find the Hancock Committee reporting:
An overwhelming majority of members of the general public supports the imposition of some form of penalty for non-compliance with `rules'.

That Committee commissioned its own public opinion poll and that public opinion poll bears out precisely what is borne out by other public opinion polls that have been commissioned privately on this vital issue. Let me quote from the reports that were made at the time the Hancock Committee report was tabled. One stated that, according to a survey conducted by the Roy Morgan Research Centre in October 1984, Australians believed that trade union power and union demands for higher wages pose the biggest problems for the system and that 90 per cent of the people interviewed favoured some form of penalty. We find in a more recent survey in 1986 that eight out of 10 Australians believe that unions in Australia have too much power. Indeed, more than half of Australians-80 per cent-believe that they have far too much power. About 70 per cent of trade unionists believe that trade unions in this country have too much power and that there ought to be effective remedies against that. We find again that there is massive support-80 per cent-for voluntary unionism; something which is not acknowledged in the legislation which the Government has brought back. In fact we have a situation where the whole community is crying out for an end to industrial lawlessness. The response of this Government is to introduce legislation which will reduce the limited remedies that are available to employers when they face industrial lawlessness.

There could be no more flagrant attack on the desires of the Australian people than the Government's industrial relations legislation. That is why it is hiding this legislation away until it has had an election. It desperately wants to get it off the table because it knows that this legislation faces not only the united opposition of the employees, large and small, city and rural, but also the united opposition of the people of Australia. That is what we are representing in this debate as clearly and as forcefully as we possibly can because it is the wish of the Australian people that the remedies against trade unions should be strengthened and not decreased.

What is this Government doing in the legislation? It is removing the right to seek an injunction under common law which might be obtained if a federally registered union was taking unlawful industrial action against an employer. The common law injunction is feared by the trade unions because it means that, once the court orders that the union must comply with the law, a breach of that injunction puts the union in contempt of court. Again let us not look at this as a theoretical matter. Let us look at the recent dispute with the plumbers and gasfitters. Month after month the plumbers and gasfitters ignored the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. They took continuous strike action against employers which tied up building sites around Australia and they openly, and before the Industrial Arbitration Commission, flaunted their position and admitted that they were in breach of the ACTU, the Arbitration Commission and everybody in the industrial scene. Month after month there were painful attempts to use the industrial arbitration system-the system that is so beloved of practitioners opposite such as Peter Cook who waxed fat on the proceeds of professional trade unionism. These are the people who are supporting a system that has no intent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I object to the remarks made by Senator Chaney. They are a gross misrepresentation and they should be withdrawn. I ask you to rule that they are offensive and that they should be withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Chaney, the words have been found to be offensive. Will you withdraw them?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was using the words in a metaphorical sense. If they are offensive to Senator Cook--
—The honourable senator should withdraw.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I withdraw as I do not want to waste any more time. The point is that these trade union officials are typical of what occurred in the plumbers and gasfitters case. In that case, Mr Acting Deputy President, the plumbers and gasfitters continually defied the Commission and their trade union colleagues in the ACTU, as well as this Government and the employers. What we find, after months and months of this open and overt defiance by the union in breach of all of the applicable rules and the final attempts by the employers to get the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to impose the penalties open to it under the system, is the Deputy President of the Commission who dealt with that dispute saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Reluctantly because in the long term its value is, to say the least, very doubtful, I have no alternative other than to issue the record and certificate as provided by Section 33 as sought by the employers in this matter-

After months of procrastination and abuse by the unions of their position the Deputy President of the Commission issued a certificate under section 33 and he went on to say-and this is the sort of person the Act would require to be appointed to the Labour Court:

I must say it is no secret that I have firm views about the value of penal sanctions and actions of this type, and I have expressed those during these proceedings. I have great doubts about their long term value, but that is not a matter for me to decide, it is a matter for the employers to decide whether they wish to use it.

Mr Acting Deputy President, my point is that these people have shown an enormous reluctance to come to grips with the fact that there have to be some sanctions against those elements of the trade union movement that are prepared to abuse their power to the detriment of Australia and of the whole community. What the plumbers and gasfitters case proves is that the arbitral authorities are exceedingly reluctant to see any form of penalty, even a minor penalty, imposed. In that dispute it was not until the Federal Court of Australia came into it-it was not until there was an injunction, a breach of the injunction and the imposition of a penalty of $280,000-that the plumbers and gasfitters finally went back to work as requested, not by the Liberal Party, but by the ACTU, the Arbitration Commission, the employers and everybody who was concerned. It is in dealing with that sort of rogue conduct, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this Government is wilfully at fault in its legislation. It is proposing to deprive Australians of the right to go to the courts of the land when their rights are being threatened by the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—That is true and that is why this Government has succeeded in uniting the employers of Australia in a way in which we have not seen them united for years. We have seen them united because of these blockages to access to the Federal Court, the destruction of the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and the establishment of a special Australian Labour Court. There is no right to use sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act without the certificate of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-no right to use the common law injunction.
—You are wrong, wrong, wrong.

—Senator Cook says that I am wrong, wrong, wrong but they are the facts. This Government is putting logs in the way of those Australians who would seek to enforce their rights in courts that are accessible to everybody. The Government wishes to get these matters hidden away in a special court composed of people who are part of the system. We will oppose this legislation but we demand, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Government come clean on its intentions before it goes to the people. The Government knows that the people of Australia do not want this legislation; it knows that they want the rule of law to be enforced; and it knows that it is engaged in a confidence trick. It is a disgraceful political performance.

SPEECH.PARA: Written in every line of the face of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, was his anguish at what the Government was doing to the legislation he has laboured on for so many years. Mr Willis is an honest man. Let us see a bit of honesty from this Government and let the Government tell the Australian people whether it intends to destroy the rule of law and put trade unions above the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Bill and the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill, which involve a major overhaul of the industrial relations system of this country, were introduced recently. Already, within a few days, this legislation has been subjected to deliberate misinterpretation, some lies and a great deal of misunderstanding on the part of people out there who have relied--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. A point of order was taken on me because I used a metaphor about waxing fat. That came from a gentleman who is not altogether slim. Senator Aulich has just suggested that I said lies. I insist on a withdrawal. I will not tolerate any of the usual Labor nonsense in this debate.
—Order! As I understand it, Senator Aulich did not say that you had in fact lied. If Senator Aulich did say that, I should be grateful if he would withdraw.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, it is very interesting. I said--
— Order! Will you withdraw, please.
—I have said, and I will repeat what I said for your benefit, that this Bill has been subjected to lies.
— Order! Will you withdraw, please.
—There was no personal remark intended at all.
— Order! Will you withdraw, please.
—I then raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I shall speak to the point of order that has been raised by Senator Chaney.
—Order! Senator Aulich, I will name you unless you withdraw.
—Order! I will hear the honourable senator briefly on the point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have indicated that this Bill has been subjected to lies and some deliberate misinterpretations. I have not said `in this chamber'; I have said that out there in the general community there have been some people who have been doing this. At no stage did I indicate that Senator Chaney was in that position. Therefore, no offensive remark was made about any person in this chamber and at this stage I do not believe a withdrawal is required. I am sure that Senator Chaney does not believe I called him a liar.
— Order! Senator Chaney, Senator Aulich has said that he is not reflecting on you as an individual. Are you willing to accept that?

—If Senator Aulich is saying in his explanation, as I understand it to be, that he is not suggesting in any way that what I said in this chamber was lies, I accept his explanation and do not require a withdrawal.
—Thank you, Senator Chaney.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. One can see that tactics that are being adopted to ensure that the Government is not able to put its case in the full 20 minutes allowed. I have indicated that the Government will lay these Bills on the table to allow time in which those misunderstandings can be cleared up, for opinions to be given by practitioners in the community and the community at large and for those opinions to be taken into consideration. The Bills are important and contain many valuable changes, many of them long overdue and expected by the community at large. However, as a government we are prepared to give the community time to understand and debate the issues before the Bills become law. It is a pity that many of the positive changes contained in the legislation have been overlooked or lost somehow or other in the debate about certain individual provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to deal briefly with some of the more positive aspects of the Bill, those that have escaped the attention of the Opposition. For example, let us look at some of the major concerns that have been expressed by people involved in industrial relations and by the community at large. The first one is the number of unions. There will, as a result of these Bills, be a dramatic reduction over the next 20 years in the number of trade unions representing workers in this country. At the moment we have something like 300 unions, which on a per capita basis must be the greatest number in any member country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. West Germany has about 19, Britain about 40, and America about the same; but Australia has about 300. Of course, this is a cause of many demarcation disputes. It is a cause of problems in covering all workers fairly and equally. Everyone in this chamber who has a sensible view about industrial relations will support that proposal.

That is just one positive aspect. The next concerns smaller unions; new unions will not be permitted to register unless they fulfil certain minimum membership requirements. Union elections will be stringently controlled. They will be conducted officially by the Australian Electoral Commission, which conducts all political elections, unless a special exemption is granted by the Registrar. Secret postal ballots for all elections will be made mandatory. Provision has been made, also, to protect individuals against discrimination against them by their own unions. I could go on to talk about controls over unions and discuss the discipline that will be imposed by this Bill on the trade union movement-and, I must say, on employers as well.

Let us look at the overall economic viewpoint contained in this Bill: What discipline is imposed on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in making its decisions about what wages and conditions it will grant to workers in this country. For example, the Commission will be required under this Bill to take into account, as a priority, the economic interests not just of employers and employee groups which are part of the system but of the whole community. It will not be allowed to compromise on wages at the expense of the general community by coming up with a compromise, for example, which certain industries or the community at large cannot stand. Decisions will have to be made in the light of a totally responsible economic attitude on the part of the Commission. That is a major provision contained in this Bill, one that has not been mentioned at all by any member of the Opposition in public over the last week.

To deal with other areas, the major problem we have in industrial relations in this country is the division of responsibility between State and Federal tribunals. We have six State tribunals and a Federal tribunal. In some cases they work against each other and allow certain misinterpretations and certain disorganisation to occur in industrial relations. This legislation will make provision in a number of areas for a sharing of personnel, a sharing of decisions, if you like, and a sharing of the overall economic responsibility to be taken by those tribunals and commissions. That is a signpost for the future that again has not been mentioned by the sorts of people out in the community who want to misinterpret what is contained in this legislation.

Let us have a look at what the legislation is all about. It does not deal only with structures, although structures are a very important part of creating and maintaining a viable and productive industrial relations system. We have to have the right atmosphere. This Government, for example, and the senior parts of the trade union movement have helped to create that right atmosphere. This has been shown, for example, in the dramatic reduction in the number of strikes that have occurred in this country over the past three or four years in which the Hawke Government has been in power. That did not happen by accident; it happened by dint of hard work, negotiation and a totally responsible attitude on the part of certain senior people in this Government and in the trade union movement. This is not a perfect world. There will be occasions when unions, for example, are irresponsible. There will be occasions when employers will be irresponsible and selfish. The right atmosphere is a very important component in ensuring that that irresponsibility on both sides is kept to an absolute minimum. I believe we, as a government, have helped to create such an atmosphere.

Of course, we get down to tin-tacks when we hear talk about `the intervention of government' in this system. The Government has gone to the Arbitration Commission and has put its view about what decisions ought to be made about wages and conditions in this country. It has said: `As a Commission, we ask you not to give handouts which this country cannot afford'. In that light, real wages in this country have decreased over the past three years in line with Australia's reduced viability as an exporter. As we become more productive and as our export industries are able to compete more effectively-as a result, for example, of the restructuring that is taking place in this economy-it may well be that real wages will rise again. But they will rise within the guidelines that have been set down as part of the decisions made by a responsible industrial commission which, as I said, will be required by this legislation to take into account all the major economic priorities that face the whole country and not just the individual interests of particular groups.

The fourth part of what constitutes or helps to make a good industrial relations system is flexibility. We have had that flexibility. We have had a period in which the accord tended to govern the relationships between the Government, the trade union movement and, I must say, the employer groups in the community. That accord served a very important purpose in holding down an explosion of wage increases during a period when productivity in this country was improving, when this economy was starting to get back on its feet again after the seven years of the Fraser economic desert. Since then we have moved, as a flexible government in a flexible system, into the two-tiered wages system, which will make allowance for those increases in productivity, particularly in those areas that have undergone restructuring under this Government. In other words, there is under the system we have now, and there will be under the new system we intend to bring in, potential for wages and conditions to reflect fairly accurately and fairly what the community at any given point in time can afford. That flexibility has been part of this Government's policy. We do not resile from that. We do not resile from the fact that the Government has a significant role to play in industrial relations in setting overall economic directions and in asking the Arbitration Commission, as it is now, to take that into account.

This Liberal Opposition motion shows a central prejudice against working people and those organisations which have been established to represent the interests of working people-I mean in particular the trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party. Let us not beat around the bush: This motion is part of a campaign not only to attack the concept of trade unions but also to ensure that they are ineffective representatives of ordinary people in the community. I believe this indicates a fundamental misunderstanding about the way people relate to each other in an employer-employee situation. Let us go back to that particular basic concept that there is a way that employers and employees presently relate to each other and a way that they would relate to each other if unions were not present in the system.

At the heart of the Liberal approach is the view that, left alone, employers and employees are equal and are able to strike bargains about wages and conditions that will result in a fair deal for all concerned. On the face of it, that laissez-faire or liberal approach can be seen as attractive-`Leave them alone and they will fix their own arrangements in terms of wages and conditions'. But in practice it falls down because of a number of factors. These factors relate to the way people work as human beings and to the work environment. Firstly, it is extremely rare to find and employer-employee relationship that is equal. After all, employers hold the purse strings. They have the legal right to hire and to fire. Secondly, of course, the major aim of employers is to make a profit, which generally motivates them to see labour as a cost which ultimately affects their capacity to make that profit. That is fair enough; that is part of their brief as employers. Thirdly, in an economy where unemployment has been and will remain high, very few workers have the luxury of seeking work elsewhere should their wages and conditions be unsatisfactory or insufficient. In a society where mortgages, hire purchase and other forms of credit are necessary financial commitments, a worker's ability to seek employment elsewhere is even more limited. In short, then, the employee is at a disadvantage in all sorts of ways, and unless a union is involved to represent workers' interests they will not have the control over their own lives in the work environment that they should have and they will remain vulnerable to the wishes, the motivations and the power of employers. So, as we all know, unions were established to provide group protection for individuals who otherwise would have remained extremely vulnerable.

The industrial relations system in this country has reflected that concept-that there has to be a structure and that there have to be unions to protect the interest of individual workers. It is a recognition that ordinary Australians are entitled to a decent standard of living-not something which is handed out at the whim or the wish of employers, or at the capacity of employers from time to time. Australia led the world in encouraging that fairness and in enshrining it in the type of legislation that we have had for over 80 years and which is now being modified positively by this Government.

In fact, the Liberal Party viewpoint reminds me in some ways of those halcyon days in education when we imported holus-bolus from America ideas for open plan classrooms which said: `Young people can be themselves and teachers will withdraw from any form of discipline and somehow or other they will all learn'. Like the Liberal Party industrial relations policy, which is also based upon the American model of `Let it all hang out', the education system, I believe, suffered from that. In fact, incompetent teachers who were not very good in the traditional system just simply gravitated to these new open plan schools and wreaked their havoc there in an even more uncontrolled way.

I believe that that is basically where the Liberal Party industrial relations policy would take us as well. People who could not cope when they were in government between 1975 and 1982, who mucked it up and who had the highest level of strikes that had been seen for many years in this country, now want to open the door and say: `Let it all hang out; let it all be free; let unions and employers bargain between themselves; let the market prevail'-despite the fact that in 1982, the last year of their government, they started that policy. It ended in the most massive wages explosion we have seen in this country for many years, an explosion which ruined the manufacturing base of this country for nearly a decade. It is only now that that manufacturing base is starting to come out of the wilderness that Malcolm Fraser led it into. The $39 metal trades award right across the board was all part of the so-called free bargaining arrangement the Liberal Party was pushing at the time. Did it learn from it? No; the Liberal Party is still pushing the same policy and the same principle of operation that failed during the time that it was in government. People who do not learn from history are condemned to keep repeating the same mistakes, and I can see that happening here today. This Government is all about reshaping industrial relations in a responsible manner. I heard the personal remarks being directed at Senator Cook by Senator Chaney. Right from the start he attacked my distinguished colleague on a personal basis because that is the way the Liberal Party is organising and running the debate. It is misrepresenting, and forcing people to fear that something will happen to them.

I refer to that one area where the Liberal Party has concentrated its efforts-common law and statute rights for employers to seek redress in courts. The Bill does not take away the common law rights of employers to seek immediate redress in civil courts. They can take out action, for example, for compensatory damages against any union at any time in any court in any State in the country. If a union goes over the top and becomes thuggish and irresponsible, it is quite within the rights of employers, both now and after the Bill becomes law, to take action against those unions or some of their officers.

Employers are not losing those common law rights under this Bill, despite the misrepresentation that occurred during Senator Chaney's speech. Even under sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, which the Opposition holds up as being the only way to discipline legally a trade union if it goes over the top, all that is required is a period before the Commission to put the case. Ultimately, if the case is justified, certification will be given to a particular employer to take action under sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, which will now be taken in the Labour Court. That option will not be taken away, and sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act will force people to seek some form of negotiated arrangement or some sort of conciliation before they go into what is basically a semi-judicial system. I see nothing wrong with that. Injunctions can be taken out elsewhere. If an employer wants to put all his cards on sections 45d and 45e and make them the only way to discipline a trade union, he has been misinformed by the Liberal Party and a number of employer groups who, for political reasons, want to make that an issue. The last point I want to make, and I have only a few minutes in which to do so because of the deliberate interruptions--
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Obviously my speaking time has elapsed because of the deliberate interruptions of the Opposition. I raise a point of order on the basis that when the light was on during the last one minute of my speech, a quorum was called. I ask for your interpretation of the attempt to silence me from making the point that, under the new legislation, unions will be subject to new fines that are much higher than those contained in the present Act.

—Order! I have heard enough debate. There is no point of order. It is quite appropriate at any time for a senator to call attention to the state of the House, and the fact that it was done towards the end of Senator Aulich's speech was just a misfortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate must be seen as an effort by the Opposition to discuss legislation the Senate will not get and which almost certainly will not be debated in this Parliament. The Senate will not get it because of the caution of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who is, in many respects, turning himself from a hawk into a sparrow who wants no boats rocked because of an early election. That is a pity because the Industrial Relations Bill 1987 has a good deal of merit in it. However, it is not possible in an urgency motion to debate the Bill in anything more than a piecemeal fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition motion is fundamentally flawed in its concepts, and it has never been the policy of the Australian Democrats to vote for propositions that are half-baked or based on wrong premises. Indeed, putting forward such spurious propositions is one of the oldest tricks in the game, particularly on a day when the proceedings of the Senate are broadcast and with an election in the air. The public has come to rely on the Australian Democrats to serve their best interests at all times and to serve the interests of real debate. Hence, the Democrats will not support the motion, for reasons that I will shortly canvass.
I was interested in some comments by Mr Michael Taylor in the Australian. Among other things-and I suggest that it is worth listening to-he says:

Employers and other opponents of Mr Willis's legislation should remember they were equally critical of the existing laws and will run the risk of locking themselves into the bad old days unless they can ensure that the Industrial Relations Bill is amended rather than buried and forgotten.

The Australian Democrats agree with that. It hoped that substantial amendments to the Bill would be brought forward in the Senate but the Government is running scared on this matter because it believes it will get flack from the business sector. I shall continue to quote Mr Taylor:
Despite their misgivings-
that is, the employers and other opponents of the Bill-

about certain sections of the legislation, they should remember that the Bill was not all bad and, overall, represented one of the few genuine attempts to drag Australian industrial relations laws into the 1980s.

The employers and the conservative political parties should remember that in the absence of Mr Willis's legislation they must live with the existing law, a law acknowledged by all to be badly flawed and out-dated-a law that originated in 1904.
Somewhat later in the same article some further good points are made:

A new mood of conservatism permeated the industrial relations debate, with the so-called New Right emerging to threaten the laissez-faire attitude of mainstream employer groups such as the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia.

At the same time, the prices and incomes accord began to change rapidly in complexion, with the Government, confronted by a dramatic economic downturn, being forced to eschew the central tenets of its relationship with the unions such as full wage indexation and comparative wage justice.
Though they have been viewed as voices of extremism, the members of the New Right have been effective in hardening the attitudes of employers and conservative politicians.
Indeed, it is arguable that in the absence of the New Right the CAI and BCA would have been somewhat less vociferous in opposing Mr Willis's legislation.

They have said that their opposition will stand, despite the Government's decision to let the Bill lie on the table of the House, but it is to be hoped that they can yet find common ground with the Government.

They are wise words, and words which those who shout and scream about the Bill should think about. The Australian Democrats will not support the urgency motion for a number of reasons. First, the motion contains an implication that the Industrial Relations Bill 1987 contains a number of provisions which `further entrench the privileged position of trade unions'. The Bill does not contain such provisions. Secondly, the motion implies that the limitations that the Bill imposes on existing legal sanctions will further entrench the privileged position of the trade unions. We do not accept that proposition, either, for reasons which I will give later. Thirdly, this motion is yet another example of the Opposition's wasting of the time of the Senate by engaging in a posturing exercise when we could be dealing with one of the many Bills that still have to be considered by the Senate. We still have our work to do, despite an election being in the air.

As I said a moment ago, the Industrial Relations Bill 1987 does not entrench a union privilege; it restores effective sanctions to the Commission and integrates those sanctions effectively for the process of conciliation and arbitration-which I would have thought was something that we all want. Mr Taylor in his article pointed out that it is common knowledge that the Commission has been unable to enforce its recommendations under the existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act. If one looks at the penalties contained in that Act, one sees that they are far below the penalties to be imposed by the new Industrial Relations Bill. Under clause 119 of the existing Bill, for instance, breach of an award is punishable by a maximum fine of $1,000 if the penalty is imposed by the Federal Court-otherwise the penalty is a maximum of $250. Breach of the statutory prohibitions in the Bill on an industrial action are punishable under clauses 5, 122, 132, 138, 144a and 188, with penalties ranging from $40 to $400.

Clause 209 of the Industrial Relations Bill 1987 imposes a maximum penalty for beach of an award or failure to follow the directions of the Commission of $5,000 per breach. Those words `per breach' are very important. Clause 215 provides that, where the failure to abide by the direction of the Commission has resulted in an injunction and the union has failed to abide by that injunction, a penalty of $5,000 per day applies for breach of the injunction. The Opposition and employer groups have been noticeably silent on these provisions, and I suggest that they have been less than honest in that regard. They have shrugged them aside and said: `Well, that is all very well but the really important point is the loss of common law injunctive relief and the limitation imposed on injunctive relief under section 45d and section 45e of the Trade Practices Act'-the secondary boycott provisions.

I find that a quite extraordinary position for them to take. Had the Commission had effective power to enforce its directions in the case of the Mudginberri dispute, the Dollar Sweets dispute or the plumbers and gasfitters dispute, there would not have been the need to seek injunctive relief under section 45d of the common law. It worried me indeed that Senator Chaney instanced in his speech the plumbers and gasfitters dispute in such a casual and partial way. In the plumbers and gasfitters dispute, for instance, the sanctions imposed under the new Industrial Relations Bill would have resulted in fines of $350,000 per week. That represents $5,000 a breach for each day on each of 10 work sites. That is the situation and that is the penalty that could be imposed by the court under the Bill-$350,000 per week. All this talk of a $5,000 maximum being inadequate has been fraudulent to the extent that employers and the Opposition have omitted reference to the fact that the $5,000 maximum can be applied per breach, per day, per work site. They are not advancing their cause by bringing forward all this spurious nonsense that we have heard on the media. If the employer groups think they are going to impress the Democrats because they say they are spending $1m or $4m, or whatever it is, over this sort of thing, when they ignore the kinds of truths to which I have referred and try to impose on the people of this country a partial truth-near enough to a lie-then that is not good enough for us. As I have said, we are here and we are responsible to the people of this country to see that the truth is served, and that should be the purposes of the Opposition too.

I think it is very unfortunate that members of the Opposition are neglecting their duty in this regard. If subsequent Opposition speakers can get up and say that what I have said is not true, I will be most interested in hearing that. I think that they ought to make some reference to what I have said. If I am in error, I am willing to be corrected, but if I am not then indeed the Opposition should front up and level with the people of this country, some of whom will be listening today, and give them the truth of the matter and not simply a part of the truth which is designed for a political end-and I fear for an extreme political end. While I am at it, I would also suggest to members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia that they should not be over-influenced by the New Right. Those in the New Right are not representative of the Australian people; they are deeply distrusted by Australians, just as any extremist group from the Left would be. None of us in this place ought to be interested in extremist views of that kind, from people who are there to push their own barrow and to serve their own selfish interests.
