We know that perfectly well and, for that reason alone, they ought to be utterly discounted in relation to any consideration in this country. They have disqualified themselves from any consideration in Democrat councils by the fact that in relation to this matter they have brought forward what in fact is a pack of lies and half-truths. I have heard that it has even been put forward on the media this week that the Labour Court will have no power at all to operate against any contempt of its proceedings. That is rubbish and it is scandalous that such things should be brought up in public debate in an issue of this importance.

For the sake of completely meeting the objections of the Opposition, I would now like to consider briefly the way in which this Bill does in fact limit existing rights to injunctive relief. Does it limit them? I refer first to the provisions in sections 45D and 45E. The new Bill leaves intact the definition of a secondary boycott and the penalties for imposing a secondary boycott. I hope that we have agreement on that, because that I think is a fundamentally important principle. Jurisdiction for hearing actions under sections 45D and 45E has been moved from the industrial division of the Federal Court to the new Labour Court. That court is not, as one propagandist for the New Right has called it, `just the Commission in legal drag'. That is a wrong and disrespectful way to approach any branch of the judiciary. We in this place ought to have the assumption at least that the judiciary is going to work and do it that credit. If it does not work, then I think we have every right to criticise it. The Labour Court would appear to be designed to be a superior court of record, equivalent to the Federal Court and the State supreme courts. In order to be appointed to that court the appointee must already hold judicial office or be a legal practitioner with at least five years standing before a Supreme Court or the High Court. The attempts by some members of the Opposition and employer groups to impugn the integrity of that class of people seem to me to be shameful and not convincing and, here again, totally counterproductive to the cause that they are trying to serve. That is the ridiculous thing about it; these people are not doing themselves any good with all this nonsense.

In order for the Labour Court to hear an application for an injunction under section 45d or section 45e, the Commission must grant a certificate. However, this requirement does not involve the Commission exhausting the processes of conciliation and arbitration, as has been asserted by those who apparently have not read the Bill, or who have read the Bill but for political reasons have chosen to misrepresent what it says. Clause 197 (3) of the Bill provides that a certification will be immediately granted `where the Commission decides that it would cause a substantial injustice to the party if the party were prevented from instituting that proceeding while the Commission is exercising conciliation powers in relation to an industrial dispute'. That is a very clear and precise piece of legal drafting, which I think does the draftsman credit. It states quite clearly what the situation is. This would clearly cover the situation of an innocent third party who gets dragged into an industrial dispute or who becomes the target of a boycott whose business is endangered by the dispute. If the Commission is not of the opinion that a substantial injustice will result from continuing to conciliate the dispute before issuing an injunction, nevertheless, under clause 197 (1) the Commission must issue a certificate once `it appears to the Commission that it will not be able to settle the boycott dispute promptly'. Had this legislation been in place, in the case of the Mudginberri dispute, and in the Dollar Sweets case, injunctions would have been issued months earlier than was actually the case.

I refer now to the common law injunctions. We are told by the Opposition and employer groups that right to a common law injunction is essential because: First, a common law injunction is an essential backstop or last resort if negotiations fail to stop industrial action and, secondly, a common law is essential because it can be so speedily obtained, within 24 hours it is sometimes asserted. Leaving aside a certain logical inconsistency between these positions, what is the existing position and how is it modified by the Bill? The existing position is that resort to common law injunctions is extremely rare. Where injunctions have been sought, as in the Dollar Sweets case, the industrial action has been continued for some time. The injunction has been sought only where resolution of the dispute by normal industrial relations processes has broken down. As I stated earlier, the procedures laid down in the new Bill for enforceable directions of the Commission which, if breached, would give rise to an injunction under the Act, will prevent a Dollar Sweets Co Pty Ltd type of situation arising.

But there is another answer to those who claim that common law injunctive relief is necessary. That answer is contained in the Senate Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report on the Industrial Relations Bill. Paragraph 4 of that report states:

It is suggested that clause 216 does not trespass unduly on an individual's right to bring an action in tort against a trade union, since at least Waddell J., in the Supreme Court of New South Wales in David Jones Ltd v Storemen & Packers Union (1985) 14 I.R. 75 has already expressed the view that remedies available are inappropriate when the parties' dispute could be settled by the application of principles of industrial law

In the Dollar Sweets case judgment, on which employer groups have so heavily relied, Murphy J. of the Victorian Supreme Court stated that the Court was willing to intervene in an industrial dispute despite the general understanding that interlocutory injunctions would not be granted by civil courts on industrial matters because the normal processes of resolving the dispute through the industrial relations process have been tried and failed.

An improvement in industrial relations will come not from attempts by people such as Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen to crush the union movement and not from attempts by those in the New Right to use the courts to circumvent the Commission. It will occur if the present centralised industrial relations system is strengthened and the authority of the Commission is increased. The Industrial Relations Bill would have achieved that end. For that reason, with the modifications to it which have become a matter of record in the Press in recent days, it will have our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of urgency moved by Senator Chaney is of vital importance to the future of Australia and it is vital for the people of Australia to know the intent of the Government in regard to the Industrial Relations Bill. For the time being it has been shelved and the question that is being asked is why. The question was asked of Senator Button in Question Time today. His answer was similar to the remarks made by Senator Aulich in his speech. Senator Button's answer was that the delay would enable consultation between the parties concerned. Both of those senators have a reputation in this place of being relatively straightforward and honest. However, I would like to question those two observations about them. In a Press release on 14 May 1987-the day on which he introduced this Bill into the House of Representatives-the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said:

SPEECH.PARA: The changes to the industrial relations system embraced in the Bill are evolutionary and were carefully developed through a process of wide consultation over the life of the Hawke Government.

So here we have the Minister saying that the legislation came about after a period of wide consultation during the life of the Hawke Government and now we are told it is being shelved to enable consultation to take place. There is a basic dishonesty somewhere in this.

This Bill will very effectively prevent legal action being taken against one class of citizen, namely trade unionists and their officials involved in industrial disputes, for conduct which would make the rest of us liable for proceedings under established civil law. By whatever statistics we use, whether it be interest rates, inflation, taxation, the size of the debt or whatever, this Hawke Labor Government has delivered to Australia an economic crisis. Probably no single person has contributed more to that than the Prime Minister himself, not just in his term in government but also in his previous role as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. A major cause for Australia's demise has been the loss of competitiveness and lack of reliability not only on world export markets but also on domestic markets. This reduction in competitiveness came about because we paid ourselves too much-this has been stated often by people on the other side of the House-and because we introduced work practices and restrictions at the work face. In the main these were forced upon the community by the then shortsighted militant trade union leaders led by the present Prime Minister of this country, Mr Robert Hawke, whose totally irresponsible actions destroyed not only individual companies but also whole industries.

In the 1970s the trade union movement had been running rampant in the name of improving wages and conditions. But what did it do in the medium to long term? It destroyed jobs. Who can forget the phoney reputation of the President of the ACTU in the 1970s-the same Mr Bob Hawke-as solver of disputes. By drawn out industrial disputation an industry or company would be bludgeoned to its knees and then would be delivered the coup de grace. Inevitably the settlement flowed on and so the vicious cycle was compounded. No account was ever taken of the capacity of the company to pay or survive. I can recall in the mid-1970s an extraordinary claim in the central Queensland coalfields. After weeks of dispute, the President of the ACTU lurched into the area and like a mafia boss told the overseas management of the company that, if it did not agree to the conditions demanded, he-Bob Hawke, President of the ACTU-would personally ensure that the mines would close down and would never open again. No doubt he returned to the bar of the Black Nugget Hotel and bragged about the benefits of conciliation. No wonder that in Japan, Asia and the United States he was looked upon as the Australian version of Jimmy Hoffa. He set about consciously or otherwise to destroy the manufacturing industry and the jobs of hardworking Australians. I will quote a statement made by this man, this destroyer of jobs and destroyer of industries. He said in August 1979:
We know inflation is at 16 per cent and we believe it is quite likely to reach 20 per cent in the next two quarters.
I remind honourable senators that there was no devaluation of the dollar to bring that about-it was simply wage induced inflation. He continued:
But we will not indulge in a trade-off in wages for some conjectural reduction in inflation.

That was Bob Hawke, the same Bob Hawke who currently presides over the disastrous economy he and his cronies have inflicted on the Australian people. It is easy to say that management was at fault in capitulating. I have heard that on many occasions. In many-perhaps most-cases with borrowings to service and contracts to honour or be lost, it was a matter of capitulate or die; pay the protection money or else.

It was also a period when we saw great export industries disrupted by all sorts of ploys, the most notable of which were the so-called green bans at places like Port Kembla where we have disputations going on today. Because of this, in 1977 the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr John Howard, introduced section 45d-the secondary boycott provisions-into the Trade Practices Act. The aim of section 45d was to enable employers to take action in civil courts should illegal activities be taken against an organisation by people not engaged in that organisation. The then President of the ACTU, the now Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Bob Hawke, threatened John Howard that if he proceeded with section 45d there would be blood in the streets. This attempted intimidation of a Minister of the Crown, the blatant bullying tactics of the power-bloated leader of the ACTU, did not succeed and section 45d became part of the Trade Practices Act. Why the concern? The reason he was so concerned and was threatening blood in the streets was that for the first time there was a piece of legislation in place to enable those affected by the brazen abuse of monopoly trade union power-and I deliberately choose those words because many trade unions do not fit that category-to seek remedies through the civil courts. Injunctions could be obtained quickly and proven damages would be claimed.

It has been estimated that since that time sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act have been used between 80 and 300 times. It is a little hard to get an exact figure because on many occasions just the presence of sections 45d and 45e or the threat of their implementation has been sufficient to prevent secondary boycotts. This legislation never sat comfortably with the Labor Government or its masters within the trade union movement. The Hawke Government tried once before to remove these sections but was blocked in the Senate. I am amazed to hear Senator Mason in here do a 180-degree somersault. Perhaps I should not be amazed because I think honourable senators on both sides are used to that behaviour from the Australian Democrats anyway.

The legislation has been used in recent times in the much publicised cases of Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd and the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union. It will be recalled that in the Mudginberri case the management and the employees worked out a deal which was of benefit to both parties, and an export contract was gained. The employees received more money, Mudginberri management achieved greater productivity and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union did not like it. It did not like it because it had in place an outdated restrictive work practice called the tally system and it was in fear that the deal might spread to other abattoirs in Australia and make them more productive. People who were not employed by the Mudginberri abattoirs were flown in to picket the operation; damages were claimed against the AMIEU and were awarded to Mudginberri. This would not have been possible without section 45d.
The ACTU has recently produced a document on the future of unions. The report and comments by Bill Kelty were summarised in the Australian of 26 March in an article which states:

. . . Mr Kelty believes the well-publicised legal victories against the union movement-Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets and the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union-represent `only the tip of the iceberg'.

`Employers are exhibiting an increasing willingness to seek legal redress (especially under section 45d and common law) in dispute situations. The common law and statutory rules are so heavily loaded against organised labour that such attempts to obtain legal redress are almost invariably successful in legal if not in industrial terms.'

What an amazing statement! The ACTU goes on to warn unions to restrain the use of boycott tactics, to make careful selection of targets, to adhere to dispute settling procedures and to ensure that any industrial action is supported by the membership. That is a turnaround-it wants it to be supported by the membership! Unions are also urged to keep disputes within the framework of the conciliation and arbitration system. Mr Kelty says:
Be prepared to beat a strategic retreat where that is the prudent course . . . recognise that legal action can destroy a union.
The article goes on to say:
However Mr Kelty stresses that such defensive, `avoidance tactics' will never be entirely successful.

In order for the union movement to take the offensive it would demand `a disciplined professional trade union organisation with a collective commitment and a considerable measure of employee support'.
Mr Kelty says:
These pre-conditions do not yet exist in Australia. Even if they did exist it would probably still be necessary to try to change the law.

There we have it; that is what it is all about. That is what Senator Aulich did not refer to; he conveniently neglected it. It is interesting to see, too, that one of the great supporters of the campaign against section 45d of the Trade Practices Act is the communist newspaper Vanguard. In the Industrial Relations Bill the Government has emasculated section 45d. It is all very well for honourable senators on the other side to cover up with a bit of gloss and a bit of glib stuff and say that it is still there. It is claimed that it is still available through the Australian Labour Court. Technically that is correct, but for practical purposes it is incorrect. It will need a certificate from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to trigger it, and that certificate will not be issued unless it is satisfied that the process of conciliation and arbitration has been thoroughly exhausted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in all cases.

—That process can be such that it will render section 45d totally inoperable. Senator Cook interjected: `Not in all cases'. He knows and I know that for practical purposes it will, in all cases-in all cases that count.
—No, I don't know that.

—Senator Cook has had a lot of experience in this field, and I would be very surprised if he did not ensure that section 45d does not get to the ball park. Why should an illegal industrial act be subject to conciliation and arbitration? Why is institutionalised trade unionism to be removed from the law that applies to every other institution? For the time being this Bill has been shelved because the Government is considering calling an election. It is not because it wants consultation.
—It is not because I want one.
—Senator McKiernan interjects that it is not because he wants an election, I know that is his view. It is because someone else out there feels otherwise.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said that the industrial relations field is one in which all those with no experience claim to be experts and all those who have had experience know that they are not. If that statement is anywhere near true, we have heard this afternoon from a parade of people with no experience claiming to be experts, not the least of which is the person who moved this urgency motion, Senator Chaney, who has recently been appointed to the new right wing, ultra dry look front bench of the John Howard Opposition.
—He is a pretty face.

—Yes, and will try to put a more human face, I suggest, on the industrial relations portfolio than that of his predecessor Mr N. A. Brown. However, we have heard yet again the tired old parade of cliches used to attack unions as though that were the answer to a rational industrial relations policy. The Liberal Party of Australia has proven in this debate that it has no expertise in industrial relations. It has only rigid, iron-clad pet and pat solutions which come out of abstract theory from the New Right and which are not appropriate to a modern day, advanced economic society such as Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion has been moved, as I said, by Senator Chaney. At least he got it a bit more correct than did Mr Shack in the House of Representatives yesterday. He proposed a matter of public importance asking for sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act to be retained. It may be that when Mr Shack put forward that proposal he had not read the Industrial Relations Bill 1987 which is being attacked in this debate. That Bill which has now been opened for further consultation contains those sections of the Trade Practices Act, so Mr Shack put forward a huge and glaring example of why the Liberal Party is ill-equipped to join the fray in this debate; that is, it simply does not know or does not want to know. It wants to propound the malicious half-truths that are bruited in the public domain as though they were fact in industrial relations.

In this debate it is important to remember that one of the reasons the Hawke Government was elected in 1983 was that it had as its slogan `Bringing Australia Together'. It had as a subsidiary slogan `National Reconciliation'. It sought co-operation, not confrontation. Those were meaningful words in 1983 because we had lived through a period of the Fraser Government in which confrontation was the norm. In Western Australia, under the Court Government, whenever an election approached, new industrial legislation which was supposed to provoke industrial unrest was introduced so that that Government could, as the Bjelke-Petersen Government in Queensland is now doing, point to that industrial unrest and demand yet sterner legalistic powers of sanction to justify a law and order election. In this debate we hear a parade of those cliches again, as the Liberal Party runs after the pyrrhic prize that if one can stir up public animosity against unions one can somehow improve one's political credit. I do not believe that that is possible.

In 1983 when the Australian Labor Party came to power on those slogans that I have mentioned it was not. Honourable senators who have an historical view of industrial relations in this country will remember that in the 1890s, after major industrial disputation around this nation-in the maritime and pastoral industries-there was a generally acclaimed slogan in the community that `There must be a better way'. The slogan gave birth to the Australian arbitration system, which has served this country well. In 1983 the slogan `Bringing Australia together' meant that we had a government in power in Canberra, at the helm of national affairs, which sought co-operation. This has meant a lowering of industrial disputation figures around the country. It has meant that unit labour costs have fallen dramatically, that wages outcomes have been moderate and attuned to the needs of the economy-even at a time, in the early stage of this government, of massive economic expansion-and that the economic adjustments have been smooth. It has also meant that unions, which have been brought into the consultative process, have worked out co-operative arrangements with the Government. Those who have been freed of union organisation-the professional sector or the executive salaries sector-have zoomed ahead and shown no co-operation with the economic objectives of the Government.

Anyone who listens to Question Time in the Senate will be familiar with what the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has often said about the Australian Capital Territory doctors union, which is the prime example of what the Liberals would call a maverick union but about which we have heard from them nothing but praise, certainly no condemnation. We have certainly heard from the Liberals nothing in opposition to the Bjelke-Petersen so-called legislation in Queensland. They are silent and they are condemned by their silence on that legislation. Therefore, they come into this debate with no credit at all.

The truth about the Opposition is that it hates unions and it despises workers. It encourages misinformation about industrial relations either deliberately or through its own ignorance. It believes, as an article of faith, that more penalties and more sanctions will deter people who have serious and just economic claims to be answered, as if that ever worked. It is captive of a New Right philosophy which shares an essentially extremist right wing notion that, if unions were destroyed, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission could be removed, and that employers versus workers in direct bargaining would somehow result in a fair and equitable economic outcome. That is not true; no industrialised country in the world believes that to be true; certainly no one practices that.

In the dying stages of our last three-week sitting period, I referred in the adjournment debate to the anniversary of the sailing of the First Fleet in 1787. On the weighing of anchors of the First Fleet there was an industrial dispute because of exploitation of the crew by their contract owners. The ultimate industrial penalty that the sailors crewing the First Fleet ships faced was hanging for mutiny. However, this did not deter them from mutiny because they had a justifiable economic claim that was later answered by Captain Phillip, later Governor Phillip. The fact is that, if people have no belief that penalties do not work in settling industrial disputes, they do not know Australia's history; they have not read the settlement to which I referred. Penalties did not work in 1787; they will not work in 1987 or at any future time.

If industrial relations is to be a political football, as it is now being promoted by the Opposition, there can be no rational debate or any serious analytical discussion about what is the best way of achieving an outcome most necessary for the future growth and equity of this nation. If industrial relations is argued through penalties, we are doomed to an endless disputes cycle. If industrial relations is aimed at trying to destroy the public standing and credit of unions which are protecting their members' economic well-being, again we are doomed to an endless disputes cycle.

However, if industrial relations is aimed at finding out what is the problem, what are the equitable solutions and what is the best way, we can have a rational debate. A starting point for such a debate is for a country such as Australia to ask itself: which other advanced and mature economies have, as we do, a high level of union membership and an institutionalised union system, and perform better in industrial relations than we do? If that question is asked, one looks at the countries of Scandinavia, at West Germany and at Austria, to name a few. All of those countries have well developed and high levels of union membership. Unions are an established institution. Indeed, in some of those countries they are so recognised by the country's constitution. We also see that those economies have very few disputes at all. They have strong economic growth, low inflation, and low joblessness; they include unions in their economic planning; they have high levels of skills training; and they have a strong welfare and social security base. That is, they have traded insecurity, instability, uncertainty and the political exclusion of unions for consultation, information exchange, common acceptance of joint problem solving, security, stability and confidence. That is the philosophy that this Government seeks to advance in Australia as a natural extension of the legislation that exists.

It is important to go back to the record and see what this Government has achieved so far. The Liberal Party attacks us on industrial relations. How dare it compare its record with ours! The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported that to the 12 months to January this year, in Australia 1.4 million man days were lost through industrial disputes. That was fewer man days lost than in any comparable period in the whole of the eight years of the Fraser Government. Average working days lost under the Fraser Government were three million per annum; under this Government 1.4 million per annum have been lost, a reduction of 53 per cent. Because there is higher employment under this Labor Government than there was under the Fraser Government, if one disaggregates those figures and works them out in terms of the number of thousands of employees, the reduction is 60 per cent, which is lower than the figure during the Liberal Government. This has occurred for a Labor government during a time of high economic growth, a time in which classically a union's bargaining position, and therefore propensity for industrial disputes, is higher. A high level of industrial disputes has not occurred under this Labor government because it has involved unions in a discussion of economic objectives and what would be the best outcomes for the economy. This has also occurred at a time in which per unit labour costs have fallen by about 7 per cent.

It cannot be alleged that this Government has bought off workers. Workers have made real sacrifices in order to achieve the economic outcomes that are now the basis of this Government having the across the board support that it has, support across the business, labour and economic spectrums. The reason for that is that the Labor Government has supported the prices and incomes accord, which has been a useful and important document. The Opposition has said in this debate that, as the urgency motion propounds, the Government wishes to further entrench the privileged position of unions. All one can say about that statement is that it is utter nonsense. Even on the framework of the words used in this urgency motion-`which further entrench'-the legislation we are seeking to modify is legislation that was on the books during the whole period of the Fraser Government. Can anyone who recognises the anti-union streak running up the back of the Liberal Party believe that the Liberal Party entrenched union power and that what the legislation is about is further doing that? Of course it is an utter nonsense.

As the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has said, we are amending the legislation as a natural development of a serious and considered concern of industrial relations problems by seasoned and veteran practitioners who sat on the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. It is important, since this debate has degenerated from what it should be to an attack about penal sanctions, to know what the Bill contains about penal sanctions. It is not true-this should be said as loudly and as often as necessary-that this Bill diminishes the range of penal sanctions open to employers. It does not do that. As for the continued parroting of an argument that it does, one only has to ask oneself: Why does the Australian Council of Trade Unions not support this Bill? It does not support it. It has criticised the Government for bringing it in. Why do a number of unions criticise the Government for this Bill? It is simply because the penalties that are available under two forms of statute-the Trade Practices Act and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-are now brought into the covers of one proposed Act. However, the use of those sections is open, as it is now, to employers. To concentrate simply on the argument that the proposed Act is to reduce the available mechanisms to employers is a nonsense.

The good thing about these changes is that they bring at least this certainty into industrial relations: If the Commission has a dispute before it and it is conciliating on it, as long as an experienced practitioner in industrial relations in the form of a commissioner believes they are producing some result, those conciliation procedures have a chance to work before one brings in penalties. But if they do not work or they cannot work because of capricious action on behalf of individuals or organisations a range of sanctions is open which is, I would argue, more extensive than what applies now. That point ought to be remembered.

In the very short time I have remaining to me in this debate I raise the question of common law. It is passing strange for a legislative body such as the Senate to raise to some exalted level judge-made law as opposed to parliament-made law. Common law is made by judges, by judicial precedent. To abdicate the responsibility of a body such as a parliament to judges is to deny the political process and the democratic rights of ordinary citizens. Common law does not have a special place. All parties in the parliamentary process intervene over the common law and have done so to guarantee consumer protection, such as in regard to the law of corporations-because after all common law could not cope with the limited liability of companies-trade practices and road accident compensation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard Senator Cook defending in his usual way the trade union movement and his involvement in it. Along the way he indicated that senators on this side of the chamber have a hatred of unions and despise the workers. I would venture to say that those on this side of the chamber have probably had as much, if not more, to do with unionists at a coal face level as honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, including Senator Cook, and certainly we have not operated from the hallowed chambers of the Trades Hall. I would venture to say that more senators on this side of the chamber would have had dirt under their fingernails before they became members of parliament than honourable senators on Senator Cook's side. Many have had active involvement in the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: In World War II when Benito Mussolini's axis partnership with nazi Germany was not going all that well he said:
We cannot change our policies now. After all we are not political whores.

This saying has special significance in the light of the Hawke Government's handling of industrial relations, especially as outlined in the Industrial Relations Bill that has been withdrawn from the Notice Paper. `We cannot change our policies now. After all we are not political whores'. In other words, the Hawke Government has every reason and desire to see the current industrial relations system entrenched and does not want to change it, irrespective of all the harm and damage it has done to this nation over a long period. The reference to Mussolini is, of course, quite apt. If the Government has its way the corporatist state, so beloved of the fascists, will be born. A council of fasces will be formed by big government, big unions and big business, and to hell with the rest of us.

What we really debate with any mention of the industrial relations legislation is the integrity of this Government and how it has succumbed to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government has further degraded itself by withdrawing the legislation in the heat of election fever. The heat of election fever is on us, as anyone walking around the corridors of power now would know. The legislation has been withdrawn not because of a need for further consultation, as we have been told, but because of the massive public campaign which was to be mounted against it. I might add that that would have been a very successful campaign. As Senator Chaney said when he led the debate for the Opposition on this matter, never has anything so brought employer groups, big and small, together-and indeed the whole community-than this iniquitous legislation. The more people begin to understand it, the more united they become against the Government. No wonder the Government does not want to go into an election with this iniquitous legislation hanging over its head. The Government may be sure that, having brought it to light and having let it open to the air, it will be remembered all the way through the campaign. The Government will rue the day it ever thought of bringing this legislation in.

The present industrial relations legislation needs an overhaul. I would agree with that and my colleagues in the National Party would agree with that, as would my colleagues in the Liberal Party. But I guess we differ on how the legislation should be changed. I suppose that one could say we should have started to change it as long ago as 1904 when legislation was formulated and the industrial relations club was founded. Clause 51 (xxxv) of the Constitution indicates the Commonwealth's responsibility for conciliation and arbitration. But why do we have it? Australian workers are not different. They are not intellectually inferior to any of their overseas counterparts. Why do we need a patronising and paternalistic Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to look after their interests? Overseas a lot more is done on a discussion and consultation basis even before matters get to conciliation. If a court decision is needed, the matter usually ends up in a civil court after consultation, on either an industry or an enterprise basis, has failed.

One of the major problems with the present system is that it does not encourage good industrial relations. It encourages an adversary relationship. It relies on antagonism and consultation. The whole conciliation and arbitration system as it exists now needs confrontation and antagonism to survive. The legislation would discourage good relations in many ways by, for example, its entrenchment of existing unions and the fact that it would be a well nigh impossible task to form a new one. The membership required for registration of a union would go from 101, as it exists now, to 1,000. I have received correspondence on my desk quite recently from a group which is not satisfied with the existing union it belongs to and which seeks to start another one. This legislation would make that well nigh impossible. In other words, these members would have to put up with something that is diametrically opposed to all they believe in.

Unfortunately, the Australian system was founded on the British craft union system. That system is still pretty well entrenched, to the detriment of workers and business generally. We should at least have industry unions. I would like to see unions established on an enterprise basis, but it would be impossible for that to happen under this legislation. The Queensland legislation which is lying on the table of the State Parliament now for debate in the Budget session allows and encourages the formation of enterprise-based unions, which should be encouraged at all levels. The very basis of an enterprise union is that there be room and time for consultation, even before conciliation becomes a necessity.

I would be the first to admit, as a practising unionist and union official at a branch level in times past, that many of the industrial problems we have today are management-oriented. They result from management not really trying to manage. With enterprise-based unions at least we would be forcing management to recognise their work force, one of its biggest assets, and consult with it on a regular basis. This would be far better than the no consultation situation we have now. Many disputes would be headed off at the pass instead of leading to a confrontation situation and the need for parties to go before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in an adversary situation. They would not even get to that level. So enterprise-based unions are to be encouraged. The Queensland Government is to be applauded for the fact that provision for that is in the legislation that is on the table and for enabling discussion on the matter before the legislation is ultimately debated in the Queensland Parliament.

One of the other problems with this legislation is that it entrenches the Australian Council of Trade Unions as a major political force. We have seen this happen in the last few days. It has been the cause of some questions from the Opposition to the Government. If people doubt this let them consider the bans on trade with Fiji at this time. The Tolpuddle Martyrs would roll over in their graves if they saw what they had started to work towards-to serve the interests of union members-being so prostituted by union officials today. I thought it was the Government that decided foreign policy and had to use export controls. Yet right here and now in this country there are bans on exports to a South Pacific nation which have been brought about by nothing other than the ACTU subverting this Government in doing what it should be doing-exercising foreign policy and export controls.

We now have a union movement which is a self-serving industry, serving an entrenched officialdom and certainly not the welfare of its members. The reason for this matter of urgency is that the industrial relations legislation consolidates the power of the union oligarchy by removing its actions from the ambit of civil courts. As has already been discussed by my colleagues, we are vitally concerned, within this removal of trade unions from the ambit of civil courts, with the removal from the Federal Court of Australia of responsibility for section 45d and section 45e of the Trade Practices Act. Instead of the Federal Court having responsibility for that, we will have this Clayton's court, the proposed labour court, or as I have heard it said, the judiciary in drag.

Much mention has been made, and quite rightly, of the fact that the Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets situations could not have been handled as expeditiously, efficiently and with justice done under this new legislation if it were ever to take effect. There is much cause for concern on our side of the chamber and, indeed, amongst the business community and the community generally, given the record of responsibility dodging by the present Commission, from which the labour court will draw on existing personnel. Dare I instance the live sheep export problems that arose a couple of years ago. The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and Borthwick and Son Pty Ltd colluded on live sheep exports. Ultimately, the court found in the union's favour. Fortuitously the civil court threw the matter out. Irresponsible members of the union movement often hold a firm to ransom and after days, weeks or months, we find that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, or a commissioner, will say that the reality is that the Commission has to give in. Once again another battle is lost and quite often a firm goes out of business because of it.

It is quite interesting that in February 1987 the Roy Morgan Research Centre did a fair bit of research on attitudes to trade unions. It was fascinating to hear Senator Mason talk in this debate. He is completely out of step with what Australian Democrats voters think on many matters. One of the questions asked was: `Do you think membership of trade unions should be voluntary or compulsory?' Overall, the result was that 81.2 per cent said it should be voluntary and only 13.9 per cent said compulsory. Interestingly, of Australian Labor Party voters, 73.1 per cent said voluntary and of Australian Democrats voters 88.8 per cent said voluntary. The next question was: `Do you believe trade unions have too much power, the right amount of power, or too little power?'. Overall, 69 per cent said too much. Eighteen per cent said it was the right amount and 3.1 per cent said it was too little. Of ALP voters 57.1 per cent said it was too much and of Democrat voters 66.5 per cent said it was too much.

The next question was: `. . . three ways in which wages and conditions of employment may be decided. Which one way would you prefer wages and conditions of employment to be decided?'. Overall 22.9 per cent said they prefer it to be by the Arbitration Commission, 19.8 per cent said it should be by agreement between unions and employees, and 50.6 per cent said it should be by agreement between employees and employers-in other words, by enterprise-based unions, as I have indicated. The greater number of Labor voters, 40.7 per cent, opted for that as did 52.6 per cent of Democrat voters. The last question was `Do you believe employers should or should not have the right to take action in the Supreme Court against a trade union?' which is what this legislation which the Government will ultimately foist upon us will stop. Overall, 82.9 per cent said that it should, 76.4 per cent of Labor voters said yes and 96 per cent of Democrat voters said yes. Democrat voters were even more gung ho than National Party voters-only 90.1 per cent of them said it should. It is just as well that Senator Mason is retiring from the Senate at this election which is about to be announced because he is completely out of step with Democrat voters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing an urgency motion which was introduced by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). Normally, Senator Chaney is a sophisticated and plausible speaker but I am afraid that he is off form today despite the desperate cheer squad that he had in the Opposition ranks. He has been given the job of selling the Liberal Party industrial relations policy. That is an impossible task. If I could use a rugby expression, he has been given the dump-he has been sold the dump-because he has had to take the path of Liberal Party policy which is completely unacceptable. It has the hallmark of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies, Mr N. A. Brown, who is the architect of this policy. Mr Brown is Mr Howard's right hand man in every sense and the Liberal Party policy in this area is a radical policy of all the extremism of the New Right. As we are going into an election it will be debated by us and we will show Australian people that it is a policy that seeks to give complete power to the New Right-the millionaires who back the Liberal Party and who make up the New Right. It is a further attempt to entrench the privileged position they hold in society. That is what is entrenched, not the reference to union power that appears in the matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the Australian people will allow the New Right through the Liberal Party and the National Party to experiment in its plans of confrontation and disruption is another matter. The Liberal Party and the National Party unfortunately are puppets to their outside masters. It is ironic that Senator Chaney in introducing this matter should talk of the weight of trade union power because the only difference between the Liberal Party and the National Party is: Which of the two sets of millionaires tell which politicians what to do? It is interesting that Senator Collard, who has just spoken, talks about my Labor Government being associated with big business and big government. In Queensland, where he comes from, it is the white shoe brigade of millionaires behind the Premier with, of course, Mr Stone in the background, who advise him and his Party.

Mr Elliott is the leader in waiting of the Liberal Party. He lacks only a seat. He has the money and the influence in the Liberal Party. He could not get a seat but he is there too. There is a whole list of people including Copeman, Hay, West, Porter, McLachlan and Houlihan. All these people are associated with the New Right. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr N. A. Brown, admitted that the New Right's input on 5 December last year into the Liberal Party's industrial relations policy included members of the H. R. Nicholls Society. They played a leading role in developing that policy. Mr Brown said that he had discussed the new policy with people such as Andrew Hay, and Peter Costello and Paul Houlihan from the National Farmers Federation, asking for their views. Of course, Mr Brown is the only parliamentarian in the whole of the Parliament who was soft on the military coup in Fiji when the Fijian junta took over. So when he follows the dictates of the New Right it is no accident at all.

If honourable senators doubt the confrontationist attitude of the Liberal Party they should remember that included in its secret plan for government was a warning that it should be prepared for a general strike and the likelihood of another election within six months of coming to power. It was very embarrassing for Senator Messner and other front bench members of the Liberal Party when this plan to turn Australia literally into an industrial holocaust was exposed, because the Opposition plans to experiment. I admit that I am talking only about a hypothetical situation when I talk about a Liberal government, but if we can imagine it, the Liberal Party would have the whole of Australia in a mess before Christmas. Business people have to remember that, in contrast with the tranquil atmosphere that exists in industry at present, a Liberal government would guarantee that sort of confrontation. Is it that this is just something from the firebrands on the back bench? It is endorsed by the Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr John Howard; the extremism starts from the top in the Liberal Party. Senator Messner is lower in the order because Mr John Howard said: `As far as I am concerned we need more Mudginberris all round Australia. I want to see them breaking out like wild flowers all over the country'. That is Chairman Mao Howard talking, indicating the revolutionary path that the extreme Right wants in this country. Of course, we have to contrast that with the industrial relations policy of this Government.

But the serious thing, which we have just had repeated by Senator Collard, is that the Industrial Court itself is being denigrated. That is proof of the Liberals getting to the stage where they are actually denigrating the judicial system. Senator Collard referred to the Industrial Court as being judiciary in drag. What about all the other judges? What about the Clerks and the Deputy Clerks of the Senate? Where will this denigration of honourable people following the laws of the land stop? There is no reason for industrial court judges and people in that area to be denigrated unless the Liberals are out to destroy the whole tradition of the industrial relations climate in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your secret plan?

—We have to contrast this plan that a hypothetical Liberal government would introduce before Christmas and the disruption that that would cause with the four years of relative peace that we have had in Australia under this Government, where we have had co-operation among the Government, and the unions and most employers in this country. These people have worked for stability in the economy and they have tried to ensure that working days are not lost. They are now at a level of 60 per cent compared with when the Liberal Government was in power.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the trade unions have been denigrated again and wage and salary earners, through their organisations, have been attacked, as is the wont of members of the Liberal Party who are so determined to defend their big business backers. We have found that wage and salary earners, through their organisations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, are accepting reduced wages. Indeed, the figures show that there was an increase in wages of 11 per cent under the previous Government but that under this Government the yearly rate of increase was 7 per cent. So in the interests of Australia, these terrible trade unions have been prepared to reduce their own salaries, knowing that this Government, through the prices and incomes accord with the trade union movement, has put three-quarters of a million people into jobs. Australian trade unionists were prepared to do that in the common interests of this country. We have also been able to co-operate with the trade union movement-a word that would be impossible to be used in connection with both the Liberal Party and the National Party. Those parties could not introduce the industrial packages that this Government has introduced in order to try to make our industry competitive with the rest of the world. Included in those packages are the steel plan, the shipbuilding plan, the textile, clothing and footwear plans, and the heavy engineering plan; all those plans that, on an industry basis, have helped to make Australian industry effective.

But it goes further than that. The very legislation that Senator Collard referred to earlier allows for industrial agreements in individual enterprises. When members of the Liberal Party actually examine the legislation they will see that it will allow industrial agreements that have occurred over many years in a whole range of jurisdictions that can cover the needs of a particular enterprise. Those agreements will be policed in a proper way by the arbitration authority and they will give us an opportunity to get away forever from the Liberal Party style of confrontation and allow us to move in the way in which the most successful countries have moved. The countries that are showing economic progress are Japan, Germany and Sweden, to pick out three of the most notable. It is not the way in which those countries follow the policy of confrontation but the way in which they put a premium on human resources. Unfortunately, that is the basic weakness of the Liberal Party's industrial relations policy because it seeks to underestimate the importance of co-operation if we wish to change our society. That is what we want to do, and that is the value of co-operation.

As my colleague Senator Cook has said, it is the whole process of trying to solve problems. We cannot solve problems if we have the ideologues of the New Right attempting to follow through their almost religious dogmas of attacking people. Unfortunately, that New Right faction is dominating the Liberal Party. This means that we have great problems because we will just not have the industrial relations policy that we need. In fact, as somebody has said, the New Right is not trying to take policy back to the 1930s; it is concerned about the 1830s. The Liberal Party is trying to follow the dictates of the New Right. I just want to use a typical example of the Liberal Party and the National Party following the model of the Peko-Wallsend dispute in the Pilbara where 1,100 people were dismissed overnight. These workers were offered their positions back provided they accepted the loss of accrued leave and benefits. Qualified tradesmen were told to dig holes and truck drivers were told to clean toilets. In my State of New South Wales a classic example of the mentality of people in the Liberal Party is that 400 people who were sacked at Besco Batteries were given half an hour's notice. That really sums it up.

The Liberal Party's industrial relations policy is designed to ensure that untrammelled rights are given to the employer. The Liberal Party wants to make sure that other people will not have any rights. That is not on because we are going to have an election. The Australian people have had four years of peace. They do not want the war that they will get with the Liberal Party and the National Party. The only thing that the Liberal Party can do to prevent a war with the National Party is to have a war on the whole of the Australian community. But, as far as the coalition parties, as they were, are concerned, the problem does not concern only an attack on a small group of militant unionists. The Liberal Party's policy is designed to attack all wage and salary earners. What members of the Liberal Party are not saying about their industrial relations policy, because it is very embarrassing, is that they propose to allow firms with fewer than 50 employees to opt out of the arbitration system. Some 2.1 million people will be affected by this, some 2.1 million people will not have the protection of their unions, but the employer will still have access to the industrial relations power of the employer organisations. Only the people in small business will be disadvantaged. That is what the Liberal Party policy is and as a result fewer benefits will be provided. It would mean that even the company that is decent and proper in what it is doing for its employees would be undermined by the place down the street that would become a sweatshop. There is a clear difference between the Government and the Opposition. I cannot wait until we get out on to the hustings and tell the people of Australia what the real policy of the Liberal Party is all about.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Watson did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Grimes).

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a brief statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Mr President, within the past two weeks two events of fundamental significance for the future of Australia have taken place. I refer to the May statement of initial measures for the 1987-88 Budget and the Premiers Conference. Those events must be placed firmly in the context of the continuing work of this Government. The great need now is for certainty and continuity. In the past 2 1/2 years, and especially in recent months, the people of Australia have demonstrated a willingness to shoulder and share burdens and a sense of responsibility in the face of the huge difficulties imposed upon us by the changes in terms of trade which have wiped $9 billion from our national economic capacity since December 1984. The Government believes it is essential for Australia's future that this sense of national responsibility, this new awareness and understanding of the problems, should now be harnessed to a great, continuing and decisive national effort. The basis for this national effort is a renewed mandate from the people, a mandate to continue the directions now so strongly established-a mandate to finish the job.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I understand the excitement of honourable senators on the Opposition benches; it will be their last opportunity. Accordingly, the Prime Minister today met with the Governor-General and advised him to exercise his power under section 57 of the Constitution and dissolve the House of Representatives and the Senate on 5 June 1987, with a view to elections for both Houses being held on 11 July 1987. The dissolution is, of course, subject to the Parliament appropriating sufficient funds to enable the work of the administration to be carried on during the election period. I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Governor-General has accepted the Prime Minister's advice. In addition, the Government expects that the legislation presently before the Parliament necessary to implement our high priority programs will be enacted before the Parliament is dissolved.

SPEECH.PARA: The May statement and the Premiers Conference together constitute the substantive part, and certainly the toughest part, of the budgetary processes for the year ahead. The large areas of fiscal policy-social security, education, community services, health, defence and Commonwealth-State relations-have been compre- hensively reviewed. We will not be returning to them to secure further savings of any magnitude for the 1987-88 Budget. Our strategy is now firmly in place. There has been a decisive reordering of policy from monetary to fiscal discipline. By cutting government spending in this unprecedented fashion we have continued to improve the climate for reductions in interest rates. Our measures will provide greater scope for lifting business investment in the export sector and in industries which compete against imports.

There is, however, a significant element in our long term commitment which is being thwarted. The Australia Card Bill is an integral part of the Government's tax reform package, and it is aimed at restoring fairness to the Australian taxation and social welfare systems. The Bill's rejection by the Senate significantly reduced the Government's ability to crack down on tax and welfare cheating, and the Budget deficit in the years ahead. The most conservative estimate by the Australian Taxation Office of revenue gains in the tax area alone is $724m, once the program is fully operational. Gains in social security and Medicare expenditure are estimated to be in the order of $153m. Thus the total gain to public resources from this measure would be nearly $900m. This is the ground on which the Prime Minister has advised a double dissolution, and we are committed to reintroduce the legislation in the new Parliament.

The Senate's rejection of the Australia Card does not stand in isolation. Only today in this chamber the Senate refused to reconsider the Government's legislation to extend television services to rural areas; that is, the Government's intention to give five million of our fellow Australians living in the country equal access to television services has been frustrated, for the time being.

The pattern of conduct by the Senate introduces an element of uncertainty and instability into our national affairs at a time when Australia's greatest need is certainty, stability and continuity. That is the crucial issue in the election ahead. The measures we have taken give this nation the tools for national recovery and reconstruction. Now let us finish the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the statement.
—Is leave granted?
—Leave is granted to make a statement.
—I did not seek leave to make a statement. I sought leave to move that the Senate take note of this critically important statement. It is quite absurd. I seek leave.
—Is leave granted?
—Leave is granted to make a statement.
—All right. Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate, and I indicate that we will move for the suspension of Standing Orders when I finish my statement so that we can deal with this statement in a proper way. I might say that the next government-the Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia government-will not have a Manager of Government Business who so wastes the time of the Senate. This is a very important announcement by the Government. It shows once again that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is incapable of telling the truth. We have had a succession of statements from Mr Hawke about his election timing. We have had a succession of statements and claims about the integrity of the Prime Minister. He went early in 1984 after he had said that he would not go early. In the course of that campaign he said that this Parliament would go its full term. We now have a situation where, well under the full term, and, most importantly, before the Government has brought down its Budget, Mr Hawke is going to an election.
—What has he got to hide?

—Of course, the simple question is the one that has been asked by my colleague Senator Michael Baume: What does the Prime Minister have to hide? What he said on 1 April, eight weeks ago-I suppose he felt he was entitled to mislead the public on April Fool's Day-was:

SPEECH.PARA: I have decided that the election will be held towards the end of this year or early next year.
Two weeks ago, on 14 May, he said:
I don't see any reason, I can't envisage any reasons for a July election.
On Michael Schildberger's program a day later he said:
I said yesterday it can't be July in any circumstances that I can imagine.

No new factor has emerged in that time. The pathetic excuses trotted forth by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) were all known to the Government when the Prime Minister made those statements on 14 and 15 May. The reality is that the Government has decided to run for cover-to run for an election before the August Budget is brought down and before its attitude on the industrial relations legislation is determined.

We welcome this election because it is a chance to tip this hopeless Government out of office, and that is what we will do. Just as the officials of the Australian Labor Party have been warning the Government about the fragility of its standing in the electorate, let me remind the Government that the dent in family living standards that has been made by this Government will be a central issue of this campaign. When the Fraser Government left office families were told by the Labor Party that they were in a difficult position. The reality is that after nearly four years of Labor the tax burden on families has increased. It has gone from about 17 cents in the dollar to 20 cents in the dollar. The burden of interest has increased, and the people in the small businesses and on the farms of Australia have been crushed by high interest rates. We welcome the opportunity that is being given to those voters to tell this Government what they think of it.

Today we had a debate on trade union power. We can understand why the Australian Democrats are very pleased about this result because, of course, it gives them some faint chance of evading the annihilation which they would have faced in a half-Senate election. But we should note the way the Australian Democrats today supported the Australian Government in its preparedness to insulate trade unions from the operation of the law. In a society in which 80 per cent of the Australian people believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.

—Listen to the ex-trade union officials such as Senator Peter Cook, who terrorised the people of Western Australia with his antics as a trade union official. Listen to him getting hot in his defence of trade union power in this country. I hope that Senator Peter Cook campaigns a great deal.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Chaney has done this several times today. He insists on using that word with respect to myself in ways which are demeaning. The word `terrorise' is an inappropriate and unparliamentary expression in these circumstances and he should be required to withdraw it. It is not only inappropriate; it is also untrue.

—Perhaps I may speak to the point of order. I can understand Senator Peter Cook wishing to hide his antecedents, Mr President, which are not particularly pleasant, but I would say that there is nothing unparliamentary about saying that the honourable senator, as a trade union official, terrorised the people of Western Australia. I am sure I could produce a stack of affidavits to confirm that that was the view. I would say that there is no precedent that would suggest that that is an unparliamentary expression.
—It is a reflection on Senator Cook to which he took personal offence and, in those circumstances, Senator Chaney should withdraw.

—I assure you, Mr President, that out on the hustings I shall be happy to use the same expression. I withdraw, in deference to your ruling and the sensitivity of Senator Cook. Having seen Senator Cook in action when he was working with the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council and when he was inflicting such harm on the Western Australian economy, I can only say that he did not show the same sensitivity at that time as he has shown in the chamber today.
—Have you withdrawn or haven't you?
—Mr President, I cannot help it if Senator Cook's hearing is defective or he was not listening.
—Senator Chaney has withdrawn.

—I invite that wonderful phalanx of ex-trade union officials who warm the benches opposite to take an active part in this campaign and to draw the attention of the Australian people to the fact that their Government was bringing forward legislation that it has now hidden away until after this election is held. It is hidden away forever now because this Government will not be there to reintroduce it after the election.

SPEECH.PARA: I invite all of those ex-trade union officials and ex-trade union lawyers, such as Senator Button, to remind the Australian people that their Government is trying to prevent the legal remedies that were utilised in cases like Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd and the recent strike by the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia being available to the Australian people. Some 80 per cent of the Australian people are absolutely horrified by the abuses of trade union power that are occurring to this very day.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—Senator Cook will defend the trade unions if they order the massacre of the innocents; that is the extent of his loyalty.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think that is called going over the top, and I ask Senator Chaney to withdraw.
—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber and I ask that Senator Chaney be heard in silence.

—The point I am making is that many of the elected members of the Labor Party have direct personal experience of abuse of trade union power, and I invite them to present freely to the Australian people their proposition that they wish to prevent Australian citizens from taking trade unions to the courts when they breach the common law, and obtaining an injunction that would be prohibited under the legislation. The Government is trying to restrict access to the Trade Practices Act; it is trying to prevent future successes like Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets and the termination of the plumbers and gasfitters strike. I invite the Labor Party to campaign on that issue because the people of Australia are totally fed up with the approach of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the actual reasons that have been trotted forth by the Government for bringing about this double dissolution? An examination of those reasons shows what a sham we have on our hands. The Government has said that the Australia Card Bill will be defeated-it was defeated some months ago and the Government could have had a double dissolution then-and of course the legislation with regard to rural television services was not re-listed today. The rural communities of Australia will not forgive this Government for the hardship it has imposed upon them in recent years. Honourable senators opposite know that there is vast discontent in rural Australia about what has been inflicted on them.

I do not think we will see many of the honourable senators opposite campaigning in the rural areas of Australia because the 20 per cent interest rates which have been inflicted year after year upon the farming community of Australia are driving farmers from their farms and forcing others into poverty. That is the legacy the Government is offering the rural community. When it makes some cheap crack about rural television services and expects to win the rural community, it will be treated with the contempt with which the suggestion has been treated by the Senate.

What is the Government's own evidence about the savings that would accrue from an Australia Card? There would be no net savings in the next couple of years at least, on the Government's own figuring. This is another example of a sham. The reality is that the Government has brought down two-thirds of its Budget. It has brought down a mini-Budget, which has dealt with part of the August Budget. The Government has dealt with the Premiers Conference and, needless to say, it wants an election before the results of that conference show. With the exception of the Premier of Queensland, who rushed off and made sure that some of his charges are raised immediately, the impact the conference will have on the voters of Australia will be felt, in the main, only when the States bring down their Budgets later this year. No wonder the Government wants an election in July. If it waits for the full course of this Parliament to run or if it waits until December, the States will have brought down their Budgets and the full effects of the Government's maladministration of this country will be seen.

What has the Government got to hide? It has to hide the State Budgets as well as its own Budget. The Liberal Party will be pursuing the Government before the election on 11 July to expose what it is going to do to the Australian people in the Budget. The Government should come clean and tell the people of Australia what it is going to do. It would not be game.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your tax policies?

—Senator Elstob ran for election in 1984 on the promise to have a tax summit, and he babbles away now trying to justify this sham on the part of the Government of which he is a member. It is quite clear that there is no justification for an early election. The only justification the Government has for having an early election is that it is frightened of what the next few months will bring for the people of Australia. This Government, having introduced its mini-Budget, is now trying to have an election before it discloses to the Australian people what the full impact of its budgetary measures will be. That is a simple fact. The necessary hard measures are to be hidden from the Australian people, while the Government will produce the sweeteners in the form of its election campaign. We have been told that there will be a package dealing with family living standards, so I shall now turn to what the Government has done for families over recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has taken two million people out of the health insurance system. The proud effect of Medicare has been to produce a queue of 100,000 people waiting for operations and to force two million people out of the health insurance system. There is now the prospect of greater medical charges, higher insurance charges and still more Australian families being refused the capacity to insure their health. That is one contribution.

Another contribution of the Government has been to take the cost of buying a house from something like 19 per cent of family income to about 26 per cent of family income. That is the sort of change that has put the squeeze on people in the suburbs of Australia, and it is the sort of change that will lead to the rejection of the Government in the suburbs of Australia. For years the farms of Australia have been faced with interest rates of 20 per cent. That is going to tell against the Government in the election it has called for 11 July. The purchasing price of families has declined under Hawke; real incomes have declined under Hawke; and the price of the family car has gone up by 42 per cent or more under this Government. In every area, families have been put under the squeeze.

The most significant action by the Government is that which it is now trying to hide from the Australian people-its concession to trade unions that they are not to be subject to the law. The Australian people will hear a great deal about those issues over the next few weeks. The Opposition knows the Australian people totally reject the Government's attempt to put trade unions above the law. They totally reject the idea that somebody like Senator Cook, when he is the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council, cannot be dealt with under the Trade Practices Act whereas ordinary people can be. They reject that sort of protection being given to trade union officials; they will reject this Government, and I look forward to this election and seeing many of the honourable senators opposite not returning to this place.

Finally, I turn to the Australian Democrats. One of the reasons why the Labor Government is having a double dissolution is that it knows it cannot win a majority in the Senate in its own right. It knows that since it fiddled the Parliament and increased its size, it cannot get a majority in the Senate. It is common knowledge that the Government believes it can get anything it wants while the Australian Democrats hold the balance of power in the Senate. It is common knowledge that the Australian Democrats are almost indistinguishable from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party on critical issues.

The attitude of the Australian Democrats in relation to the nuclear issue, defence, environmental matters or taxation is almost totally consistent with that of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. All I can say is that in this election the betrayal of middle Australia by the Australian Democrats will be amply rewarded by the electorate, which will repay them in kind by failing to support them in the campaign that lies ahead. The fact remains that, in relation to the Government's key legislative proposals, particularly those proposals which are not wanted by the Australian people, it has been the Australian Democrats who have provided the means of the Government getting its new taxes and the various other things that this Government has wrought on the Australian community. We believe that the election has been called at this time so that the Government can seek to hide from the consequences of its actions, but we say, Mr President, that we welcome the election. We look forward to the people of Australia throwing this Government out on to the street.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Before I make some general comments on the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has seen fit to call an election some six months or more earlier than was required, I think I ought to take up a point that was raised by Senator Chaney and say that just occasionally the honourable senator ought to let the facts get in the way of a not very good argument. In this instance Senator Chaney ought to look at the voting figures of his Party relating to the last session. If Senator Chaney does the same sort of checks that I have done, he will find that more of this Government's legislation went through on divisions last session when he and his Party voted with the Labor Government than was the case in relation to the Australian Democrats. In case his memory needs jogging, let me mention things like increases in the wine tax, an imposition of 10 per cent sales tax on fruit juice and milk products, cuts to the English as a second language program, delays to the poverty traps implementation legislation, and a delay to the normal November consumer price index increases to pensions.
—Would you have blocked Supply?

—Oh, the honourable senator should come here for a few more years and he will learn the difference between the Supply Bills and other legislation. If members of the Liberal Party are going to argue that they have to support every piece of legislation that is introduced in the Budget session, I suggest that in order to save this country a lot of money they go back to their electorates between August and December and come here only during those months when they think that they can consider legislation on its merits and vote accordingly.
—You do?

—Senator Chaney should not give me that sort of rubbish. There are plenty of people in rural Australia who are only too aware of who is responsible for the problems facing the grape growers, the citrus growers, the dairy industry, and families in rural Australia generally. So, Senator Chaney should not get all hysterical about our voting record before he has looked at his own. However, Senator Chaney's comments indicate why the Prime Minister has taken, to put it charitably, the rather pragmatic stance of calling an election as early as he has. I suppose that those of us who are a little less charitable would call it plain opportunism. In any event, whether it is pragmatism, opportunism, or whatever else, clearly, the Prime Minister has weighed up all the facts that he has had at his disposal and has decided to call the election, as I have said, some six or more months earlier than was necessary. One of the reasons why he has felt so confident was indicated quite clearly in the drivel that we have just heard from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.
