The Prime Minister knows, as does everyone else, that, short of hysteria, the opposition Parties have very little to put against him. They are in total disarray. Their communication spokesman cannot even work out their policy. He makes statements such as: `They sounded like a good idea at the time'. Then he has to go against them. The Liberals have more wings in their political party than does the Labor Party, and those in the Liberal Party spend most of the time not talking to each other. There is no doubt at all that, had the Opposition been united, even the Liberal Party within itself, much less with the National Party at the same time-with which it is sometimes in coalition while at other times it is not-the Government would not have perceived that now is an appropriate time to call an election.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, that disarray in the Opposition ranks has led the business community, so assiduously wooed by the Prime Minister over the last few years, I might point out, to indicate that it would prefer a Hawke led Labor government to win the next election than a Liberal government led by what could be anybody-assuming that the Liberal Party can find anyone at all to lead it. Of course, the May economic statement sealed the support that the big business New Right buddies of the Labor Party were giving it. Of course, those people who are not part of the New Right, who are not people involved in big business-those ordinary people like pensioners and members of families on low incomes-have been ignored by the Labor Party, although the Labor Party believes that those people represent captive votes and that they are unlikely, as indeed is the case, to vote for the Liberal Party. Finally, of course, Mr Hawke believes that, with confusion reigning over the media legislation, the owners, the media barons in this country, are going to be particularly kind to the Labor Party during an election campaign, secure in the knowledge that the Labor Party is prepared to legitimise the purchases that were made illegally in the past six months, in the hope that the whole package of legislation will get through.

Having made that point, I acknowledge that Senator Chaney is perfectly correct in one statement that he made. I would be less than honest and in fact less than an appropriate leader of the Australian Democrats if I did not acknowledge the fact that since the election has been called early I am of course pleased that it is going to be a double dissolution. The speculation is now over; we can get ourselves into an election mode, and I acknowledge that it is going to be somewhat easier for us with a double dissolution. At least I am honest enough to admit that. I do not pretend, as Senator Chaney does, that I am opposed to everything that members of the Labor Party put forward. When one looks at the voting figures one realises that clearly he is not, or he would not have sat in their arms as often as he did in the period between August and December of last year. During the next few weeks we will be doing what every political party in this place ought to be doing, namely, going to the electorate with policies and a past record of which one can be proud. That sets us apart from other parties, and the Australian Democrats will campaign along those lines.

I think that our support for the average Australian family-as distinct from families who live in Toorak, or on the North Shore in Sydney, or in any other well to do suburb-is well know, as is our demonstrable effectiveness in relation to anti-nuclear and environmental protection issues and our responsible role in reviewing every piece of legislation on its merits. We are not concerned solely with when it is introduced into this place or whether it is part of a Budget strategy or whether it is introduced between February and June. The Australian Democrats exercise a responsible role in reviewing every piece of legislation on its merits and that is something that we will be able to campaign on.

The other point that of course needs to be made during the election campaign-and I am sure we will not be the only ones making it-concerns, as Senator Chaney said, the matter of the control of the Senate. Neither of the major political parties can get control of the Senate in its own right; it can become neither a rubber stamp nor totally obstructionist. So, the choice that the Australian people will have in the coming weeks is between putting the balance of power in the hands of a political party such as the Australian Democrats, which in fact does review legislation on its merits, or letting it slip into the hands of a party such as a Joh Bjelke-Petersen led National Party, for which of course the ends have always justified the means. This election campaign will be not just a matter of policies and issues but also something that focuses entirely on the Senate as a house of review.

Therefore, I found it rather interesting that during his impassioned speech Senator Chaney was able to focus on only one campaign issue, the old spectre of union power. We know that Senator Chaney and many others in the Liberal Party of Australia would prefer to have the employers in total power in this country. If they do not actually want children back down the mines, they come perilously close to it. Quite clearly, the Liberal Party is devoid of policies if all it can do at the beginning of a fair election campaign is start a series of scare tactics in its attempts to win office. Liberal members can be assured that the sorts of people whom Senator Chaney mentioned-those in rural Australia, Australian families, pensioners, ethnic and Aboriginal groups-will not fall for the promises and the rhetoric of the Liberal Party. They will be much more aware of how this place operates and what political parties really have to offer. It will not take much for them to work out that the Liberal Party is not only in disarray, but it also has nothing new to offer and that there is very little that is worthwhile in the old measures it is offering. We are looking forward-as I presume everyone else is-to the successful completion of a longer than usual campaign and to being returned to this place in increased numbers after 11 July.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We are in the election mode; the button has been pressed and away we go. When I heard the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines) speak to the statement put down by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), I could not help but think of the words of a senator in the United States of America whose name escapes me. He described the Democrats in the United States as being `indeed like the mule-without pride of ancestry or hope of posterity'. I often think that that applies to the Democrats in this country as well. In this instance, their only hope of posterity is to sidle up to the Labor Government and they have done that quite effectively. Indeed, it is quite amazing.
—What about you?

—Despite the length of time that the Democrats have been in this place they do not seem to understand the basic principle that is accepted by both major political influences in this nation-that the government of the day is entitled to its Budget. The Democrats should have a look at the speeches in the Budget debate in order to see what we really think about that. That has always been a principle.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I will look at the reasons the Leader of the Government in the Senate has given for holding this election. First, he talked about the May mini-Budget and the Premiers' conference. However, he did not speak about the matter which Senator Chaney said he should have spoken about-that is, the forthcoming Budget. We have seen that previous Budgets have been out in their growth and inflation predictions. It was as if the Government was heading for massive budget deficits which it knew it could not handle. Because of that we had to go through the sham of a mini-Budget. The announcements in the mini-Budget were greeted by the Press at first blush as something which it could embrace. We were to have $4 billion in cuts. Once we saw the fine print we realised that only a small proportion of that would be this Government's cuts. The rest of the cuts would be made by the States, by the sale of assets and by increased charges which would ultimately be passed on to the consumers through Telecom Australia and Australia Post.

So we come down to the fact that the chickens have come home to roost and this Government will not face the hard decisions that it should have faced all along for the 1987 Budget. The Government has required an election before the Budget. Hopefully when we are in office we can take the hard decisions that are needed to get this economy back on the road. The Labor Government has had all its opportunities; it has had what could be described as a government-led recovery which worked quite well. It had the pump priming with $15 billion extra in government expenditure in the first two Budgets and that went quite well until the overseas money markets began to wake up to what this was all about. Then we began to see the dollar go down the tube. Then, of course, to prop up the dollar and save some sort of credibility in its fiscal management, the Government had to increase interest rates. Thus we had this government-led recovery being put down by the overseas money markets. Then we had--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Could the honourable senator make his position clear as to which party he represents? Does he represent the new National Party of Queensland or the National Party of Australia?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—What else would one expect from a government that is under siege and that will not bring down a responsible Budget? The Government has had to prop up interest rates to support the dollar which was put down by the rest of the world when it saw the incompetence of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: However, those interest rates have had a disastrous effect across the length and breadth of this nation and on every aspect of society. We have seen small businesses, through no fault of their own, folding because of interest rates. We have seen farmers being physically carried off their properties, not through any lack of expertise and hard work or through bad budgeting, but because the artificially high interest rates which this Government introduced to prop up the dollar have put them out of business. We have seen home owners who have quite legitimately borrowed money from lending institutions at a certain rate-a rate which they could meet-being forced to leave those homes after scrimping and saving because the homes have been repossessed. Those people have lost all the money they had saved plus all the money they had put into their homes, all because of the interest rates brought about by the incompetence of this Government. No wonder the Government wants an election; it is fearful of the hard decisions it will have to take in the next Budget.

Next I turn to the current account deficit. We have seen that rocket to figures that we would never have thought possible-more than $1 billion month after month. When this deficit suddenly goes below the $1 billion mark the Government thinks it has achieved something. It is like the difference between belting one's head against a brick wall and belting it against a wooden wall because the wood is somehow softer. The cold, hard fact remains that every month this country has been buying more than it has been selling and consuming more than it has been producing. The world money markets have reacted to that. Our total foreign debt from the time of Federation until this Government took office in 1983 was $23 billion. Now it is more than $100 billion. Such is this Government's incompetence in its handling of the affairs of this country!

The Leader of the Government mentioned the Australia Card and Senator Chaney dealt well with that. We had a Senate select committee to look at the Australia Card. Its report told us that all the things that the Government said the Australia Card would do, it would not do except, perhaps, in the area of taxation. We know from other reports-those of the Auditor-General and the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee-that the Australian Taxation Office has it well within its own capabilities to fix up any problems in the tax system. The Government also mentioned the television legislation. Let us talk about that. When the Liberal and National Parties were in government they first gave rural Australia the opportunity to have greater access to television. This Government chose not to do that. Instead, it sold itself out to the major moguls in this country. I find it hard to believe that a Labor government, which purports to represent the small people of this nation, has sold out to two or three people in the television industry. I am not in the business of voting for legislation here which allows two or three people the right to print money.

Then we had all the talk about this Government running its full term. Senator Chaney dealt with that well, but it is another of the many statements that we have heard. Do we not remember the statement: `Let there be no misunderstanding: There will be no capital gains tax.'? There were many others that will be brought home to the people of Australia during the coming election campaign, such as the recent one that this Government will run its full term. Now we see what Labor integrity is all about. Today we have had a debate about trade union power. This Government is really entrenching it and, worse still, taking it away from the ambit of the civil courts.

As well as the high interest rates we have high tax rates. In spite of all the tax cuts that we supposedly have had and the ones that we are still supposed to get on 1 July, the average taxpayer will be worse off than he was in 1983 when this Government came to power. Like my colleagues, I welcome the opportunity of getting out on the election trail and bringing home to the people of Australia what this Government is all about, its record and what it has done to ordinary people, business, farmers, home owners and Australia's record on the international scene. It will give me very great pleasure to bring that home to the people of Australia, and I welcome the opportunity to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There is no doubt in my mind that the Government's calling of a snap double dissolution is a blatant exercise of political pragmatism. There is no other reason for the Government to call a snap election at this time other than that it is concerned about the way the economy is performing. As an industrialist, as one who has to keep an ear close to the market-place, I have detected in recent weeks a dramatic downturn in the economy. There is no doubt at all that this snap election is being called simply because the Government is concerned that the chickens are coming home to roost, that its mismanagement in the last few months, particularly its mismanagement in relation to the May statement, is having a dramatic and disastrous effect on the economy, which is turning down quickly. The Government wants to get an election out of the way before this becomes obvious to the general public.

SPEECH.PARA: The Unite Australia Party, the newest political party to be represented in this Parliament, welcomes an election nevertheless. It welcomes it for this reason: It will be fielding a first-class Senate team in all mainland States. It has an important message to get across, that there is an alternative way to manage the economy. Debate on this is not occurring in this Parliament; it is not occurring in the media at the moment; but that message, I believe, can be got across in an election mode. It will be a challenge for and the task of the Unite Australia Party to say that something has to be done about the fact that we are borrowing $10 billion a year and that we are selling $4 billion of our assets every year to make up the shortfall in our trading position. We are spending more than we earn, to the tune of $14 billion a year. The Government has been congratulating itself that it will save $3 billion to $4 billion in expenditure, but we are overspending to the tune of $14 billion every year. They are the significant figures. That fundamental problem of living beyond our means, borrowing money and selling our assets has not yet been addressed by this Government, and unfortunately there has been no real debate about it because there has been no strong criticism or constructive suggestion of an alternative from the Liberal Opposition.

Mr Howard is on record as saying just the other day that the Australian Labor Party is pinching the ideas of the Liberal Party of Australia, that it is putting the Liberal Party's policies of deregulation into effect before the Liberal Party has the opportunity of doing it itself. Only last night in the Senate I quoted a reputable academic who stated that Australia is more deregulated than any other Western economy-more than the United States of America and the United Kingdom. We carry the prize for having the most deregulated economy, but we sit back and watch the country going down the tube and overspending to the tune of $14 billion every year.

The Unite Australia Party will be putting forward an alternative approach for a more managed economy, with some innovative suggestions as to how we can work our way out of debt, how we can stop borrowing money and how we can become self-sufficient over five years. That is the challenge and that message of the alternative approach to economic management has to be put across. It is a great pity that in recent months the Australian Democrats have done very little other than support what this Government has been doing. It was in a glorious position to put pressure on the Government, to debate alternative economic approaches to the management of this country. Instead of that, it has bent over backwards to support the Government on every one of its economic initiatives. Only yesterday the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Janine Haines, said on television what a pity it is that the Democrats cannot support the Government in its dismantling of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act which apply to secondary boycotts. It shows complete disregard for small business and for the fact that small business is the cutting edge of this economy and that, unless it is given a better deal, we will never earn our way out of debt.

All these points have to be made clear to the electorate. The voters of this country, the ordinary Australians, have a very difficult choice to make. The economy is at a crossroads. The country is on the verge of bankruptcy. Who can lead the country in a new direction? Who can lead it away from the brink? It is a difficult choice because there has not been a constructive debate this time as to what alternatives face this country. I hope this debate will become clearer to the Australian people during the forthcoming election campaign. The responsibility will be fairly and squarely on their shoulders. The Democrats have thrown aside a golden opportunity to put alternatives before the Australian people. They have thrown it away in their desire to be the lapdog of the Government. It will be a very interesting, very difficult and critical time. The country is at a crossroads. I have confidence that the Australian people will exercise the common sense that they have exercised in the past and will choose a new direction for the economic management of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —What started off as a joke--
—Order! Senator Georges, do you seek leave to make a statement?
—I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a joke.

—I do not think Senator Gareth Evans was game to refuse me leave. What started off as a joke about an hour ago has now lost its humour. I think those who made this decision have misjudged the electorate. I recall a Premier of South Australia going early to the electorate to get a cheap advantage, and he lost. I recall also that Prime Minister Fraser went early to the electorate to take advantage of what he considered to be a weak opposition and a weak Leader of the Opposition, and he lost. My feeling is that the Government may lose because the electorate is a little more enlightened than some people believe. What I find extraordinary is that on the most flimsy of excuses we are now in a double dissolution situation. It is the flimsiest of excuses, because I do not think there has been very much obstruction by the Senate. If honourable senators look at the record, they will see about three occasions when the Senate decided that it ought not to pass a piece of legislation. On most occasions the Senate has passed legislation-sometimes with amendment; as much amendment by the Government as by the Opposition. The Senate cannot be accused of obstruction.

SPEECH.PARA: If rejection of the identity card legislation is put as a reason for racing to a double dissolution, that reason is not sound enough. There would need to be sounder reasons. I cannot understand why the Governor-General has consented to a double dissolution. In any case, the Government will have to bear the cost of the decision, as far as the Senate is concerned. By having a double dissolution, it will be possible for the character and representation of the Senate to change very much. As I see it, the electorate has had a gutful of what has been happening in the national Parliament.

The reputation of this Parliament has been diminished. The reputation of this Parliament is very low in the electorate. If anyone considers that the electorate does not take note of, or is not interested in what is happening here, he had better think again. People in the electorates listen to our debates. At any one time, even on the lowest audience, 6,000 or 7,000 people are listening to what is happening in this Parliament, and they are not encouraged by what has been going on in the House of Representatives. They have certainly not been encouraged by what has been going on in the Senate. The electorate will react.

We shall find that changed representation in the Senate will not suit either of the major parties. The electorate will determine that there will be people in this place who will have an independent view on what happens in the House of Representatives. They will demand it, and I will tell honourable senators why. It is because they no longer trust either party in the House of Representatives. They do not trust the emergence of the Right in the Liberal Party; and they do not trust the pragmatism of the Labor Party, which seems to be more concerned with the rights of the powerful than with the rights of the people they are supposed to represent.

The media legislation, to which we have objected and which we are endeavouring to frustrate and, I hope, will frustrate next week if we are given an opportunity, was meant to advantage certain people who have the ear of Government-I will go even further and say people who influence the Government, the Executive of the Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Those people would gain great advantage from the legislation which I had hoped this Senate would reject. The electorate knows; it will make a decision, and it will produce a result which may be the defeat of the Government.

However the real problem in the minds of people in certain sections of the electorate with which I am closely associated is that if we do not support the Government, if we do not work for the Government and the Labor Party, the alternative is horrific. That is what the electorate faces at present. It has to make a choice between a government which is in the control of the Executive, to support a party which has been hijacked by its Executive, or to support the Opposition, which is suffering the same problems. There are manoeuvrings within the Opposition by a section of the corporate sector which seeks to entrap political parties at present. The National Party of Australia is being entrapped, and it has been set up. It is in the process of being bought by very powerful people in the community who would like the Government to make decisions which suit their interests. What we have to be afraid of is those people outside this Parliament, powerful and rich people, who seek to control this Parliament by controlling a party. My objection is that the Labor Party has been entrapped by such interests.

Many people in the electorates are supporters of the Labor Party and they have been hurt by Labor and its movement away from policy. They will work for the Labor Party to ensure, if possible, that it is not defeated. In spite of their reservations, they will continue to work. I remind leaders of the Labor Party of those people who established the policy of the Party by various democratic means and expected it to be carried out. It has not been carried out. It has been denied, defied and broken, and the hearts of many Labor supporters have been broken. However, they will continue to support the Labor Party because they cannot risk what the Opposition appears to stand for. The emergence in the Opposition of extremely conservative forces is quite frightening.

Out of all this all I can say is that I am really sorry for the electorate. The choice that has been suddenly presented to it is not a choice at all. The economy is staggering, and it will further stagger under the impact of the May statement. All of a sudden an election is thrust upon us. Why? It is for the pragmatical reason only that the Opposition is in a weakened position; it is disorganised--

TALK.START.PARA: —He thinks we are.

—The Opposition is disorganised. As an Opposition, it is a disgrace. As a party organisation it does not have any good sense. If it had had any good sense, it would have got down to the task of sorting out its problems. But the Opposition's problems also happen to be the electorate's problems.
—You believe what you read in the newspapers.

—I walk around these corridors, Senator. I understand; I hear, and I know what the problems are. I know just what is going on. My office is alongside Senator Withers's office. I am not suggesting that I listen through the wall. He can hear the music that I play, but I cannot hear what he says. How do I know just what is happening? I know something is happening by the number of people who walk through his door and who those people happen to be. Not only that, but occasionally I hear the odd comment around the place. If one has been a senator long enough, one knows where to get the stories; one knows where to get the information; one knows what is likely to happen. The Opposition is in complete disarray.
—Rubbish!

—Wait a moment. That does not necessarily mean that the Government has an advantage, because when the election date was declared today it was surprising how organisations tightened. I will say this to the Government: It has a problem. The problem is explaining to the electorate what is happening to individuals in the electorate-and what the Government has done, not what the Opposition has done. The electorate votes against governments; it does not vote for Oppositions. It is too late for those who made the decision to hold an early election to reconsider now. The election is on.
—The mortgage rates are still up there.

—Senator Walters will have to do better than that. The election is on. The fact that it is a double dissolution means that the quota is 7.5. The results of that ought to be considered. One ought to consider one's personal position. It has been handed to me on a plate-7.5.
—It is 7.7.

—Yes, 7.7 people in every 100 people have to have a particular view. It could be horrific to come back. That will be decided on Saturday, incidentally. But I have gone too long, Mr President. I thank you for the opportunity to speak. I have put my views before the Senate. I think the Government has made a mistake. It has raced into this decision with great enthusiasm. I hope that it does not regret it. The reason I hope that the Government does not regret it is that, as I have said, the alternative is too horrible to contemplate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986ABORIGINAL LAND (LAKE CONDAH AND FRAMLINGHAM FOREST) BILL 1987ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE PROTECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In speaking to what has been quite an extended debate on the Aboriginal land rights package, let me begin by saying that, as was noted by Senator Chaney, this is indeed an historic day. Perhaps it is historic for a second reason as a result of the announcement of the election this afternoon, but the particular circumstance to which Senator Chaney was referring, and the one which I endorse, is that this is the twentieth anniversary of the referendum giving overwhelming approval of the Australian people for the Commonwealth Government to make special laws for Aboriginal people. So it is appropriate, therefore, that we should be debating the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986, the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Bill 1987 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill 1987, which are designed to further this Government's commitment to advance the Aboriginal cause. It does seem inappropriate that, on this day of all days, the Opposition should be so critical, in its contribution to this debate, of the Government which uses powers that were so clearly and explicitly granted to it in 1967-powers which, to the Opposition's credit, it was prepared to use in its better days.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition must now bear full responsibility for the loss of bipartisanship which is now regrettably evident in Aboriginal affairs matters. The Opposition's recently announced Aboriginal affairs policy, if it can be dignified with that description, seeks to dilute the Commonwealth's role leaving the main carriage of Aboriginal advancement with the States. Aboriginal people will note, and they certainly will not forget, the Opposition's willingness to turn back the clock, to walk away from the responsibilities that the people of Australia gave to the Commonwealth 20 years ago. We agree that the States have to be involved. We always emphasise the need for States to use their own powers to help their Aboriginal citizens and to treat them as equals. But we do not agree that, where a State will not act or cannot act because of opportunistic political obstructionism of the kind that has been evident in Victoria, the Commonwealth should only wring its hands and simply say `Too bad, fellows', to the most disadvantaged, dispossessed group of Australians.

Turning to the Bills before us, first up we have the Northern Territory Bills. The two Bills before the Senate amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. I remind the Senate that that Act has been the subject of one of the most, if not indeed the most, extensive processes of review and consultation of any piece of Commonwealth legislation. In 1983, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, who has been such a doughty fighter, requested Mr Justice Toohey, a former Aboriginal Land Commissioner and now not only a prominent Federal Court Judge but also a prominent High Court Judge, to review the Act. His report entitled `Seven Years On' was presented in December 1983.

Many of the amendments in the Bills before the Parliament flow directly from Mr Justice Toohey's proposals. In 1984 Dr Joh Altman undertook a review of the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account. Some of his proposals are picked up in the Bills, others are being implemented by administrative means, and others are still under examination. Overlaying these processes of expert review has been a most careful and painstaking process of consultation with interested parties about possible changes to the Act. The Northern Territory land councils have had the opportunity, as I can personally attest, to make frequent representations, written and oral, and they have had extensive discussions with the Caucus committee on Aboriginal affairs. The Northern Territory Government and the pastoral and mining industries have also been given many opportunities to make submissions and to meet with Ministers and officials.

Whilst there have obviously been some differences of opinion about the Act, leading in some cases to deferment of possible amendments which will need to be picked up later, there can be no doubt that it has substantially achieved the objectives for which it was created. As Mr Justice Woodward put it, land rights is `the doing of simple justice to people who have been deprived of their land without their consent and without compensation'. I think it is pertinent to recall some of the views that were expressed by members of the Opposition parties when, as the Government in 1976, they introduced the Act that we are amending tonight. Mr Viner, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, said:
The Government's proposals to recognise Aboriginal land rights in legislation is one more expression of the Government's commitment to liberal and progressive reform.
Certainly those are the sorts of words that we would no longer expect to hear from the present Opposition. Mr Viner also said:

. . . the Government believes that this Bill will allow and encourage Aborigines in the Northern Territory to give full expression to the affinity with land that characterised their traditional society and gave a unique quality to their life.
Sam Calder, the member for the Northern Territory at that time, said:

I support the introduction of land rights for Aborigines in the Northern Territory. This Bill, it is hoped, will give Northern Territory Aborigines the ability to practise their law and traditions on their own land in their own manner. This is good.

Certainly the Government can be fully bipartisan with views such as that being expressed. It is a pity that views such as that are no longer being expressed by senators on the Opposition benches today.

The amendment Bill No. 3, which I introduced into the Senate earlier this month, provides for a totally new regime for mining and exploration. There is no doubt that the present Act has caused difficulties. The new regime will provide for considerably speeded up decision processes. It will limit, but not remove, the power of Aboriginal land holders to say no to exploration and mining-a power, I remind the Senate, which was seen as basic by Mr Justice Woodward when he said that to deny Aborigines the right to control mining on their lands would be to deny the reality of their land rights. After exhaustive negotiations-again I can testify personally to that-we have come up with a package of amendments that have been accepted by the land councils and acknowledged by the mining industry and the Northern Territory Government as a significant improvement. I can assure honourable senators that that particular package of responses is pretty heroic stuff given the passions that have been swirling around this issue for so long.

The Opposition has foreshadowed amendments that would involve the scrapping of these hard won compromises. I will be saying a little more about that-I hope not too much-in the Committee stage, but I simply wanted to ask members of the Opposition: Can they assure us that these amendments are acceptable to Aborigines? Have they been discussed and agreed with the land councils? Of course not! It is arrogance of the kind that only the Opposition is capable of producing.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have all been discussed with the land councils.
—Discussed and accepted? How do the land councils react to them? Perhaps the honourable senator will tell us in the Committee stage.
—Are you governed by the consent of the people?

—Not at all. We make our own decisions but we do so on the basis of consultation and consent, where it is possible to reach it, and that is what we have achieved in this instance. We are pleased that we have been able to do it and we draw the contrast with the approach of the Opposition. The same is undoubtedly true of its approach to the first Bill which was introduced last year. Some matters have been under consideration which are not encompassed in these Bills, such as providing an estate or interest in Aboriginal land to the Northern Territory Government for the provision of essential services, and also the question of further claims on pastoral properties for which Aborigines hold the leases. I hasten to reassure the Senate that these matters have not been dropped. They have simply been held back for further consideration and negotiation. Our paramount concern, having reached a settlement on exploration and mining, was simply to ensure that there would be no further delay in implementing these much needed improvements. Of course, that is the reason why we are pressing on with these Bills tonight, notwithstanding the announcement of the election. We regard these Bills as a very high priority and we do so not only from the perspective of the Aboriginal people concerned but also the whole future of the Northern Territory and indeed Australian mining industry. There has been too much delay for too long and it has been in nobody's interests. We want to break the log jam, and these Bills will do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the Victorian Bills, I fully agree that the more preferable course would have been for Victoria to have enacted this legislation. That would have happened but for State Opposition intransigence. In this instance, the Commonwealth is essentially acting as the agent of the State, and we make no apology for it. It is odd that the Opposition should be uncomfortable at the idea of Commonwealth-State co-operation in Aboriginal affairs as its policies are in favour of it. This is just a logical extension of the Opposition's kind of approach. The Victorian Government has held extensive consultations with Aborigines in the development of the legislation. The mining industry, the scientific community and others have all had their opportunity to comment. Against that background there is no need for the Commonwealth to start again from scratch. We changed some aspects of the Victorian Bills, in consultation with the Victorians, to meet Commonwealth requirements.

To address a point made by Senator Short, a number of criticisms of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills were acknowledged by amendments moved in the House of Representatives by the Minister, Mr Holding. Senator Short also raised concerns in relation to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Amendment Bill about matters such as powers of delegation, powers of inspectors, and the interests of museums and the scientific community. I can say that the Commonwealth has looked carefully at these matters and we believe that the Bill will not raise the problems that were feared. If problems do arise we will certainly look sympathetically at suggestions for improvement.

Finally, on the question of titles to the Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest lands, the Commonwealth's preference is for Aboriginal land to be held in inalienable freehold title, as in the Northern Territory. This is what Aborigines themselves prefer. The land, to them, is not a commodity to be traded. In a real sense, as has so often been movingly said, they are the land and the land is them. They want to be sure that their land will not be lost to them a second time. However, we accept that to insist on inalienable title would, in some instances, deny Aborigines the opportunity to control their lands under some other form of secure title. I would have thought that that was an essentially sensible approach with which the Opposition could have no quarrel. It will, of course, have a quarrel with that and all sorts of other things but, no doubt, we will hear more about that, mercifully at lesser length than was the case in the second reading stage, in the Committee stage. With that set of comments, I commend the package of four Bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
