TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise three items with regard to this legislation. The first two are continuing concerns of the Central and Northern land councils about items in the legislation. The first is that there is no requirement on a miner to submit a proposal containing proposed terms of payment, pursuant to proposed new paragraph 46 (1) (a) and, secondly, there is no provision for ministerial extension of the negotiating time pursuant to proposed section 46 (3). As I understand it, the land councils have already made submissions to the Government with regard to both these items and I would be interested in the Government's response to the propositions that have been put.

SPEECH.PARA: In brief, the argument that the land councils have raised with regard to proposed paragraph 46 (1) (a) is that there is no requirement for a proposal to be submitted by a miner in respect of proposed payments. However, a miner must submit a proposal at the exploration stage. The view of the land councils is that the payment proposals are even more important at the mining stage, although they remain obviously important at the exploration stage. In their request, the land councils have proposed that such payment proposals should be submitted at both the exploration and the mining stages. The argument here is that at the mining stage a commercial negotiation is taking place and, by definition, such a proposal should be submitted at some stage. To avoid a forced arbitration at the mining stage, it seems reasonable that the proposal be required of the miner at the very outset.

The second concern of the land councils relates to proposed sub-section 46(3). The land councils have already requested a change to this provision to allow for ministerial extension of the negotiating period at the mining stage. There is currently no provision to extend the period referred to in the section. Mining negotiations will necessarily be complex and time consuming. There will need to be substantial consultations with traditional owners. There is a real possibility of land councils not being able to perform their functions within 12 months, despite their best endeavours. There has been some discussion in both the second reading stage and the Committee stage which I believe sought to show the land councils in a less than favourable light. I think it shows an abysmal ignorance of what the land councils have been doing in that period and merely makes some suggestions of bad faith. If one takes the time and trouble to look at what the land councils have done with regard to each and every negotiation on mining, it is fairly obvious that they have carried out the requirements of them under the Act and the requirements of them from the traditional owners to represent their best interests. It seems to me to be a very odd proposition that many people seem to be advancing that in some way the land councils ought to have been compelled to neglect the interest of the traditional owners whom they are legally and legislatively required to represent.

With regard to the problem that the land councils might have in meeting that 12-month deadline, the mining companies may very well not agree to an extension of time in such circumstances and hence force an arbitration. There could be no abuse of the ministerial extension provision because it would be a matter for the exercise of a discretion. It could not therefore be used by land councils for commercial purposes. The land councils have suggested that in their opinion the combined effect of the absence of the two provisions under discussion is potentially serious. There could well be delays and difficulties in negotiating a mining agreement where there is no requirement for a payment proposal to be put and where there is no provision for a ministerial extension of the negotiating period. They therefore see that real prospects of negotiations are being frustrated for these reasons.

A miner is not required to put a financial proposal pursuant to proposed paragraph 46(1) (a) and a land council cannot apply for an extension of the negotiating period, but then there is the risk of the mining negotiations breaking down. If a payment proposal is not put in time for the full consultations and negotiations and a mining company wants, for its own reasons, an arbitrated and not a negotiated mining agreement, it could easily force this result knowing that a land council could not get further time to negotiate. They seem to me to be serious problems that are currently in front of us, and I would be very interested in the Government's response to both of them, particularly to the latter one with regard to the possible exploitation by mining companies of provisions contained in this Bill.

The third item that I wish to raise concerns proposed sub-sections 41(3), 42(14), 47(2) and 47(4) which were mentioned by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills with regard to the non-reviewable decisions in clause 5. In each of the cases that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee looked at it noted that the Minister had a broad discretion. While seeing that this was appropriate, it drew attention to the fact that no provision is to be made for the review of the decisions on their merits. The Government has adopted a range of proposals of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and I commend it for that. I commend both items that came forward from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, but I would be interested in the Government's response on that last point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you moved a form of words for the first of those two?
—No.
—No, no amendment is being moved.
—No amendment; I was just raising the point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not ill-disposed toward accepting the first of those amendments as to proposed paragraph 46 (1) (a). It was certainly discussed between me and the land councils. I took the view at that time that since under one of the relevant provisions, proposed sub-section 46 (18), the final agreement had to contain terms and conditions relating to payment, it was so obviously implicit in the whole structure of the proposed sub-section that a proposal had to be forthcoming on terms and conditions as to payment that it was hardly necessary to spell it out. There did not seem to be a need to require a proposal to be put if there had to be something in the final agreement. The amendment that came forward finally from the land council arrived after the final deadline that we had set for the conclusion of these discussions. Since it did not seem to be strictly necessary, I was not prepared to re-open consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The further point that has been made to me in a telex, as it has now been made to Senator Macklin, is that if the miner can delay the submission of a proposal until well into the negotiating period he might, for all practical purposes, be able to reduce the time. I do not believe it would be in the interests of any sensible miner to do that. Notwithstanding that, there may nonetheless be some point in inserting a provision, perhaps as 46 (1) (a) (xiii), in the following terms: `Terms and conditions relating to payment'. If Senator Macklin were to formally move something in those terms, I would be disposed to accept it for the reasons he has articulated. I do not believe it takes anything away from the legislation, for reasons I have explained, and it may just add something of utility to the bargaining process. I believe we can accommodate that.

However, I am not disposed to accommodate the second matter in issue, which is the argument that there should be some capacity for extending the 12-month period at the mining stage. The Government thought about this a lot and certainly discussed it with the land councils. We have made the point that the 12-month period is extendable by agreement. We have also made the point that, where there is no agreement after a matter has been holding fire for 12 months in this context, it is really about time the thing went to arbitration and got itself resolved. One of the big problems about getting mining activity going in the Northern Territory is the way in which negotiations have stalemated for endless periods, with one or other of the parties taking advantage of all sorts of legislative opportunities to extend the period. While I am not suggesting that Ministers would exercise their discretion other than sensibly-certainly not Ministers from this side of the House-there is an element of difficulty that can arise in these situations if too many avenues are available for extension.

The distinction is to be drawn between negotiations at the mining stage and those at the exploration stage. Many more matters will require resolution at the exploration stage than at the mining stage for the simple reason that the rule of thumb is that 100 exploration activities take place for every successful venture that is set running as a result of those explorations. Therefore, one can expect the ratio of exploration negotiations to mining negotiations to be roughly of the order of 100 to 1. It might be a bit better than that in the Northern Territory because that is such a highly prospective area for minerals, but we are talking about many fewer negotiations, negotiations that arise only after some years of exploration activity and some years of exposure of the people concerned to the issues involved in a mining presence. It will not come out of the blue.

The further particular reason for giving ministerial discretion to extend at the exploration stage was the obvious necessity for a transitional period in the operation of this legislation rather than the land councils, the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy, and possibly the Minister, being flooded simultaneously with an absolute mass of outstanding exploration applications. It was necessary to prioritise those areas to identify those of high priority, those of lower priority and so on. Accordingly, it was felt necessary to give a generalised discretion to the Minister to set time limits to enable us to get through that transition period. That is probably the major reason why the ministerial discretion to extend is there at the exploration stage. It is not because it is felt likely that there will be any particular need to use it in particular cases very often; it is more because of that transitional factor.

The other reason for the ministerial discretion possibly coming into play is that with the time for consent and the time for negotiation of exploration terms and conditions being coterminous at the exploration stage, difficulties may arise particularly when dealing with situations in which people are confronting exploration of mining issues for the first time. We may need an agency, such as a Minister, acting as a traffic policeman to set periods within which these issues can be resolved. We anticipate none of those things being the case at the mining stage. There will be many fewer such instances. The parties should be much better prepared. The 12 months should enable the hard-headed commercial negotiations about which we are talking to take place. If they do not produce a result within that time frame, we believe it is appropriate that they go to a judge of the Federal Court of Australia for arbitration.

As to the matters raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in the Alert Digest, I do not think a final report has yet been brought down dealing with this matter following the ministerial reply. I think the best way in which I can deal with those criticisms is simply to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the terms of my letter in reply to the Committee, which took up, one by one, the points that have been raised about extended ministerial discretions, unreviewability and so on, and explain the particular policy context in which these--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the non-reviewability one that I was interested in.
—If I can find, in all the morass around me, the terms of my reply, which I very carefully penned, I will seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard. The debate can be picked up later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his response, particularly on the first item regarding the proposed terms of payment. If I heard the Minister correctly, he would be willing to accept an amendment which would simply insert as sub-paragraph 46 (1) (a) (xiii) the words `terms and conditions', which I think was the phrase the Minister used.
—`Terms and conditions relating to payment'.
—The words `terms and conditions relating to payment' would certainly satisfactorily address that issue. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 11, clause 5, after proposed sub-paragraph 46 (1) (a) (xii), insert the following word and paragraph `and (xiii) terms and conditions relating to payment.'.
I must admit that I am still concerned about the whole legislation.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman, for working that out so expeditiously. My unease with regard to the Minister's statement probably applies to the whole legislation. I must admit that, after the Minister's meeting with the traditional owners, any opposition we may have had to the Bill obviously was no longer sensible since the propositions had been accepted by the traditional owners and agreed to by them. They have a perfect right to undertake that type of activity. Nevertheless, I must admit that I still have some unease about moving back in any way from the strong position of a veto being available to Aboriginal people over their land. I am reminded particularly of the various royal commissions and other commissions of inquiry, such as the Seaman Aboriginal Land Inquiry, which pointed very strongly and very forcibly to the fact that recovery of land is sensible only in the context of total control of that land. It is a proposition that I support very strongly and hence I have unease about any propositions to put more pressure on the traditional owners to come to an accommodation with a mining company when they may not necessarily wish to come to an accommodation with the mining company, at least not in a time frame. But the agreement has been made and in that context it must stand.

SPEECH.PARA: I am still worried that a mining company in these circumstances may wish not to consult with land councils. I am not simply suggesting some ill will on the part of mining companies; I am pointing to the deplorable history of mining companies negotiating with the Aboriginal people. A comparison of the way that mining companies in Australia have carried on negotiations with Aboriginal owners with the way that mining companies have operated in the United States of America and Canada shows fairly clearly that there is an unwillingness on the part of many mining companies in this country even to accept that the Aboriginal people own and control their land and must be a party to negotiations.

I still have some concern that a company may wish to extend the 12-month period to force an arbitration. I would have thought that ministerial discretion could not be used in any way by either the mining companies or the Aboriginal people-the traditional owners or the land councils-but that the discretion of the Minister could be applied in such a way as to make sure that meaningful negotiations, rather than a forced arbitration, took place. It is fairly obvious that the Government is not willing to proceed down that line; but I still admit that to me it would be sensible for the Government to have that element which would make sure that both parties entered into meaningful negotiations and did not simply wait around for arbitration from which they thought they may receive an advantage.

The last point-I hope the Minister has managed to find among the morass of his documents the point that I am interested in-is the item dealing with the avenue of review which would be available, as I mentioned before, with regard to sub-sections 41 (3), 42 (14) and 47 (2) and 47 (4) relating to non-reviewable decisions. The only possibility of review would be with regard to the legality of the decisions pursuant to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, which is strictly limited in its application. One way of getting around this, as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggested, is the addition of the words `on reasonable grounds'. The Committee stated that the addition of the words `on reasonable grounds':

. . . restricts the discretion afforded the Minister and, in the view of the Committee, makes review pursuant to the Administrative Decision (Judicial Review) Act a sufficient avenue of review since it will be possible in an application pursuant to the Act to go behind the Minister's reasons for holding that, for example, the public interest required the making of a further application for an exploration licence in order to test whether the Minister had reasonable grounds for holding that view.

The small addition of the words `on reasonable grounds', as suggested by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, would be one way out. It is a simple drafting change and would bring these sections into keeping with other parts of the Act. Paragraph 48 (3) (c) of the Bill states that the Minister, after consultation with the Commonwealth Minister for Resources and Energy, who is the Minister in the chamber at the moment, and the Northern Territory mining Minister shall authorise the making of a further application for the grant of an exploration licence if the Minister is satisfied `on reasonable grounds' of a certain matter. So the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's suggestion is incorporated, and including the words `on reasonable grounds' at other points in the Bill makes eminent sense and would address the issue sufficiently. That is the area of my concern. The other points certainly bear weight. The Minister has addressed a large number of them in some of the amendments which have already been moved to this Bill. This item is the only major item left over from the scrutiny that I think needs some clarification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now found the response I made to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I do not know whether Senator Macklin has seen it.
—I have not seen it.

—I will settle for incorporating it in Hansard and leaving it at that. I am not sure whether it is the best possible formulation now that I look at it. The point can perhaps be more strenuously made about the need for expedition, the inevitability of judgmental decisions having to be made at the margin and the desirability of the process not being side-tracked into the formidable jungle of legal technicalities which, regrettably, the administrative review processes tended to become in this area. That in short states the reasons we believed, and I honestly believe, that the provisions here, which have been reached after very intensive consultation-they do not represent nirvana or the millennium so far as the Northern Territory Government or the miners are concerned-will work in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible-I say this as someone who has been a fairly passionate supporter, as Senator Macklin will know, of administrative review over the years-to overburden legislation of this kind with reviewability. The particular discretions that have been vested in the Minister have been carefully chosen. They are limited in scope and content and will, I believe, be applied only in those circumstances where there is, inevitably, a highly discretionary judgmental character involved of a kind that is best left to the Minister to make in all the circumstances of the case without exposing the whole thing to a further layer of review. Against that background I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of my reply, although I do not claim authorship of it with as much pride as I might usually do, as I look at it now. But I think it is good enough to satisfy Senator Macklin tonight and, as such, I am happy to leave the debate at that.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1987
Bill Alert Digest No. 8 of 1987 draws attention to four sub-sections providing for non reviewable decisions, viz 41 (3), 42 (14) and 47 (2) and (4).

In the cases of 41 (3) and 42 (14) the nature of the decision is a ministerial discretion to grant an extension of an otherwise fixed time for completion of an action; in the first instance, by the applicant for access to explore and, possibly, mine; in the second instance, by the Land Council undertaking negotiations on such an application. In each case the potential for difference of interests would most likely rest between the principal parties to the question. The Minister is required in each case to consult first with the Northern Territory Mining Minister.

These provisions were drafted in close consultation with the Land Councils and with the mining industry through the Australian Mining Industry Council. It has been recognised by all parties that the granting of an extension of time in these circumstances is essentially a political decision, most appropriately taken by the Minister with provision for review as to the legality of the decision only and not the merits.

The Ministerial discretions under sub-sections 47 (2) and 47 (4) relate respectively to the cancellation of the exploration licence and the refusal to grant, or the cancellation of, the mining interest. In these instances also, the Minister is required to make a decision concerning an essentially political matter, viz the likelihood that the exploration undertaken or proposed, or the mining works proposed, would be other than in accordance with the proposed program to the extent that the Land Council would not have consented to the grant of the licence. If the Minister so decides he must decide further that the national interest does not require that the works should proceed. The consequential cancellation of the exploration licence under s. 47 (6), or the non-granting or cancellation of the mining interest under s. 47 (7), therefore depends on two conditions, the merits of which are most appropriately assessed by the Minister and would not be appropriate to determination by a tribunal.

Alert Digest No. 8 draws attention to the reviewability on grounds of merit and legality of decisions to be taken under 48 (3) (c). Such a decision is to be taken by the Minister after consultation with the Commonwealth Minister for mineral resources matters and the Northern Territory Mining Minister upon the application of the Land Council and without detriment to the original applicant for consent to the grant of an exploration licence. The granting of consent, as a subject of appeal, would be of interest principally to a third party. The greater degree of transparency and scope for review in this instance is appropriate where substantial interest may rest with persons not privy to the primary negotiations behind the issue (i.e. the Land Council and the original applicant).
GARETH EVANS...May 1987
Minister for Resources and Energy
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1986, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek this opportunity to table a revised explanatory memorandum to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill and an explanatory memorandum to the amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move together the Government amendments circulated in my name in respect of which I earlier tabled an explanatory memorandum. I do not believe that there is anything controversial about them.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, line 9, leave out ``subsection (2)'', substitute ``this section''.
(2) Page 1, clause 2, after subsection (1) insert the following subsection:

``(1a) Paragraph 23 (1) (ea) and subsection 50 (2d) and (2e) of the Principal Act inserted by this Act, and section 34, shall come into operation on a day, or on respective days, to be fixed by Proclamation.''.
(3) Page 5, clause 7, lines 23 and 24, leave out ``referred to in subsection 50 (2e)'', substitute ``to which subsection 50 (2e) applies''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer briefly to the Government amendments that have just been circulated. The first appears to be quite in order. However, I would like some explanation regarding the second amendment. As I see it, it allows the proclamation of sub-sections 50 (2d) and 50 (2e) to be delayed indefinitely. These sub-sections relate to the new stock routes provisions. I ask the Minister: Can he make clear the reasons for the amendment and why will there be a delay in the introduction of the sub-sections?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a bit of a history to this exercise with which I am not entirely familiar. But as I understand, it bears basically upon the felt need to wait upon the outcome of the legal challenge which has been made to the Maurice decision in the Ti Tree land claim which, as I recall, held that stock routes were to be regarded as roads for the purpose of the proper construction of this legislation. As such, this made unavailable for claim quite a large chunk, if not all, of the Northern Territory stock routes.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the uncertainty as to the precise legal status of the stock routes, the Government has felt it appropriate to enable specifically the deferral of the proclamation of these clauses. There will need to be a further amending Bill, at some stage later this year or early next year, picking up some of these matters which are still not fully resolved, such as essential services and pastoral conversions, which in the rush of events were omitted from this legislation. To the extent that there are any outstanding questions relating to stock routes, it is proposed that they be picked up at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has forecast that a Bill will be introduced later, no doubt in the new Parliament as we have an election before us. As a lot of it will relate to the pastoral industry, I ask what consultations will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) be having before the Bill is introduced-although, of course, one expects that those opposite by then would be in opposition so they would not be introducing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have heaps of consultations and we will continue the process that has been going on for some considerable time. I thank the honourable senator for his acknowledgment of the realities of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments that have been circulated on behalf of the Opposition would overcome a number of the deficiencies which the Opposition has identified in the Government's legislation. It is claimed by the Minister that the Bill that is before the Committee would provide an answer to the problems created by the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. However, in speaking to the Opposition's amendments I will outline briefly those aspects of the Government's Bill which warrant modification or outright opposition. The first Opposition amendment, which has been circulated on a single sheet of paper, relates to clause 11 of the Bill. This amendment would ensure that rents paid to the Northern Territory Government by the holders of a mining interest on Aboriginal land would not have to be in turn paid back to the land council by the Northern Territory Government. I believe that this is a reasonable amendment. I would like to draw the Minister's attention to it. The Government's clause 11 purports to have this effect. However, the Government's amendment only refers to fees for services paid by the holder of a mining interest, not to rentals. I refer the Minister to page 11, paragraph 18 of the explanatory notes which relate to this matter. The explanatory notes refer to rents, but later fees for services are referred to. I think that matter should be cleared up. The amendment I am proposing would make it quite clear that rentals paid to the Northern Territory would not be repayable to the land councils under the land rights Act.

—Clause 11 as it presently stands seeks to ensure that the Northern Territory Government does not have to pay to land councils equivalents of payments it receives in respect of fees for services provided under Northern Territory mining legislation. The Opposition amendment would, as I understand it-I am not sure that I understand it at all-have a similar effect, but seeks to extend the non-payment provision to rents received. I am advised that this is not necessary as rents are paid directly to the land councils and not to the Northern Territory Government. The Government amendment reflects a specific recommendation by Mr Justice Toohey, and under those circumstances we insist on our amendment.
—Senator Kilgariff, do you wish to move your amendment to clause 11? You have not actually done so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I note the Minister's advice relating to clause 11. I will heed his advice. I hope that it is correct. I turn to clause 12. The Opposition opposes this clause in relation to dealings with interests in land by land trusts. The amendments proposed by the Minister provide that land trusts, with the approval of the Minister and at the direction of the relevant land council, can grant an estate of interest in land vested in the land trust. The provisions governing the granting of interests or estates in Aboriginal land are a very sore point in the Northern Territory. It is disappointing to see again that the Territory's right to have access to and across Aboriginal land for the provision of essential services has been ignored. My proposed new clause 12a would enable the Northern Territory to gain access to Aboriginal land for the provision of these services. Where the Northern Territory Government has been refused access by a land council, it will be able to apply to the Minister to have the matter dealt with by arbitration. That is very reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: Essential services provided for in this new clause include the provision of power, water, sewerage, communications, railways, boat landings, airstrips, health and education facilities, roads and accommodation for government employees. I referred earlier in the second reading debate to the outrageous claims that have been made by a number of Aboriginal groups when the Northern Territory has attempted to provide services on Aboriginal land for the people. There have been claims for rent for the land on which Housing Commission houses have been built for Aboriginal people, claims for compensation for gravel used to build roads to Aboriginal settlements, et cetera. I have given many illustrations, but the illustration I now wish to give relates to the Beswick water supply which the Northern Territory wished to upgrade in response to a request from the Beswick community. The Northern Land Council, acting on behalf of the Beswick traditional owners, demanded over a protracted period that the Northern Territory enter into a licence agreement at its cost. The then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory responded that the Northern Territory would not be held to ransom in pursuit of its responsibilities to provide essential services to Aboriginal communities. Ultimately, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs encouraged the NLC to accept the Northern Territory's point of view and eventually it was agreed that the water service would be upgraded without a licence agreement. However, cases such as Beswick can be repeated because of the failure of the Minister to provide a legislative remedy. The amendment which the Opposition proposes would provide such a remedy.

I indicated to the Minister earlier that I am taking all the Opposition's amendments as a package. The Opposition is not moving an amendment to clause 13 but I take this opportunity to register our opposition to the clause which deals with the functions of the land councils. I question the need for the new functions land councils are to perform in assisting Aboriginals to take measures to protect sacred sites in the areas of the land councils, whether or not it is Aboriginal land. How much more will this cost and what land council resources will be diverted to this function? My final question to the Minister is: Is it necessary? I believe that the answer is clearly no. Comprehensive and effective legislation is already in place on the statute books of both the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth to protect Aboriginal sacred sites. I can only assume that this provision has been thrown in for good measure by the Minister at the behest of the land councils in return for the supposed concession that is alleged to have been given in relation to mining on Aboriginal land. It is an unnecessary and potentially divisive provision and the Opposition objects to it on that basis.

Similarly, while the Opposition proposes no amendment to clause 16, I register our protest at the effect of the clause. It removes the obligation of land councils to compile registers of traditional Aboriginal owners of land-one of the most important and fundamental functions which land councils were intended to carry out. I believe it is quite outrageous that when the Federal Government is giving the land councils additional unnecessary powers-and there are many Aboriginal people who believe this-such as those contained in clause 13 relating to sacred sites, it is making it possible for land councils to opt out of carrying out the very necessary tasks for which they were established. As I see the problem, it now means that the land councils can take short cuts.

Surely the Minister must recognise the potential for legal and administrative problems if the register of traditional owners is allowed to deteriorate. How is it proposed that those who want to identify the traditional owners of land, such as mining companies or other commercial interests, let alone the Aboriginal people themselves will go about this, where there is an argument over land? I find it quite difficult to understand how the Land Commissioner will operate if he does not have before him a comprehensive register of traditional owners. Over the years we have seen the necessity for having such a register. Now it will be thrown out the window. It is my understanding that the reason for the abandonment of the register of traditional owners is that it has not been properly compiled and maintained and is in a shambles. If that is the case I would have thought that the proper course would have been to rectify the situation rather than the Minister allowing the land councils to wash their hands of the problem completely. I believe that the government has a responsibility to the traditional owners and the Aboriginal people. I believe that the register is essential and it should not be thrown out. This amendment is an admission of the failure of the land councils to carry out one of their primary and most critical functions. It is a most retrograde step and the Opposition is strongly opposed to its implementation.

I move to the Opposition's fifth amendment on the consolidated list of amendments which we have circulated. I seek leave at this point to amend the amendment, which contains a drafting error. It should read:
. . . `or the provisions of the Trustee Act 1979 of the Northern Territory as amended from time to time'.
At present it reads:
`and the provisions . . .'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Are you seeking to change the word `and' to `or'?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly this amendment means that moneys would be able to be invested by land trusts in accordance with the Northern Territory Trustee Act 1979 instead of the more conservative and restrictive provisions of the Audit Act 1901, a Commonwealth statute. Both the Audit Act and the Trustee Act govern the way in which trustees may invest on behalf of their beneficiaries. Both have strict requirements to ensure the protection of beneficiaries under a trust. However, the Northern Territory Trust Act permits investment in a broader range of property, including real estate, and of course shares, banks, et cetera. This amendment will simply give land trusts a broader range of investments in which Aboriginal trust fund money could be invested, and it will mean that Aboriginal trustees would have the same option and protection afforded to other Northern Territories trustees by the Trustee Act of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The next clause to which the Opposition proposes amendments is clause 25. We have moved three amendments listed as numbers (6), (7) and (8). The Opposition takes the view that the amendments proposed by the Government in this clause should be opposed. They will, among other things, allow land claims to continue under the Act for a period of ten years and allow land commissioners to continue to hear claims in relation to public purpose land, including stock routes and reserves. The first of these three Opposition amendments is to amend the time allowed for further claims from the 10 years proposed to 12 months, and the second and third are to prevent claims upon public purpose land, including stock routes and stock reserves. I do not think I need to go into this any more as I think I covered it quite amply during the debate on the second reading speech.

On the first amendment, which is to reduce the period during which further claims may be made to 12 months, the point must be made that already there have been 11 years during which traditional owners of Aboriginal land have been able to lodge with the Land Commissioner claim to that land. During this time almost 50 per cent of the land mass of the Northern Territory has been claimed. To allow a further 10 years can be described only as an abrogation of the responsibility of the Minister to bring the claim process to a close. It lets the Minister off the hook. Surely one year is sufficient, instead of another 10 years, which I think makes it something like 21 years, when 50 per cent of the Territory has been claimed or is under claim now.

The other aspect of the amendments which I am proposing to clause 25 is the inclusion of an alternative sub-section 2d to section 50 of the principal Act. The sub-section which I am proposing would establish that where a claim to land is made to the Commissioner, after the commencement of the sub-section, where the land claimed or part of the land claim was reserved, dedicated or otherwise set aside as either a stock route or a stock reserve or for a public purpose, the Commissioner would not be able to hear an application in relation to the land. I will deal first with the need for the protection of stock routes and reserves. I made mention in my speech during the second reading stage of the way in which the stock route system in the Territory has been fragmented by the land rights Act. That the Federal Government has allowed this to occur is a testament to its irresponsible attitude towards the pastoral industry in the outback. The Commonwealth Government is the only government in this country which has adopted a policy of breaking down an existing stock route network within its jurisdiction. This is in stark contrast to the positive efforts that State governments are putting into protecting the stock routes within their States.

The Minister has made a lot of the amendment that he states will limit claims on stock routes to those where claims have already been lodged and future claims where the particular route or reserve claimed is entirely within the total area of land under claim. However, the Minister does reserve unto himself the right to intervene in the case of other stock routes or reserves where there is a dispute and no agreement can be reached between pastoralists and Aboriginal claimants. In such a case the Minister is able to designate the land in dispute as claimable under the Act.

So the Minister has given the pastoral industry absolutely nothing. The amendment the Minister proposes purports to limit claims on stock routes and reserves but it is clear that it does not. The pastoral industry in the Territory is quite justified in being disappointed with this effort. It had been given to understand by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that, in return for the impressive progress that has been made in granting excisions from pastoral leases to Aboriginal people for community living areas, there would be an end to claims under the land rights Act to stock reserves and stock routes. The progress of the Territory and the pastoral industry, although impressive in its own right, is phenomenal when it is contrasted with the progress of land claims under the land rights Act.

The Territory Aboriginal excisions program has been under way only since May 1985 and in the two years to May 1987 the statistics show that, of 118 applications or expressions of interest, only two have been rejected; 13 titles have been registered; seven offers have been accepted and are awaiting final processing; and another five offers have been made with negotiations complete. In addition, negotiations are proceeding on another 27 applications. There have been 30 expressions of interest about which more information is being sought from the land councils or the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and at the bottom of the list, and given a lower priority, are 34 expressions of interest for which no details have been supplied.

The 13 titles registered, the seven other offers accepted and the five offers made represent a very substantial achievement. I venture to suggest that if these pieces of land had been claimed under the land rights Act the debate would still be raging, in some cases, five to 10 years down the track. Yet, in spite of the proven commitment of the Northern Territory pastoral industry to recognising and accommodating Aboriginal people with a rightful claim to certain areas on pastoral leases, the Minister is still retaining the big stick. The pastoralists and the Territory Government have kept their end of the bargain-the Commonwealth has not. The amendments I am proposing would prevent further claims on stock routes and reserves that have been dedicated or set aside as such.

For the purposes of this legislation land is said to be reserved, dedicated or set aside for a public purpose if the purpose is related to health, education, community development, fire prevention and control, quarantine, energy supply and conservation and a range of other matters specified in Regulation 4 of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Regulations. In no other part of Australia would a situation such as has arisen in relation to Tennant Creek-where the town's water supply forms part of the subject of a land claim-be tolerated. This is another of the elements of the present land rights regime which have created friction within the Territory community and which must be addressed. As the Minister has not made any attempt to do so, I shall move an amendment in this respect.

Finally, although the Opposition has no further amendments, I take this opportunity to voice our opposition to the Government's clause 32. This clause represents yet another fetter on the Northern Territory in carrying out its responsibilities to the Territory community. It provides that, once land is the subject of a land claim, any alienation of that land by the Crown will be invalid, so the status of the land the subject of a claim is frozen. This will severely impede the Northern Territory Government in planning community, educational, health, housing and other facilities for the people of the Territory.

The amendment discriminates against Territorians in effectively preventing Crown land from being set aside for public purposes for the duration of a land claim-which may, incidentally, run for 10 years or more, if experience is anything to go by. No State government in Australia would tolerate having its resource planning disrupted in such a way; the Territory should not be expected to tolerate it either. I seek leave to move amendments (1) to (9) together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond briefly on behalf of the Government and indicate why, despite Senator Kilgariff's manful efforts to persuade us about these various amendments and opposition to particular clauses, we do not agree with him. The first matter was the opposition to clause 12. Essentially, this is concerned with administrative tidying up. Much of it is based on the Toohey report on the Review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. Nobody else in the Northern Territory Government or in the land councils, or anyone else, seems to have bothered with the clause. We had some difficulty until Senator Kilgariff rose in understanding the Opposition's attitude. We are a little the wiser after having heard him address some perceived difficulties in clause 12. We are not sufficiently moved by what he said, however, to change any of it or to delete it at this stage, but it is the sort of thing that we indicate a willingness to keep under review. In the context of further legislation that will need to come forward later this year or early next year we will certainly have a close look at what Senator Kilgariff has said about those particular matters and make any necessary remedial amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: As to his proposed insertion of new clause 19a about grants for essential services, this is one of the provisions postponed for further consideration, as I indicated before, as a result of the Government's wish to press ahead with other agreed amendments. That is not to say that we do not acknowledge some force in what Senator Kilgariff has said. We find it rather difficult to understand the opposition to clause 13. Firstly, the clause validates the land council's role of assisting in the taking of measures likely to assist in the protection of sacred sites. As we see it that does not provide the land council with any direct powers at all. Secondly, the clause validates the land council's role of assisting the traditional owners to undertake commercial activities. It does not provide the land council with any powers to undertake commercial activities in its own right. Otherwise, the clause merely makes minor administrative changes and as such would seem unexceptionable.

Deletion of clause 16 would retain the requirement for a register of traditional owners against Toohey's expressed recommendation that this be made optional. We should now say His Honour Mr Justice Toohey of the High Court of Australia, but I am sure he will not mind the shorthand. He found that there are major practical difficulties in requiring a register to be kept under this particular clause. Abolishing that requirement acknowledges that difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you going to get around the problem if we do not have a register in recognising the true traditional owner? There can be a contest between Aboriginal people.

—I am sure that there has been so much subtlety and ingenuity shown so far in making the system work in the Northern Territory that the need to put together a list of traditional owners for a particular claim, which still must be the case, will still be satisfied but without the practical difficulty of maintaining a register on an ongoing basis. I am not sure whether that is a completely satisfactory answer, but if there are any difficulties that manifest themselves in the period ahead, this is another issue which I am sure the Minister will be willing to take up in his or her further review of the legislation that will take place later on.

SPEECH.PARA: As to amendment (5), the proposed change of words to clause 21, the requirement that moneys held in trust be invested in accordance with section 62b of the Audit Act is standard in Commonwealth legislation. We see no need to extend that provision by including the Northern Territory Trustee Act in its coverage. The amendment to clause 25 would have the effect of shortening the sunset clause for lodgment of claims from 10 years to 12 months. We take the view that the present provision is reasonable, not least when one compares it against the open-ended alternative that was sought by the land councils. There have been a number of changes in the regime under which applications are made and we see a reasonably extended further period as appropriate. I think the point has to be made that the days of land claims are very largely over in the Northern Territory. Most claims with any credibility that are going to be made have already been made, although not all those claims have been adjudicated upon. The real emphasis will now shift to mineral activity on the land thus awarded. I think that as a practical matter this is unlikely to be a significant factor.

The proposed omission of new subsection 50 (2b) would remove the provision for repeat claims to be heard, subject to a land commissioner being satisfied that there are sufficient reasons for a re-hearing. We see this present provision as being reasonable. I can say no more about that.

As to the proposal to replace proposed subsections 50 (2d) and 50 (2e) in clause 25, the effect of this would be to reinsert the non-claimability of public purpose land. As I have said a couple of times before, this is one of the deferred provisions in the Government's proposals and its absence from this Bill does not mean that we do not acknowledge the need for some such provision, and that matter will be addressed later.

Finally, the Opposition opposes clause 32. We do not; we want to retain it. This clause provides for estates and interests in land not to be granted while the land is subject to traditional land claims. This is a Toohey proposal and, as such, and because of its intrinsic merits, we believe it ought to be accepted. That is a rather quick resume of the basic Government responses to those amendments. I know that not all those responses will satisfy Senator Kilgariff, but I hope he appreciates that there is a willingness on the part of the Government to make this legislation work. We will be keeping it under close review to ensure that that is in fact the case.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Kilgariff's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the closing stages of the debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986. I will make a few brief comments about the desirability of persisting with the inalienable freehold concept. Already, Mr Justice Woodward has raised the question of whether the manner and extent of claims made under the land rights Act might not have exceeded what is advisable to serve Aboriginal interests. Mr Justice Woodward, the architect of the land rights Act, has even gone so far as to suggest that Aboriginal people should consider handing back some of the land which they have claimed. One wonders how, even if they wanted to, they could do this, given that Aboriginal land granted under the land rights Act is granted as inalienable freehold land. The idea behind granting land under inalienable freehold title is one which does not sit entirely comfortably with the notion of giving Aboriginal people control of and responsibility for their own future. Inalienable freehold title does not permit the holder of that title to deal with his or her land freely. The land cannot be sold or subdivided and then sold. The granting of other interests in the land is also prohibited.

SPEECH.PARA: The idea behind inalienable freehold title was that it would protect Aboriginal landholdings from being sold off or dissipated to the detriment of future generations of Aboriginal people, which is a good concept. However, difficulties have emerged from the inalienable freehold concept. Because of its inalienability, the land is not as valuable as security as it might be if a potential mortgagee could rely on forfeiture of the land in the event of a default on a mortgage. This severely limits the ability of traditional owners to raise finance to improve their landholdings or to set up business enterprises. The limitations imposed by the inalienable landholding form pose a legitimate problem for Aboriginal people, and it should be given wide consideration in the future. I urge debate on the establishment or development of some other form of landholding which is more flexible but still allows considerable protection of Aboriginal land for future generations. It is a matter for consideration not just by the Parliament but also by those in the legal profession, and I invite them to put their minds to this problem.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 17 to 22, Part V, line 19 (page 17) to line 11 (page 22), leave out the Part, insert the following Part:
``PART V-MINING
Interpretation
``30. A reference in this Part to a mining tenement includes, where the context so requires, a reference to the land to which the mining tenement relates.
Grant of mining tenements
``31. (1) Subject to this Act, a mining tenement may be granted in relation to the relevant land under a law of Victoria relating to mining for minerals.

``(2) A mining tenement shall not be granted in relation to the relevant land unless the applicant for the mining tenement has first entered into an agreement in writing with the Corporation relating to:
(a) the compensation to be paid on the granting of the mining tenement;
(b) the guidelines to be adopted after the granting of the mining tenement in relation to the identification and protection of sacred sites; and
(c) the employment opportunities to be offered to Aboriginals in the operations to be conducted under the mining tenement.
Agreement provisions
``32. (1) An agreement referred to in section 31:
(a) shall make provision for the distribution of monies paid to the Corporation under the agreement to or for the benefit of such traditional owners as are specified in the agreement;

(b) may make provision for the applicant for the mining tenement to lodge with the Corporation a security in such form, for such amount and from such person as the Corporation thinks fit, to secure the applicant's compliance with the conditions referred to in section 37;

(c) may make provision for a process of arbitration, in accordance with a law of Victoria relating to commercial arbitration, to determine disputes relating to compliance with the conditions referred to in section 37 and failing such provision in the agreement, the parties to the agreement shall be deemed to have agreed to the appointment by the Minister of a Mining Commissioner as the arbitrator in respect of such disputes; and

(d) may provide that where a condition referred to in section 37 requires the holder of the mining tenement to do anything in relation to the mining tenement and the holder does not, within the time provided in the condition, do that thing, the Corporation or a person authorised by the Corporation may enter on the mining tenement with such assistance as, and take whatever action, the Corporation or that person, as the case may be, considers necessary for doing that thing, and the costs reasonably incurred by the Corporation or that person in so doing shall be a debt due and payable by the holder of the mining tenement to the Corporation or that person, as the case may be, whether or not at the time that the thing was done by the Corporation or that person the mining tenement had been cancelled, forfeited or surrendered or had expired.

``(2) A condition referred to in paragraph (1) (d) shall not entitle the Corporation, or a person authorised by it, to take any action in pursuance of the condition until the grounds on which the Corporation claims to be entitled to take or authorise the taking of such action have been referred to arbitration under a condition referred to in paragraph (1) (c), the arbitrator has determined that the holder of the mining tenement is required under the agreement to do the thing to which the matter relates and the further time (if any) determined by the arbitrator for the holder of the mining tenement to do that thing has expired.
Aboriginal consultation

``33. (1) In consulting with traditional owners in relation to an application for a mining tenement referred to in this Part, the Corporation shall ensure that the applicant is given an opportunity to present to the traditional owners for their consideration, in such reasonable form and manner as the applicant thinks fit, as explanation of the purposes for which the mining tenement is required and the mining operations to be conducted thereunder.
Determination of compensation
``34. (1) The compensation to be paid under an agreement referred to in section 31 shall be limited to compensation:
(a) for the traditional owners being deprived of the use of the surface or part of the surface of the land;
(b) for the effect that the carrying out of mining operations on the land may have on:
(i) the preservation and protection of the lifestyle, culture and traditions of the traditional owners of the land;
(ii) the social, cultural and economic structures of those owners; and
(iii) the freedom of access of those owners and their freedom to carry out, in accordance with tradition, rites, ceremonies, and other activities on the land;
(c) for damage to the surface of the land through or mining operations conducted on the land;
(d) for the traditional owners being deprived of the use of improvements on the land;
(e) for the severance of the land from other land held in trust for or occupied by the traditional owners; and
(f) for all other damage to the land or improvements on the land arising out of mining operations to be conducted under the mining tenement.
``(2) In determining the amount of compensation to be paid under an agreement referred to in section 31, no account shall be taken of minerals known or supposed to be on or under the land.
Arbitration on agreement

``35.(1) Where a Corporation and the applicant for a mining tenement cannot agree on the terms and conditions of an agreement referred to in section 31 within 12 months after the applicant having notified the Corporation in writing of the applicant's wish to commence negotiations for such an agreement or within that time the Corporation refuses or fails to enter into such negotiations, either the Corporation or the applicant, or both, may request the Minister to refer the terms and conditions to a person appointed by the Minister as a Mining Commissioner for determination of the appropriate terms and conditions of the agreement and where the Minister receives such a request the Minister shall, as soon as practicable, appoint a person under section 37C as a Mining Commissioner and that person shall thereupon proceed to determine the appropriate terms and conditions of the agreement.

``(2) In determining the terms and conditions of the agreement referred to in subsection (1) the Mining Commissioner shall have regard only to the requirements of sections 31, 32, and 33 in relation to the terms and conditions to be agreed upon and shall determine as appropriate only those terms and conditions that, in his or her opinion, should in the circumstances be acceptable to the Corporation and to the applicant and the determination of the Mining Commissioner is binding on the Corporation and the applicant.

``(3) In determining a term or condition of an agreement referred to in section 31 requiring a security to be lodged by the applicant for the mining tenement to secure the applicant's compliance with the conditions referred to in section 37, the Mining Commissioner shall take into account any security that the applicant may be required to lodge under a law of Victoria relating to mining for minerals in respect of the mining tenement and shall make his or her determination so that, as far as practicable, the applicant is not required to provide more than one security in respect of the same matter.
Applicant for mining tenement not bound to proceed with application
``36. An agreement referred to in section 31 shall not be construed so as to compel the applicant for the mining tenement to which the agreement relates to proceed with the application.
Implied conditions etc. in grant
``37. In addition to the terms and conditions subject to which a mining tenement in respect of relevant land is granted, that mining tenement shall be subject to the conditions that:

(a) the holder of the mining tenement or the holder's employees, servants or agents shall not unlawfully interfere with any historical site or object, or any Aboriginal sacred site or object, declared as such by or under a law of the Commonwealth or of Victoria;
(b) the holder of the mining tenement shall keep to a minimum the number of people associated with the exploration or development on the land to which the mining tenement relates;

(c) except for the purposes of consumption by its employees, servants, agents, contractors or sub-contractors at its camps, the holder of the mining tenement shall not bring or permit to be brought onto the mining tenement any alcohol;
(d) the holder of the mining tenement shall not bring or permit to be brought onto the mining tenement firearms of any kind or, except with the prior consent of the Corporation, any animal;

(e) the holder of the mining tenement shall at all times give full consideration to the aspirations and welfare of the local Aboriginals and co-operate with the traditional owners and not interfere with the growth and development of the Aboriginal social, cultural and economic structures on the mining tenement;

(f) the holder of the mining tenement shall employ and engage, and shall ensure that its agents, contractors and sub-contractors employ and engage, as many Aboriginals or incorporated Aboriginal associations or groups associated with the mining tenement as is practicable who are capable of carrying out, or being trained (including by on-the-job training) to carry out, in a satisfactory manner, the particular work required to be carried out in relation to the mining tenement at the usual award rates for the type of work performed and subject to the usual conditions of employment;
(g) the holder of the mining tenement shall take all reasonable steps to adjust working hours and conditions of Aboriginal employees to suit Aboriginal culture;
(h) the holder of the mining tenement shall progressively rehabilitate and restore, as far as practicable, all areas disturbed by its activities in accordance with good environmental practice;

(j) the holder of the mining tenement shall liaise with the Corporation on the exploration or development programs in relation to the mining tenement and discuss the possible relocation of proposed works and details of the program as it develops;

(k) the holder of the mining tenement shall, before carrying out a program involving substantial disturbance of the surface of the mining tenement, advise the relevant authority of the State of Victoria and the Corporation, in writing, of that program and comply with such directions as the relevant authority considers appropriate for the protection of the environment in the carrying out of the program;

(l) the holder of the mining tenement shall advise the relevant authority of the State of Victoria and the Corporation, in writing, of the proposed location of all infrastructure facilities on the mining tenement and the proposed method to be used in disposing of waste, and comply with such directions as the relevant authority considers appropriate in relation to the disposal of that waste;

(m) the holder of the mining tenement shall not erect a permanent building or facility on the mining tenement except with the approval in writing of the relevant authority of the State of Victoria; and
(n) the holder of the mining tenement shall comply with the terms and conditions of the agreement referred to in section 31 in relation to the mining tenement.
Access to Aboriginal land

``37a. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, where a person has the right under a law of Victoria to occupy relevant land by virtue of the grant of a mining tenement, that person has for himself, his employees and his agents, a right of access from a public road to that land and across other parts of the relevant land of which the mining tenement is part and any contiguous relevant land, by the shortest practicable route, being a route agreed upon by the person and the traditional owners of the land.
Right of way in respect of services etc.

``37b. (1) The grant of a mining tenement entitles the holder of the mining tenement to a right of way over relevant land for all reasonable ancillary purposes in connection with the operations to be conducted under the mining tenement.
``(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), a right of way extends to access for or in connection with:
(a) the erection and use of conveyor apparatus in connection with the transporting of minerals or substances containing minerals;
(b) the erection of electricity lines;
(c) the construction of roads;
(d) the cutting and construction of water races or drains; and
(e) the boring, sinking for, pumping, raising of or conveying of water.

``(3) Where the holder of a mining tenement is entitled under subsection (1) to a right of way, that right of way may be exercised by a route agreed to by the holder of the mining tenement and the traditional owners of the land.

``(4) Where the traditional owners and the holder of a mining tenement cannot agree on the route by which a right of way under subsection (1) may be exercised, those owners or the holder of the mining tenement, or both, may request the Minister to refer the matter to a person appointed by the Minister as a Mining Commissioner for determination and where the Minister receives such a request the Minister shall, as soon as practicable, appoint a person under section 37c as a Mining Commissioner and that person shall thereupon proceed to determine the matter.
``(5) Compensation shall be payable by the holder of the mining tenement to the relevant traditional owners in respect of a right of way under subsection (1).
``(6) The compensation to be paid under subsection (5) shall be determined on the same basis as under section 34 in respect of the grant of a mining tenement.

``(7) Where an amount of compensation payable under subsection (5) cannot be agreed upon between the traditional owners and the holder of the mining tenement, the traditional owners or the holder of the mining tenement, or both, may request the Minister to refer the matter to a person appointed by the Minister as a Mining Commissioner for determination and where the Minister receives such a request the Minister shall, as soon as practicable, appoint a person under section 37C as a Mining Commissioner and that person shall thereupon proceed to determine the matter.
``(8) A right of way under subsection (1) shall not be exercised until compensation has been paid in accordance with this section.
``(9) A determination made by the Mining Commissioner under subsection (4) or (7) is binding on the traditional owners and the holder of the mining tenement.
Appointment of Mining Commissioner
``37C. (1) Where, for the purposes of this Part, the Minister is required to appoint a Mining Commissioner, the Minister shall appoint:
(a) a person who holds, or has held, office as a Judge of the Federal Court of Australia;
(b) a legal practitioner of at least 5 years standing; or
(c) a Fellow of the Institute of Arbitrators Australia.

``(2) The Minister shall not appoint a Mining Commissioner unless the Minister has submitted to the applicant for, or the holder of, the mining tenement and the Corporation or the traditional owners of the land, as the case requires, the names of not less than 3 persons having the qualifications set out in subsection (1).
``(3) Where the Minister has submitted the names of persons to the parties under subsection (2), the Minister shall appoint as a Mining Commissioner:
(a) if the Minister is satisfied that the parties agree to the appointment of one of the persons whose names have been so submitted-the person so agreed upon; or

(b) if the Minister is satisfied that there is no reasonable prospect that the parties will so agree-a person having the qualifications set out in subsection (1) whom the Minister considers suitable to be so appointed.

``(4) A Mining Commissioner shall be assisted in the performance of his or her functions under this Part by 2 persons appointed for that purpose by the Minister of whom one shall be nominated, in writing, by the Corporation or the traditional owners of the land concerned and the other shall be nominated, in writing, by the Victorian Chamber of Mines (Incorporated).''.

This is a substantial amendment to the Bill. It relates to Part V, which contains the mining provisions. The amendment substitutes a new Part V and involves a new mining code. The Opposition has registered its very strong opposition in principle to this Bill, and although it did not succeed in the vote just taken the Opposition has indicated that the Federal Parliament should not pass an Aboriginal land rights law applicable to Victoria or, indeed, to any State. I understood that the Government has already adopted that view, as it had abandoned its notions of introducing national Aboriginal land rights legislation. Even though it has promised that to the Aboriginal people in a very solemn way, it welshed completely on its promise to provide that type of legislation.

This Bill is another confusing approach by the Government in that it is legislating specifically for Aboriginal land rights in Victoria even though it has abandoned its promises to legislate for Aboriginal land rights throughout Australia. The Government has now created a very confusing position for itself-although that is not our problem. The problem is that, in proceeding to legislate for land rights in Victoria, the Government has created great confusion in relation to Victorian laws that relate to this legislation. The mining provisions in the Bill contemplate that, under laws applicable to mining in Victoria, mining titles will be required before mining rights can be established. But of course those rights are governed and restricted by the provisions in Part V of the Bill. Those provisions introduce a completely new concept to Victorian mining law which will apply to all other mining rights and titles that are issued under this legislation. Yet somehow existing Victorian mining laws will have to be tailored to comply with the new mining scheme provided for in Part V of the Bill.

The legal problems created by the Bill would be major. Undoubtedly, they would create many legal problems, and no doubt legal challenges will be mounted as a result of the way that the Government has gone about this matter, apart altogether from the concept of a Federal Government creating new rights of access to land by Victorians, or Australians generally in Victoria.

In addition to the rights that presently exist under Victorian law, this special law will now apply, albeit to a small proportion of Victoria. However, we have no idea of the extent of the possible granting of land rights in Victoria. Although this legislation applies to only a small area of Victoria, it is setting a precedent and, in future, actions of this kind might occur in other parts of Victoria, with possibly unspecified areas of Victoria being dealt with in this way.

With these amendments we are endeavouring to remove the great doubts about the application of the Victorian mining law under which it is necessary to apply to be granted rights, even under the Government legislation, and how that would tie in with the rights created under this part of the Bill. We believe that the appropriate course to adopt, as has been the case in relation to the Northern Territory land rights legislation, is an alternative mining code in place of Part V and that is what these amendments seek to achieve. I do not need to go through them in detail, because I have already spoken to them in relation to the amendments that I moved to the Northern Territory Bill and, although the Committee did not adopt those, I believe that it should think again in relation to this Victorian Bill because, unlike the Northern Territory law, Part V does not fit very satisfactorily into Victorian law.

I have already explained-and I do not intend to repeat it tonight-the details of these amendments. Essentially, they are based on the proposals contained in Senator Kilgariff's private member's Bill which he introduced in the Senate some time ago. In short, they seek to remove the veto power at any stage of the granting of mining rights. This provision in the Bill provides for veto at both the exploration and the mining stages. The proposals contained in the amendments provide that there should be no veto power either at the exploration or at the mining stage and a code is set out whereby Aboriginal rights are protected. Compensation is required and that may be achieved by agreement with the Aboriginal owners, or by a method of arbitration. The only difference between these amendments and those contained in the Northern Territory Bill which I proposed earlier in this debate concerns the resolution of a dispute regarding compensation, if in fact an agreement is not reached. The amendments proposed to the Northern Territory Bill assign the resolution of those disputes to the Wardens Court of the Northern Territory. However, the Victorian mining legislation does not really fit very satisfactorily into that framework and, therefore, in these amendments we have adopted the Government's own proposals for resolving disputes which have not been solved by arbitration. We propose that that should be done, in the case of Victoria, because of differences between mining laws in the Northern Territory and in Victoria, as the Government has proposed, by a Mining Commissioner. That provision is contained in the Northern Territory legislation. The Mining Commissioner may be a Federal Court of Australia judge, a legal practitioner of at least five years standing or a Fellow of the Institute of Arbitrators.

I do not propose to go into any further detail in relation to these amendments because, as I have said, they are otherwise very much on all fours with the amendments which I moved earlier. The Government's proposals for Victoria allow veto at both the exploration and the mining stage. In that respect, they are wider than the Government's proposals for the Northern Territory which have been passed by the Senate. They are based on the Pitjantjatjara and Maralinga model in South Australia and that model has been in place now for five years. No new exploration or mining tenements have been granted in South Australia on those Pitjantjatjara or Maralinga Aboriginal lands. It is clearly an inadequate model, it is not working in South Australia and it seems unlikely that it will work in Victoria. In any event, it creates separate rights over land for the Aboriginal communities which are superior to those enjoyed by other Victorians. It creates that division and the legal problems that I have already mentioned. For those reasons we believe that the Senate should support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support this amendment essentially for the reasons that I spelt out in the debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987. This particular mining model is different from the Commonwealth's preferred model, as now contained in the Northern Territory legislation which we passed earlier tonight. Nonetheless, we regard it as a workable and acceptable model based as it is on the combination of Pitjantjatjara and Maralinga models in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The main point to make-and I make it very swiftly-is that this Bill has been the product of very extensive consultation with all relevant interests including, in particular, the people from the respective communities who are here tonight. That puts them in a very different class from that which the Opposition now proposes. It should be remembered that we are talking about two very small pieces of land amounting to some 12 square kilometres in all with no known prospectivity. Therefore, the debate about the appropriate mining regime has a somewhat abstract and artificial character. This should not be regarded as a precedent for legislation elsewhere, as I have already indicated, but it is appropriate and tailored for this purpose and I commend it accordingly to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on the proposed amendments, particularly on the question of whether this legislation provides a precedent. The Opposition has complained about the fact that this legislation is before the Parliament. We should remember that that is the case only because the Opposition parties in the Victorian Parliament were not prepared to pass such legislation. I, and all the Australian Democrats, would be perfectly happy if this Bill did provide a precedent. As we see it, the Labor Government has abandoned its policy for national land rights legislation and that is a matter of regret to us. If this reference to the Parliament does anything towards jockeying along land rights legislation in other jurisdictions, we welcome it. We also believe that the Australian people will welcome it on this, the twentieth anniversary of the referendum which overwhelmingly put Aboriginal affairs in the hands of the Federal Government-something which no Federal government since then has taken up. Therefore, we have supported this reference and we congratulate the Government in this for picking up the Victorian aspects. This is unique legislation due to its reference from the Victorian jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his speech on the second reading of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Bill, Senator Short raised the question of the artifacts in the Daylesford Museum in Victoria and whether their location in that museum would be affected by the general provisions of this Bill. He raised the question of the possible removal of the artefacts from the Daylesford Museum to some other area under the powers contained in this Bill. This would mean that the artefacts would be moved to an area away from where their Aboriginal originators came.
